PETITION.PRESENTERS: BELL; BOURNE; COULTER; LEES; SPINDLER; WOODLEY
PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bell (from 162 citizens), Senator Bourne (from 1,737 citizens), Senator Coulter (from 712 citizens), Senator Lees (from 2,772 citizens), Senator Spindler (from 540 citizens) and Senator Woodley (from 1,067 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1.Optometry has been covered by Medicare since its inception in 1975, and currently provides eye care to over 2.4 million people each year.
2.Removal of optometric benefits from Medicare will increase Government expenditure on eye care, as people will instead obtain their care from a more expensive source.

3.The cost to the public of eye care will increase, both through the removal of benefits for optometric consultations and the shift to ophthalmologists who generally charge well over the scheduled fee.

4.The visual welfare of the community will suffer as people are discouraged from seeking eye care. Many eye diseases, such as glaucoma, do not produce symptoms until they are in an advanced stage. Any discouragement from seeking regular eye care will increase suffering from these diseases.
5.The removal of benefits for optometric examinations will disadvantage children, as undetected visual disorders will adversely affect their development and school performance.
6.Access to eye care will be reduced, particularly in rural areas, as part-time and visiting optometric practices will no longer be economically viable, and alternate care is not available.
We therefore request that the Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal health insurance system and that all eye examinations by optometrists are covered.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Crowley (from 22 citizens), Senator Kernot (from 122 citizens), Senator McKiernan (from 13 citizens), Senator Spindler (from 44 citizens) and Senator Zakharov (from 396 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) and to decrease the threshold at which graduates begin the repay their HECS debt.

Wherefore, your petitioners, request that any further changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) be referred to a committee that will assess the impact of fees and loans on higher education.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned strongly oppose Government changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) as released in budget 1993. These changes include increasing HECS by 50% for students taking longer than the specified time to finish their degrees, increasing HECS by 100% for students doing second degrees, decreasing of the initial repayment threshold from $27,700 to $26,400 and increasing the rate of repayment from 2, 3 and 4 percent to 3, 4 and 5 percent respectively.

Wherefore, your petitioners request that any further changes OR proposed changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) be referred to a committee with student representation that will assess the impact.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Exports to Indonesia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the export of uranium extends the nuclear cycle which fuels the development of nuclear weapons;
That no satisfactory means of dealing with nuclear waste has yet been devised;
That the mining and exporting of Australian uranium contributes to the nuclear fuel cycle.
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
To withdraw from any treaty or agreement with Indonesia which will lead to the export of uranium to that country;
To foster research and development of safe and sustainable energy generation technologies in Australia and Indonesia;
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worst extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bougainville
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the plight of the people of Bougainville. We call on the Australian Government to:

PARA.TAB: end military aid to the Government of Papua New Guinea.
demand the withdrawal of the Defence Forces of Papua New Guinea from Bougainville and an end to the blockade of Bougainville.
recognise the right to self-determination of the people of Bougainville.

PETITION.TITLE: VIP Aircraft
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our strongest opposition to the Prime Minister's intentions of purchasing new VIP aircraft, particularly given that the Prime Minister is responsible for the record unemployment and worst recession in sixty years, and calls on the Prime Minister to abandon his plans to purchase any new aircraft until Australia's economy picks up and unemployment falls dramatically.
Further, that the Senate recognises the Prime Minister's previous misuse of such aircraft, in particular, his using one to fly from Canberra to Melbourne and back to watch a football game.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the Senate to oppose any plan by the Prime Minister to purchase any new VIP aircraft.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Asylum Seekers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
the Australian Government's policy of detaining people seeking asylum has caused enormous hardship and misery for those detained;
the policy has contravened international obligations undertaken by Australia;
as a result of the detention of asylum seekers the Australian community has borne a considerable financial burden;

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:

PETITION.PARA: to end the policy of detaining asylum seekers, and
to release those asylum seekers still being held in Department of Immigration Processing Centres.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lead Standards in Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: Vehicle emissions are having a serious impact on the health of Australians and include lead emissions which are of sufficient volume to cause a permanent reduction in the intellectual capacity of young children in inner city areas, and benzene emissions which are highly carcinogenic and cause acute myeloid leukemia.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate should support a national uniform and legislated standard of lead in petrol of no more than 0.026 grams per litre, and a national uniform and legislated standard of benzene in petrol of no more than 0.8 per cent of total volume.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) (EXEMPTION OF COUNCIL ALLOWANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Ian Macdonald) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: A bill for an act to amend the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) (Exemption of Council Allowances) Act 1992 to provide for local government councillors in relation to the operation of that act.
Motion (by Senator Ian Macdonald) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Of the 10,000-odd community minded persons who are Local Government elected Councillors and Aldermen within Australia, some are paid full time salaries and wages, some are paid nothing at all. The majority though do receive allowances in the form of meeting allowances paid monthly. These meeting allowances range between about $3,000 annually and $20,000 annually with the vast majority in the $5,000 to $10,000 range.

There have been rulings from the Tax Office that in relation to the Superannuation Guarantee Act, Councillors are deemed to be employees and their monthly allowances are deemed to be salary and wages.
This will mean that even for those Councillors receiving a meeting allowance which amounts to just a small annual sum, the Superannuation Guarantee Levy will have to be paid.

The effect of this though, is that where the meeting allowance received by the elected Councillor is more than 10% of his annual income, then the attachment of the Levy to those allowances precludes the recipient from claiming in his or her tax return the $3,000 tax deduction and 75% of any amounts over that figure in private superannuation over.
So for a very minor reward from the compulsory superannuation, recipients will be deprived the opportunity of claiming tax deductions on their contributions to their own superannuation savings.

This is grossly unfair and will mean that many hardworking community conscious citizens will give up their role on Local Councils simply because they cannot afford the financial burden of being prevented from obtaining the tax deduction everyone else gets when contributing to their own superannuation.
The Labor Party directly promised that it would move amendments to overcome this anomaly but nowhere in the Governments forward legislation program is the legislation mentioned.
It's just another in a long series of broken promises from this Government.

To correct the broken promises and to do what the Government undertook to do, I have introduced a Private Senators Bill and I seek the support of all sections of the Parliament in supporting this Bill to remove this anomalous provision for Local Government members and to keep the Government accountable for it's promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill relates to local government matters in an area where local government has been very poorly treated by the federal government in recent times. I mention in passing, without elucidating, the local capital works program, the review of the financial assistance grants, the pensioner rate concession matter and the fact that—not a matter for this government—the government of Queensland has introduced a new form of tax on local government.

PARA.TAB: The bill I have introduced will prevent the government from denying the right to any individual wishing to contest local government elections, as it is our belief that this should not happen because of the effects of the superannuation guarantee levy. The bill I have introduced does something that the Labor Party promised local government it would do. It did this in the form of two written pieces of material—a letter to all councils and a response to some proposals by the Australian Democrats on the superannuation guarantee levy. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard both that letter to councils by Mr David Simmons and the response to the proposal by the Australian Democrats. I have given the minister and the other groups in the Senate copies of those two pieces of material.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Minister for Family Support,
The Honourable. David Simmons, MP Federal Member for Calare
Shire Clerk
Shire of Burdekin
PO Box 974
AYR QLD 4807
Dear Shire Clerk,
SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE CHARGE
I am writing to dispel any concerns your Council may have concerning the application of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill when it comes into law later this year.

The Opposition Health Spokesman, Dr Bob Woods, has written to Councils claiming that the legislation will require Councils to provide employer sponsored superannuation on allowances paid to elected members. This claim is incorrect.

As far as Local Government elected members are concerned the new superannuation arrangements will only apply to councillors who are in receipt of salaries. Consequently, I would expect that the legislation will impact on Brisbane City Councillors only.

The Government avoided arrangements that would have characterised elected members as employees of Councils. The approach taken here is consistent with that which applies to Fringe Benefits Tax in relation to the elected members of Local Governments.
The Federal Government understands and appreciates the important voluntary work done by the thousands of Australians who are elected to represent their communities in Local Government.
Yours sincerely
DAVID SIMMONS
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Local Government Councillors

The Government intends moving an amendment to the SGC legislation to remove a technical defect that seemingly brings local councillors automatically within the definition of `employee'. The Australian Taxation Office has advised that the word `payment' in the relevant clause of the Bill be changed to the word `remuneration'.

PARA.TAB: This amendment will result in local councillors who receive salary or wages being covered by the Superannuation Guarantee. Other local councillors, who typically receive a monthly payment for attending meetings will not be covered by the Superannuation Guarantee.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill will make the government comply with the promise it made. Everybody knows these days that the government is not able to be trusted and that its promises are rarely kept. This bill, if it is passed in the Senate and adopted in the lower house, will force the Labor Party to comply with the promise it made in relation to local government.

DEBATE.TITLE: TOXIC CHEMICALS (COMMUNITY RIGHT TO KNOW) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act relating to toxic chemicals.
Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, it gives me great pleasure to reintroduce this Private Members Bill which was previously introduced by Senator Janet Powell in May of this year. I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate Senator Powell for the enormous amount of work that she and her staff put into the preparation of this very important Bill. I would also like to thank her for the invitation to pursue this Bill now that she is, unfortunately, no longer a member of this parliament.

It is very appropriate that this Second Reading speech should take place on the first day of Spring. In her famous book,"Silent Spring", Rachel Carson alerted the world to the dangers of toxic chemicals and warned against their proliferation. This Bill has taken up that challenge and proposes a system that allows the general public access to information about the use, storage, handling, transportation, recycling and manufacture of toxic chemicals.
Janet Powell neatly summarised the aims of the Bill in her Second Reading Speech on 19 May 1993. She stated:

"This Bill will not only provide for a National inventory of All toxic chemicals currently in use in Australia, but also the information relating to the health and environmental effects of toxic chemical use, reports from industry of toxic chemical releases, the production and disposal of toxic chemicals, reports on the emergency procedures that are in place and reports on methods of reducing the use of toxic chemicals. The most important and fundamental object of this legislation however, is that all of this information is to be made freely available to the community through the Registrar.

It is worth noting at this point that a legislative approach to information on toxic chemicals is not new. In the United States, for example, the concept that the community has a right to know about the hazards of toxic chemicals has had widespread acceptance since the early 1980's. This community concern was given legislative form in 1986 with the passing of the Federal "Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act" which gave the public access to information about the uses and emissions of toxic chemicals. Similar legislation, such as the well known Proposition 65 in California, has been passed in various States in the United States.

This legislative approach has proved valuable to many communities in the United States in protecting the health and well-being of their families. In an article entitled "What you don't know can hurt you. . . and what you can do about it!", Deborah Sheiman points to the fact that the 1986 Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act ". . . has become a powerful tool to community groups concerned about their environments. The law has stimulated a virtual revolution in industry attitudes towards toxic chemical releases. Many companies have voluntarily committed themselves to sharp cutbacks and, ultimately, elimination of hazardous pollutants. Armed with the right-to-know incentive, citizens are publicly demanding cleanup commitments from local industries, thus illustrating the essence of grass-roots environmentalism.

These signs of hope in the United States are in marked contrast to the despair of many communities in Australia who are battling to obtain information about the toxic chemicals that prevail in their region. In my home State of Western Australia, for example, the citizens of Welshpool in suburban Perth have been fighting for many years to find out what waste is being burnt at a commercial incinerator in Felspar Road. It is now becoming apparent that the very toxic substance PCB was being burnt in that incinerator for a number of years without proper controls, without the permission of the State Government authorities and obviously without the knowledge of the local community.

In another example, a businessman is taking action against Bunnings after he discovered seven 200 litre drums of sodium nitrate that also contained arsenic, on a property he had bought to establish a marron farm. Ironically, the drums were dumped on the site by Bunnings after advice from the W.A. Health Department. The businessman was never advised about the drums when he bought the property and was only informed of their existence by neighbours. Soil and water samples have confirmed that arsenic and chromium have leached into the surrounding area and the farm is now useless for marron breeding.

In Lorinna, in Northern Tasmania, a local community has been fighting the Tasmanian Forestry Commission for many years about the use of a chemical known as Atrazine for weed suppression in plantation areas. Their difficulty has been in obtaining information about the toxicity of the chemical and the recommended levels that have been set by international agencies such as the World Health Organisation. The information was finally obtained by my office with the assistance of researchers in the Parliamentary Library and assisted in determining that the level of Atrazine in the streams which provide the local community with drinking water was in excess of World Health Organisation recommended levels.

The Coode Island disaster was referred to by Janet Powell in her Second Reading speech and I commend fellow Senators to obtain a copy of her speech and read the appropriate sections. It is appropriate in this context, however, to refer to the final report of the Independent Coode Island Review Panel of March 1992 which recommended the enactment of Community Right to Know legislation ". . . to assist public understanding of hazardous materials and the production processes." That recommendation should be followed at both State and Federal level.

The work of Naomi Segal and the Western Australian group "Householders for Safe Pesticide Use" should also be mentioned. Naomi and her group work tirelessly in the community fighting to obtain information about the use, storage and disposal of toxic chemicals. Their work would be substantially eased if legislation such as this were passed. Rather than battling against bureaucratic inertia and claims commercial confidentiality, the information they seek would be available from a central registry authority and they could then concentrate their efforts in promoting a safer environment for all communities.

This Legislation should not be considered to be an extension of F.O.I. It goes further by establishing the doctrine that toxic chemicals information affects the whole community and as such the community has the right to obtain such data. It will no longer be the privilege of those whose vested interest it is to keep this information out of the public gaze.

As such the Bill has a strong connection with the Whistleblowers Protection Bill 1993 which I intend to formally introduce in the Senate on the 1st October. In many ways the two Bills are complementary. The Community Right to Know legislation will force corporations to place on the public record all information relating to the manufacture, use, storage and disposal of toxic chemicals.

It is extremely appropriate to be introducing this legislation today when this matter is coming under scrutiny at an environmental law conference in Hobart over the next three days. Professor Gunningham, the director of the Australian Centre for Environmental Law at ANU commented this morning that legislation of this type is very important because there is a clear need for a regulatory framework in addition to industry codes of practice.

The Whistleblowers Protection Bill will provide protection to those people who are forced to "blow the whistle" on companies and individuals who fail to act responsibly. Both of these Bill address the need for greater accountability through by providing for greater disclosure in the public interest.
As Senator Powell pointed out in her second reading speech, the major elements of the Bill include;

1) The establishment of a Registrar, who collects information, as contained in the Objects of the Act, from the chemical industry and makes that information available to the public upon request. This will be done through the creation of an on-line data base, available at local libraries, a 008 phone number or through application to the Registrar's office. Studies both in Australia and overseas have shown that the chemical industry is unwilling to respond directly to community requests for information. Through the establishment of an independent Registrar these barriers will be taken away.
2) Provision of information about emergency procedures, health and environment effects and reports on releases of toxic chemicals for public perusal and comment.

Clearly the environment would benefit greatly from the introduction of this Legislation. As a result of the publicly accessible data base and telephone hotline, the public would be able to discover hitherto secret information about toxic releases from chemical facilities. Facilities would report toxic releases to air, water and land. Already in the United States since the introduction of the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act in 1986,

3) Public involvement throughout the process of implementing and developing the framework provided for in this Legislation. For example, the Registrar will, in consultation with industry and community bodies, develop codes of practice regarding the safe production and use of toxic chemicals.

Obviously industry self-regulation, although attempting to have the community's interests at heart, does not have the required commitment to work openly with the public. This Legislation would make the chemical industry more accountable to the community. Through the provisions in the Bill the public can find out what chemicals a business is using.

The Legislation would guarantee public access to chemical information for use in emergency response, pollution prevention and/or control and local community information or action groups. The information would also be useful for land use planning, insurance, property transfer or any other public purpose.

I trust that this Bill will be given serious consideration by all Honourable Senators and may I finish with the words of Janet Powell who stated that, "this Bill represents an important step forward in the protection of the health and safety of Australians and the environment in which we live.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of this Bill, the second of these two associated Bills, is to amend the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 to set the amount of the charge payable under the previous Bill and to specify when the charge is to be paid.
This Bill provides that the annual charge payable for ASO safeguards activities by each uranium producer is $500,000, or a lesser amount if the regulations so provide.

Mr President, I said in my earlier remarks that the uranium companies would pay no more than is reasonable, having regard to the nature and costs of the relevant activities undertaken by ASO. This will be achieved by ensuring that the regulations annually specify an amount, less than the upper limit in the Bill, which represents the reasonable costs of the relevant activities undertaken by the ASO in that year.

It is the Government's clear intention that the uranium companies will be fully consulted each year on the planned program of ASO activities and costs and the charge proposed, before the final charge is set in the regulations. In other words, company officials will sit down each year with the Director of Safeguards and other relevant officials and seek to agree on the level of ASO activity in relation to the companies' operations.

Naturally, the Government must retain the ultimate responsibility to determine the annual charge to ensure that the safeguards and physical protection programs fully meet all requirements and obligations, so that the uranium mining companies may keep operating. However, the views of the companies will be fully considered each year, and the Government will itself continue to pay for ASO activities which benefit the Government and the Australian community generally.

The ASO's program of activities for 1993-94 is of course not determined at this stage, so the charge for 1993-94 cannot yet be specified. We have, however, arrived at an indicative charge based on ASO's 1992-93 program. On this basis, we estimate an annual charge of about $340,000 for each of the uranium companies. For its part, the Government would contribute annually about $250,000 in connection with ANSTO operations and a further $460,000 for wider community benefits.

The maximum charge specified in the Bill—of $500,000 for each uranium producer—has been set to ensure that the legislation will not require frequent amendment. I emphasise, however, that it does not represent in any sense the charge that will in fact be payable by the companies unless and until their reasonable shares of ASO costs should approach this amount.

Finally, Mr President, the intended sanction in the event of failure to pay the charge provided in the Bill is revocation of the permit to possess the relevant nuclear material. Revocation is possible if permit conditions are not complied with, and all relevant permits will require the payment of the charge from the date of commencement.
I commend this Bill to honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 241 be taken as formal.
—Is there any objection to this motion being taken as formal?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion no. 241 standing in the name of Senator Hill for this day, relating to the tabling of documents by the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for suspension is that this matter has to be dealt with today because the return date in the motion is tomorrow. You will recall, Mr President, that what we are seeking to achieve by this motion is to require the government to table such legal advices as it got in relation to the preparation of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and also the drafting instructions in relation to that bill.

PARA.TAB: The critical importance of the matter is that the constitutionality of the bill is very much under question. I have already tabled in this place two opinions from learned counsel to the effect that the bill is unconstitutional. The Senate is therefore being asked to deal with a piece of prospective legislation, the constitutional validity of which is very much in doubt.

Yesterday, the Senate—I might say very sensibly—resolved to send the issue as a whole to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report, and it will report in a fortnight. But the committee does not have the power the Senate has to require the tabling of essential documents. It seems to us that, in order that the committee can properly complete its function, it should have before it not only the opinion the minister tabled yesterday but the preliminary opinion upon which the considered opinion of yesterday was based.

We understand that the government instructed the draftsmen to draft this bill in a way that would make it particularly difficult for the Senate to oppose the government's increases in tax and new taxes. It did that by asking the draftsmen to link with those taxes the so-called benefits in the bill—the benefits in relation to Medicare and the taxation reductions, although they are just half of the reductions the government promised at the last election. Nevertheless, to link together tax increases with other matters was to make it more difficult for this Senate to oppose those particular taxes. So the drafting instructions to that effect are of great interest to the Senate and, I would have thought, to the standing committee because it can get to the motive of the government in putting the bill in this most unusual—some have suggested to me unprecedented—form.

As we understand it, the next step in that process was, not surprisingly, that the draftsmen were uncomfortable and wanted a legal opinion from within the government before they were prepared to draft in that way. We are told that that opinion was obtained. That is presumably the preliminary opinion referred to by Mr Rose in his considered opinion that we received yesterday, and I am sure that the Senate would be vitally interested to see exactly what Mr Rose said on that occasion.

The matter is of major consequence. I think perhaps the Greens and the Australian Democrats are not totally cognisant of the consequences of this bill, if it becomes law, then failing before the High Court next year. The advice of counsel in the opinions I have put to the Senate is that the whole act would then collapse. The benefits of the changes under Medicare would disappear; the tax reductions that are included in the piece of legislation would disappear; the credit unions would be thrown into turmoil because they are now to be taxed under this bill and that taxation imposition would be lost; the increases in wholesale sales tax would disappear and there would be the incredibly complex legal issue as to what right there would be for recovery of tax; and the wine tax would go, with consequences as to whether the recovery of that sales tax could be made. Everyone in the community would be wondering whether they should have kept receipts for their taxes. The whole position would be one of turmoil.

At least the government, I would have thought, would recognise that it has a responsibility to prepare its legislation in a form where this is least likely to occur. It has not met that responsibility. In order to achieve its grubby political objective, it has put this bill in a form where it is very much in doubt constitutionally. This Senate, before it proceeds with the matter further, has the right to have on the table what legal advices the government got to justify that course of action and the drafting instructions so that we can see transparently exactly what the government's motive was and the risk to which it was prepared to put the economy of Australia to achieve its political agenda. That is all this motion seeks to do. That is why it is urgent; it has to be returned tomorrow. I urge the Senate to support the suspension and then the substantive motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will oppose the suspension of standing orders to deal with this matter, for two reasons: one has to do with the specifics of this particular situation; and the second has to do with larger general principles that apply to exercises in seeking documentation of this kind.

PARA.TAB: As to the specifics of this particular situation, let me say this: the matter in issue here is the constitutionality of the particular product—the bill that is now before the Senate. It is obviously a matter of legitimate public interest, it is obviously a matter of legitimate Senate interest, to be satisfied that the bill in its present form is constitutional and that there will not be the kinds of adverse consequences that might conceivably flow from its being otherwise.

There is no difficulty, from the government's point of view, about the Senate debating that, looking at it, and we have not resisted the reference of the matter to a committee. The government will fully facilitate the committee's consideration of this particular substantive issue. We have already tabled yesterday the very detailed 13-page opinion by the Chief General Counsel, Dennis Rose, explaining the constitutional foundations on which we relied throughout the drafting process and on which we rely now.

The matter in issue in this particular case—the constitutionality of the final product—will be able to be fully explored. There is no issue here about malfeasance, possible misbehaviour by public servants, or some other question of public interest possibly being involved such as might conceivably justify an exploratory examination of the process by which these bills came to light. I do not want to concede any ground in a particular case that might arise in the future but, obviously, different considerations arise about the production of documentation if that kind of public interest issue is involved. There is none of that kind here.

As to the motivation for the bills coming forward in this compendious form about which Senator Hill waxed lyrical a moment ago, there is no issue about the motivation. We made it perfectly clear that this is a new precedent that is being created to bring together revenue measures of this kind in this particular way. We acknowledge that. It was done very specifically for a policy purpose in order to demonstrate the interconnectedness of these revenue measures and the need for a responsible—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to the Senate.

—I will say that quite frankly; it has been said. It was done to demonstrate the need for a responsible approach to the revenue measures, to treat them as a whole and not to cherrypick. That is the motivation. There is no point in exploring the background to that. That is quite overtly and frankly acknowledged.

PARA.TAB: The matter in issue, I repeat, is the constitutionality of the product. There will be sufficient material before the Senate committee to enable it to reach a considered conclusion on that. We will fully cooperate in the production of relevant witnesses and in other ways that the committee might seek to enable it to reach that result. So this kind of material is not needed in order to answer the question that is legitimately before the Senate committee at the moment.

The second side of the equation—the second response I make to this—is the one based on general principles. I am a strong advocate of freedom of information, a strong advocate of transparency in government, a strong advocate of open processes. I was in opposition; I am in government. I put my money where my mouth was and I introduced major changes to the freedom of information legislation when I was Attorney-General. Those opposite do not have to argue with me about these principles. But there is a limit to the extent to which this kind of material can be constantly, routinely exposed. There are obvious and accepted limits so far as matters that are potentially the subject of court proceedings are concerned. There are well established limits so far as privacy of a personal kind is concerned, commercial confidentiality and impact on international relations. There are limits.

There ought also to be limits so far as the government's preparation of legislation is concerned. The government must have the capacity to have frank exchanges with its legal advisers—Attorney-General's, the Chief General Counsel and the Solicitor-General. It must have the capacity to have exchanges of views, both orally and in writing, backwards and forwards, while legislation is being crafted and particular options are explored, in some cases being pursued and in other cases being ruled out.

To have that entire process exposed and to be made the subject of political assault or political fishing expeditions is not something that contributes to good, frank government in the sense of a good, frank relationship between the government and its advisers. It is not something which contributes in any way to rational government process. That is a point that has been frankly acknowledged by those on the other side when they were in government; it ought to be frankly acknowledged now. There are limits. This motion goes beyond them, and we will resist it accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a critically important motion and it would be entirely regrettable if the Australian Democrats or any other party in the Senate did not appreciate the fundamental significance of what the government is maintaining. A very important concession by Senator Gareth Evans this morning is that the government deliberately set out to lump together a whole range of taxes and tax increases with the One Nation tax cuts. That is precisely what was in mind when the founding fathers put in the prohibitions about tacking and tried to ensure that each taxation measure was dealt with separately.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans's admission today is a very stark revelation of our concerns. All that we have been provided with to date is essentially one in-house, after-the-event opinion. One understands that we are in the game of politics. Therefore, it is very much in the government's interest to have someone come along and validate its actions. It is an entirely different matter to explore what it had in mind originally when it engaged in this tacking, or indeed tacky, exercise to try to frustrate the express terms of the constitution. That is why it is critically important that we have some outside, independent advice. I note that we still do not have the opinion of the Solicitor-General to whom Senator Gareth Evans has always been able to resort very readily; it would be indeed surprising if that officer is not trotted out in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I do not want to do this, but I believe that the issue, the policy surrounding the motion itself, motion 241, is being debated and not the suspension of standing orders. I would have thought that it is important to get to the general debate on the motion as soon as possible.

—Senator Harradine is right in that the merits or not of this case are being discussed. This is the problem we have always found ourselves with and I think it is one of the reasons that led to time limits on debate. Therefore, although Senator Harradine is correct, I will be lenient and allow Senator Alston to continue.

—My remarks really can be taken as those that would have been made later on. The point to be made—and Senator Evans has tried to make the opposite case—is that, unless we know what the government had in mind and address the underlying instructions, we do not know precisely the extent to which the government is trying to circumvent the constitution. Those documents become very relevant indeed. We do not have an opinion from the Attorney-General at this stage and, unless and until we have that, the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will not be in a position to make an intelligent judgment about the constitutionality of the bills.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very important indeed and very significant that the government is hiding in this manner, clearly embarrassed by what I would have thought was now a transparent ploy—as conceded by Senator Evans this morning. Therefore, unless we can have this matter dealt with today and passed prior to 2 September, the Senate will be complicit in frustrating that committee's activities and will not be able to properly get to the bottom of a very important issue that goes to the heart of the funding of the business of government.

It is entirely regrettable that Senator Evans has had to resort to all the red herrings which he has. We are not talking here about commercial-in-confidence matters or inhibiting frankness and candour in discussions. Indeed, one would assume that in giving instructions the government does act in good faith. Judging by the way Senator Evans has portrayed the matter today, it is clear that there are some very real concerns on that count.

Unless we have access to those original instructions and unless we know what the views held by those in positions of authority were before the legislation was drafted, we cannot make judgments that go to the heart of the matter. All we will have instead will be rationalisations after the event by those who are beholden to their political masters. That is why it is critically important to know what the facts were at the relevant time.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two issues involved in this particular debate on the suspension of standing orders. The first issue relates to the substance of the matter which has been adverted to. Although I appreciate Senator Harradine's intervention, I do believe that that is part of the debate that needs to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: The second issue relates to the political embarrassment that could result for the government if drafting instructions were to be released and publicised. The Democrats take the view that in this particular instance such a course is not warranted. Already this morning the government, through Senator Gareth Evans, has advised in so many words what its intention was. Quite clearly, it did want to make it more difficult for amendments to this particular bill to be undertaken by this House. That is quite clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—Senator Evans may not have said it in those words, but I believe that what he said very clearly leads to that implication.
—Not technically more difficult; just politically more difficult. It is a subtle but important distinction.

—I believe that we are engaged in a political debate on the budget and how it should be addressed, and whether the legislation that has been introduced by the government should be amended and in what form it should be.

PARA.TAB: We have supported the coalition in the reference to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs because we believe that that is the proper forum in which to address this matter. This will be done. The committee will receive opinions. Indeed, some opinions have already been placed on public record in this chamber. We have the power to have before us further opinions. After all, the matter to be decided is whether this bill is a bill imposing taxation or is not a bill imposing taxation. When that question is clear, I trust that the government will see the sense in splitting the bill and enabling the Senate to go about its business to amend it, as it rightfully should.

I believe that the question of whether we should force the disclosure of drafting instructions is irrelevant to this consideration. I also believe that it harbours some degree of danger for future instances of this type. I believe that in this particular instance it would not add very much to the government's embarrassment, which I believe it is already suffering; nor would it add very much in terms of substantive information or a substantive argument.

To some extent, however, I do accept that there could be situations in which the government has exchanged opinions with its legal advisers which should not be, as a matter of public policy, disclosed to the public at large. I am a little uncomfortable about that because essentially I do believe in transparency of government processes. I do accept, though, that there might be occasions when public policy considerations demand that drafting instructions and other confidential legal advice are not published at large. In a sense, it is a side issue, but we do not wish to contribute to creating a press precedent.

I repeat: we believe that the proper avenue for this parliament to decide whether this bill is a bill imposing taxation is the committee. The committee will be meeting shortly. It will determine its procedures and it will determine dates for public hearings. It will be able to have before it all the information it requires to make that decision. Therefore, the Democrats will not be supporting this motion for a suspension of standing orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of this debate is one that has been addressed by the Senate on a number of occasions in the past. In fact, there is a clearly established set of precedents that covers what is before us this morning. The debate is between the right of the public to have access to information and, on the other hand, the right of the executive to conduct its deliberations with some degree of secrecy and without intrusion from places such as the Senate.

PARA.TAB: It has always been accepted in our system that it is the privilege of ministers and of the executive to deliberate, to contemplate and to take advice as they request in a way that they can treat it as confidential. That has been established as a precedent in place. If one wants to look at some of the precedents, one can find former attorneys-general from this side of parliament and from the other side who have established that benchmark.

One could very quickly go to quotations from people such as Mr Greenwood QC and Mr Ellicott QC, both former attorneys-general, and the submission they made in 1972 on the question of the powers of parliamentary committees and the protection afforded to witnesses. They made it very clear that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the process of cabinet government and the security of military information would be seriously prejudiced if all information on these matters was readily available either to a House or a committee of the House, whether in public or in camera. This we think is quite evident.

TALK.START.PARA: —The truth might get out.

—Senator Alston says, `The truth might get out'. What we have before us here is a situation in which the government has, in fact, made available the legal advice. That underscores the way that this area of the law has always operated and the way this area of precedent has always operated; that is, it is very much within the discretion of the parliament and the executive to make available information, legal advice and the like in this area.

PARA.TAB: That has been established for quite some time and, hopefully, the opposition accepts that. To that extent, yesterday the government made available the legal advice on the constitutionality of the budget. As Senator Spindler says, that relates to the fundamental issue before this parliament and before the committee.

Let us look at the hypocrisy on the other side—the hypocrisy that drives those opposite into this place. Let us accept that there is a principle that is very much within the capacity and prerogative of the government to make available documents as it likes, particularly legal documents. Let us also accept the words of Mr Byers, a long time Solicitor-General of the Crown, in 1975 when he underscored the principle that this policy is based on. The Hansard of 1975 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The central constitutional notion is the secrecy of deliberations. It is something that has always been accepted in here.

What about the hypocrisy of those opposite? Before the election they went to the people with an industrial relations policy. No matter how much the public screamed for them to make available not only their legislation but also their drafting instructions, they claimed that those instructions should have been kept confidential. John Howard and John Hewson ran around the country asserting that those drafting instructions and deliberations should be kept within their province.

PARA.TAB: That leads to the next point. Private member's bills that come to this parliament are also developed on the basis of drafting instructions. Members of parliament always assert the right for those drafting instructions to remain confidential to ensure that all those deliberations can be as broad based and as wide ranging as possible. For months before the election those opposite refused to show their legislation. Not only that, they also refused to show the drafting instructions. Now they come in here, spooked by the likes of Senator Bishop driving them to abort principles that they have stood for for decades.

The real reason we are having this debate this morning is that Senator Hill and John Hewson want to be seen to be tough. Why do they want that? Because the heat is right on them. Alexander Downer was up in the gallery last night telling people, `We have to oppose the tax measures because if we don't Bronwyn Bishop will come in right over the top of us'. That is exactly what is happening here today. If those opposite do not believe me, they can ask the journalists. This is a fraud that has been perpetrated on the Senate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the remarks made by Senator Hill. In doing so, I remind those following this debate that the first requirement of this Senate is to make sure that the laws it has passed are constitutionally valid. That is the first prescription that is required of all members of all parties on all sides in this place—to make sure that the laws we pass are constitutionally valid. The second requirement is to go into the details of how these laws affect their constituent members in the wider electorate.

PARA.TAB: Earlier today I gave notice of a motion which called on the government to present its taxation and other budget bills in a manner meeting the prescriptions of the Australian constitution. This was a second reminder to the Senate of getting its priorities right.

This Senate has been humiliated on a number of occasions—indeed, this parliament has—because we have not paid enough attention to the detail of the laws that we pass. I remind honourable senators of the recent High Court case involving the interpretation of certain capital gains provisions and what is known as 160 M6 and M7. Basically, the High Court judges indicated in the Hepples decision that it was a disgrace for the parliament to present laws that were so incoherent. It is not surprising to see the manner in which they brought down that particular decision.

Therefore, it is a timely reminder at this time that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, acknowledges that this legislative approach is novel. Today for the first time we heard from him some admission that all is not quite well in the state of Denmark. Quite obviously, I acknowledge that he was not party to this original scheme. That is not surprising, because it is well known in the community that the Treasurer does not get on well with his Treasury officers and advisers. So they have allowed him to stew in his own mire, and we have a real mess on our hands, which is of the government's making.

We really have to ensure that we have adequate time for a full and fair examination of all the opinions that are available to see that the legislation before us is constitutionally right. Unfortunately, the government—in case people are not aware—is employing a very despicable tactic known as tacking, which is, in this case, adding tax raising measures to what are otherwise known as benefit issues, which technically are not taxing bills. I remind the Senate that, as a result of moving down this path and considering those bills not as taxing bills, the government is opening up the possibility of their being amended in this place.
Mr President, I draw your attention to section 55 of the Australian constitution, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Laws imposing taxation shall deal only with the imposition of taxation, and any other provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect.
Section 53, which deals with the powers of the Senate in terms of legislation, states:
Proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys, or imposing taxation, shall not originate in the Senate.
We are aware of that. It continues:

But a proposed law shall not be taken to appropriate revenue or moneys, or to impose taxation, by reason only of its containing provisions for the imposition or appropriation of fines or other pecuniary penalties, or for the demand or payment or appropriation of fees for licences, or fees for services under the proposed law.
It goes on:
The Senate may not amend the proposed laws imposing taxation, or proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

I wish to make it very clear that the Liberal-National coalition is not by any stretch of the imagination blocking supply or changing the appropriation bills. We are concerned about the taxation legislative prescription that is laid down by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I therefore think it is incumbent on us to ensure that we get the widest field of independent advice. Knowing Senator Gareth Evans's interest in constitutional issues, I am sure that he would not wish to be a party to what has gone on before. We are all aware that this prescription has been forced upon the advisers. We are not condemning the Australian Democrats; this situation is of the government's making. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the suspension of standing orders on the basis that this matter is urgent. It goes to certainty before the law. Of all things, that is very important to the whole of the people who are likely to be affected by this measure.
—Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:

That general business notice of motion no. 241 standing in the name of Senator Hill for this day, relating to the tabling of documents by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business until determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That there be laid on the Table of the Senate, on or before the adjournment of the Senate on 2 September 1993, by the Leader of the Government in the Senate:
(a)any opinions provided by the Solicitor-General, the Attorney-General's Department or the Office of Parliamentary Counsel concerning either:

TAB.TAB: (i)the drafting and validity of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993; or
(ii)the question whether the kinds of provisions which are contained in the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, if enacted, may lawfully be combined in a single bill; and

PARA.TAB: (b)the documents containing each and every drafting instruction, including new and revised drafting instructions, received by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel for the purpose of drafting the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion would require the government to table the legal opinions it received in relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill, together with drafting instructions and other related matters. I canvassed the reasons for that, outlining the importance of the issue, in the debate we just had on the suspension of standing orders and I do not want to repeat what I said. I want to pick up the apparent motive that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) put to us, I think for the first time, as to why the government had linked the tax increases and tax impositions in this bill to the so-called attractive aspects. I do so by reminding the Senate of the constitutional provisions and the reasons that they exist.

PARA.TAB: Section 53 of the constitution contains one of the very few restraints that exist upon the Senate; it basically states that we are limited in relation to bills imposing taxation. We cannot amend bills imposing taxation. The balance to that was section 55 which provided that, if the Senate was going to accept that very limiting restraint, it could not be abused. Firstly, in the case of a bill imposing taxation, the government could not put before the Senate any other matter linked to the same bill. In other words, it could not tack on other matters. Secondly, it had to put before the Senate each bill imposing taxation separately. That was the balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read it out.
—I do not think my colleague Senator Watson likes my paraphrasing; I thought I had done a reasonable job. He wants me to quote specifically from section 55 of the constitution which states:

PARA.TAB: Laws imposing taxation shall deal only with the imposition of the taxation, and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the first protection of the rights of the Senate. The second protection contained in section 55 is:

PARA.TAB: Laws imposing taxation, except laws imposing duties of customs or of excise, shall deal with one subject of taxation only. . .

SPEECH.PARA: So the two protections are in there for the benefit of the Senate because, under section 53 of the constitution, the Senate has conceded the power to amend bills imposing taxation. Normally there is no problem in that regard. The government brings to the Senate these bills imposing taxation separately. It does not attempt to tack on other matters. Under section 53 of the constitution, the Senate can then vote for or against the tax bill, and there is no difficulty.

PARA.TAB: But in this instance, as Senator Gareth Evans said to the Senate a few moments ago, the government deliberately sought to link the issues together because it wanted the Australian people, in his terms, to see the taxation package as just that—a package. The new taxes, the extended taxes, the benefits to Medicare and the reductions of tax were all to be linked together. That was the motive of the government, as Senator Gareth Evans just said.

In doing so the government has obstructed our capacity to deal with those new impositions of taxes in a way that would appear, on the face of this matter, to be unconstitutional. The government is restricting our capacity by virtue of the restraints that are accepted in section 53 of the constitution, and it cannot do that. So far in this place we have put down two opinions. Further opinions will be put before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that will make clear that that is an abusive process.

The government has sought to abuse the process of the Senate in a way which restricts our capacity to deal with these impositions of taxation. It cannot get away with that. It should not get away with it because the Democrats and the Greens and, no doubt, Senator Harradine will in due course recognise it is an abusive process and will say to the government: `Do what is right. Take the bill back, redraft it in a form that is constitutional'. That is not difficult. The government simply has to take back the bill and split up these various tax bills, as was intended by the constitution.

I am told that will probably require 11 separate bills as there are 11 separate impositions of tax contained within this one bill. But that is the government's obligation. The Senate can then address each of those taxes separately, as the constitution requires us to do. That is the error in the government's ways and we regret that it is not recognising the danger of putting an unconstitutional bill before the Senate. As it will not recognise that, it will not accept it; as it wants to push on with this, notwithstanding the constitutional risks, for its own political imperatives, it is important that the Senate ensures that it is in the best informed position for the forthcoming debate.

We will be better informed if we have the drafting instructions which, I am quite confident, will make clear to the Senate and to the Australian people that this is an abusive process and that the draftsmen were seriously worried about what they were being told to do by the government to do for its political objectives. We will know that when we have those drafting instructions on the table. We will be particularly interested to see what the Solicitor-General said at that time, not what the Solicitor-General said in the opinion dated the 30th of this month which Senator Gareth Evans tabled yesterday. We want to know what advice was given to the government at that time in relation to the abusive process that it was seeking to bring into this chamber.

We on this side of the chamber believe strongly that, in these circumstances, we have a right to see those documents. In normal everyday circumstances we do not. We do not seek the internal opinions of the government. We do not seek drafting instructions. But this matter is unprecedented. It is of critical importance to Australia because if this bill fails before the High Court the results will be calamitous to industry. There will be an enormous mess. That is why the Senate must demand that it is in the best informed position when the time comes to vote on these bills.

If we are in the best informed position, the government will have no alternative but to take the bill away, draft it correctly and bring back a series of bills imposing taxation, as it should have done in the first instance. That is why, particularly at this last moment, I urge the Australian Democrats and the Greens, who have a very major responsibility in this regard, to join with us and make the government show us and the Australian people the full picture.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also spoke on the procedural motion addressing, no doubt improperly, some substantial issues at the same time. I do not want to repeat that particular ground, and I will keep my remarks as short as Senator Hill did.

PARA.TAB: Let me address several of the issues that have already arisen in the debate. I make the point yet again that the matter in issue here is the constitutionality of the product; that is, the actual bill that is now before the parliament. It simply does not help our understanding of the constitutionality of the bill as it is now before us by poking and fiddling away at the various process issues that were involved in producing that product. What matters is whether in the result we got it right or wrong when we proceeded as we did.

As I have already said, we are very much prepared to help the committee with that by tabling the detailed opinion of Mr Rose, which sets out the basis on which we put this together, and we will cooperate further with witnesses in proper discussion across the table in the committee. I have no doubt that at the end of the day we will be able to persuade the Senate that there is no problem in all of this.

Although we are unwilling, for the larger reasons of principle that I spelt out, to open up this whole Pandora's box of drafting instructions and other internal memos and things that have flown backwards and forwards in this, as in other drafting exercises, I say to the Senate quite frankly that, on the information that I have been given, there is absolutely nothing in terms of any documentation which may already exist which is inconsistent with the terms of the Rose opinion. In other words, the issues of legal principle that we are talking about here are pretty well understood in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and in the Attorney-General's department. There is no great argument about the bottom line—about what can constitutionally be yoked to or linked with other things. I am told that there is no disagreement in any of this material with the bottom lines that are now formally set out in the Rose opinion that is already before you.

We are not in a position to verify the statement I have just made because we are not willing to provide the documentation. But, for what it is worth, I want to indicate that it is not a matter of the government having anything to hide or wanting to hide anything in this instance; it is a matter of being very firm about the precedent that there are matters that governments must be entitled to keep within house while policy is being developed and while appropriate legal strategies to implement policy are being developed.

As I have said, there is no secret about the motive. It was for demonstration and presentation purposes to make clear that there was a connection between the amendments increasing tax rates and removing exemptions, rebates and deductions on the one hand, and amendments reducing tax liability on the other hand. The fiscally responsible approach that we adopted demanded that. We have absolutely nothing to hide in that respect. It is very clear. It is implicit, and I think explicit, in what has been said by a number of people. I have certainly been explicit about it today. So there is no great triumph to be gained from the committee process by extracting anything to confirm that because that is very clear.

The question is: what are the consequences of our being wrong? This is something for the committee to ponder, but let me say a word or two about that. So far as the Senate is concerned, much has been made by the opposition about the dangers and democratic parliamentary problems associated with so-called tacking; that is, having multiple revenue measures run together. I say two things about that. First, if one adopted an absolutely strict and literal reading of the kind that Senator Hill seems to want of section 55 of the constitution, one really would have no subject matter dealing in any way with the imposition of taxation sitting alongside any other subject matter. We would have many more multiple packages of bills than has been the practice in the past. It has often been the case that a number of different revenue measures that have dealt in one way or another with the imposition of taxation have been put together.

The only unique thing about this particular package is that we have a number of matters dealing with the imposition of taxation, increasing tax rates, removing exemptions and so on which are linked at the same time with some amendments reducing tax liability. That is probably unique, and that is why this issue has come to public attention in the way that it has. Please do not get carried away by the notion that in the past every single kind of taxing measure has been dealt with in its own piece of legislation, enabling a debate on the policy issues about that particular taxing measure. That has not been the case in the past, as all sorts of things have been linked together, and nor will it be the case in the future.

Secondly, there is no inhibition that follows from this in terms of the actual powers of the Senate. Of course, there is a difference technically between a capacity to amend a bill, which we do not have if it is a bill imposing tax, and a capacity simply to make requests of the House of Representatives if it is a bill dealing with taxation. There is a technical distinction, but it is a distinction without a difference in practice, as we all know. The Senate can make just as much a nuisance of itself to the government of the day by making a request and insisting upon that request as it can by insisting upon an amendment. So for all practical purposes, however much we might huff and puff—and I think Senator Watson and Senator Hill ought to acknowledge that—

TALK.START.PARA: —It just doesn't go to a third reading. That is the only difference.

—It just goes backwards and forwards. The effect is the same in terms of the opposition's capacity to stymie the legislation going through. I do not think we ought to get too overwrought by that. The other matter relates to the alleged dire consequences that may flow if Dennis Rose is wrong, if I am wrong and if the government is wrong in the assumption that one can, in fact, have—
—That is the difference.

—I will come to that. I do not want to go on at nauseous length, because I promised to be short. Let me say quickly that it is very clear from the Rose opinion, from the Air Caledonie case and from a well-established body of precedent that all of this is a bit of a storm in a teacup. Even if it is the case that one cannot put these particular measures together, what matters—
—Don't get yourself locked into this. Your reputation could be at stake here.

—What the Air Caledonie case says—and it is a fairly extraordinary proposition when one thinks about it, but nonetheless this is clear-cut law—is that if one has an amending bill, as this is, which itself purports to amend a number of other parent acts, even if that amending bill is in a sense improperly dealing in a multiple fashion with more than it should, at the end of the day what matters—
—Your time is up.

—I know. I am just being kind to Senator Hill's colleague by explaining what the issues are. At the end of the day what matters is not that; rather it is the status of the parent act as amended. As long as the parent act as amended by one clause of this particular amending bill is itself an act or a law dealing only with the imposition of taxation or only with one subject, then there is absolutely no problem.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day we can huff and puff, and even if we are wrong in the basic assumptions here, at the end of the day it makes not a ha'p'orth of difference to the constitutionality of the final result. So I think all of that needs to be taken into account. I understand that Senator Harradine might be minded to move an amendment. Since I will not have another opportunity to speak—

TALK.START.PARA: —Please acknowledge that that case is not identical with the issue of deficit reduction.

—No, I do not acknowledge that. I think it is squarely an issue here, and Mr Rose has made that clear. Senator Harradine was contemplating an amendment—I do not know whether he will move it—in which he was seeking to draw a distinction between the policy issues, at least relating to taxation policy, that might be involved in this documentation which apparently he regards as possibly genuinely immune from scrutiny and other sorts of issues.

PARA.TAB: Having thought about the matter, I do not honestly think that is a distinction that can be accepted in this particular context. What matters is the government's capacity not only to debate internally in a preparatory way the substantive policy issues that are involved, but also to debate with its legal advisers the technical issues that are concerned in this kind of legislation. I am sure the opposition, in its quieter and more constructive moments, contemplating the possibility of ever being back in government, would have the horrors at the prospect of every layer of internal debate backwards and forwards being exposed to possibly conceivably politically motivated scrutiny at the end of the day.

There is a limit in public interest terms as to how far one can go in doing this. I have sketched out some of those limits previously; I will not bore everybody by doing so again. But that is the reason why the government takes the very strong view that this motion ought not be accepted. But I repeat that we will be completely cooperative with the committee in enabling it to wrestle with the substantive issues that are now in front of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also spoke during the earlier debate on the motion to suspend standing orders and I do not propose to rehearse the substantial and substantive arguments that go to the legal question. This will be dealt with by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and quite properly so. We believe that the issues involved are weighty. It is now on the table that the government did try to make it more difficult for this house to amend this legislation. Senator Evans is shaking his head, but I believe that is quite clear. The question is whether, in the attempt to do so, the government has acted in contravention of the important constitutional provisions on this issue.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that this legislation, to the extent that it does impose taxation, shall deal with one subject only. I hope that the government will save a lot of this chamber's time and allow the process to proceed expeditiously by taking the proper action and splitting the bill. That is what the government should do. It is quite clear that the government itself is now considering amendments to the legislation. It will be a lot easier for all parties concerned if that process can be undertaken properly and without time-wasting arguments about whether the government did or did not act with constitutional propriety.

Having said that, the Australian Democrats do not propose to support the motion as it stands. It seems to us that paragraph (b), the one that asks the government to provide drafting instructions, is the offending one. Tabling the drafting instructions is not going to add very much to the substance of the debate either in this chamber or in the committee. It will add to the government's embarrassment, but I wonder whether this chamber should buy that embarrassment of the government at the expense of several hours of time-wasting debate. The Australian Democrats, therefore, believe that paragraph (b), which refers to the drafting instructions, should be excised from Senator Hill's motion.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats I call on the government to accede to the motion after it is amended. If paragraph (b) is removed, the material that remains and which the government will have to table is the opinions provided by the Solicitor-General, the Attorney-General's Department or the Office of Parliamentary Counsel concerning the drafting and validity of the taxation bill and the question relating to whether the kinds of provisions contained in the taxation bill, if enacted, may lawfully be combined in a single bill. I believe that the government is obliged to provide that information to the chamber and to the committee. If the Senate votes in favour of the amendment, the Australian Democrats will then vote in favour of the amended motion of Senator Hill's calling on the government to table those documents.

Our concerns were primarily with the drafting instructions and the precedent which that would set for future instances. Indeed, the minister has advised us that this is his prime concern; that his concern is not so much with what is contained in these materials apart from the drafting instructions. I venture to say that this is really not a great issue, apart from the embarrassment to the government, because the motivation of the government is very clearly on the table for all to see.
