So we would be wasting the Senate's time and the committee's time to press for this issue, which seems to give the government so much heartache. However, I cannot see how the government can legitimately refuse to table the opinions it has received on the validity and the drafting of this legislation. I move:
Paragraph (b), omit the paragraph.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about this very important question. The issues surrounding this debate are vital to the issue of certainty before the law. That is an issue crucial to the running of any democratic society. I believe that we need to be as fully informed as possible so as to come to a conclusion as to the validity of this measure that has been presented to the House of Representatives, namely, the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 because ultimately that in one form or another will come to this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, says in his speech that really there is not much difference—that whilst under the constitution we cannot amend a tax bill, we can make requests to the House of Representatives. He maintains that there is not much difference because the Senate can make life very difficult for the government if it chooses to dig its toes in. But the essential difference is this—and the minister knows it, of course: where we have a bill which has certain taxation benefits and which also imposes certain taxation burdens, and where we lump those into one measure, it then becomes extremely difficult for members of parliament to analyse those measures on their merits.

I am not necessarily talking about only the taxation burdens. Some people—and I have heard the Democrats talk about this publicly—may wish to reject certain of the income tax benefit measures that are in this legislation. So it is important for the review role of this chamber to have all of the information possible available to us in respect of this legal question.

I have had distributed an amendment which qualifies paragraph (b)—I would like Senator Spindler and Senator Chamarette to follow this part of the debate. I had this amendment drafted when I thought paragraph (b) was going to be part of this motion. I have listened carefully to what Senator Spindler says and, understanding the circumstances surrounding this chamber, I am inclined to support it. But in so doing, I do not suggest that that should be taken as a precedent. There will be the need on some occasion in respect of some bill for a return to order for the Office of Parliamentary Counsel to provide to the Senate for tabling documents relating to drafting instructions. That is very important in some areas—to enable us to get a better hold on the meanings behind legislation.

The Office of Parliamentary Counsel should be a servant of the parliament rather than a servant of the government. After all, it is not the office of government counsel, it is the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. I just make the point that I am not saying that on no other occasion will I refuse to support the tabling of drafting instructions. My draft amendment, which has been circulated, is predicated on the basis that (b) may still be in the motion. If Senator Spindler's amendment is supported then (b) will not be in the motion and there will be no need for my amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some real worries about the course of action that has been proposed. I will be interested to hear what the eminent opinion of Senator Alston is about this. If we now order this material to be tabled, we will be in a certain sense acting retrospectively. I will just explain what I mean by that. People have gone ahead and got this advice on a particular basis; that is, that it was going to be confidential advice.
—What! It couldn't stand the light of day; is that what you are saying?
—I will just take up that point: all of us in this chamber depend upon confidentiality. We all want to be put in a situation where we can go back to our rooms—
—In other words, it is open to public scrutiny.

—Senator Panizza might listen to this—we might want to talk to our staff, ring up people who might want to give us advice and discuss that fully and candidly. There is a public interest, as Senator Harradine says, in everybody knowing what goes on; there is a great public interest that everything should be revealed to the light of day. That is the proposition those opposite are putting. It is a fair proposition. But there is also a public interest in that we as members of this Senate and parliamentarians should be able to discuss fully and candidly anything we want to with people who advise us on the basis that the discussions will be kept confidential.

PARA.TAB: There are many areas where confidentiality is preserved. For example, a person does not want to see his lawyer subpoenaed to tell everyone what has been told to him. One does not want one's lawyer to tell the world at large what the public wants to know. Also in the confessional, and perhaps Senator Harradine would be interested in this, one would not want to confess one's sins and then have the priest reveal to the world at large what was said. All I am saying is that, although there is a great stake in the public knowing what goes on, there is also a great stake in members of the public having an ability in some circumstances to preserve their confidentiality.

If we pass this sort of motion, what is to stop the Senate saying, `Well, we want to know what Senator Herron told his patients last week. That is of interest to us. We will get the Senate to pass a motion to that effect'. We might want to know what Senator Alston has told some of his clients over the years. We could summons them to give evidence to the committee. I listened to Senator Panizza the other night speaking very graciously about his wife. What about the intimate exchanges between Senator Panizza and Mrs Panizza? Is Mrs Panizza going to be summonsed? Of course, it could be argued that we have the power to do all those sorts of things, but the interesting thing is whether we want to do it.

I will just finish up with a quote that all honourable senators might want to think about quite seriously. The quote is from what a very learned judge said in 1846. I think this quote is worth listening to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it Judge Jeffreys?
—No, it was Vice-Chancellor Sir Knight Bruce. Senator Alston will no doubt recognise the words as I read them. The Vice-Chancellor stated:

PARA.TAB: The discovery and vindication and establishment of truth are main purposes certainly of the existence of Courts of Justice; still, for the obtaining of those objects, which, however valuable and important, cannot be usefully pursued without moderation, cannot be either usefully or creditably pursued unfairly or gained by unfair means, not every channel is or ought to be open to them. The practical inefficacy of torture is not, I suppose, the most weighty objection to that mode of examination, nor probably would the purpose of the mere disclosure of truth have been otherwise than advanced by a refusal on the part of the Lord Chancellor in 1815 to act against the solicitor, who, in the cause between Lord Cholmondeley and Lord Clinton—

SPEECH.PARA: which Senator Alston would, of course, know about—
had acted or proposed to act in the manner which Lord Eldon thought it right to prohibit.
He goes on to say this, and I think it is a proper statement:
Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely—may be pursued too keenly—may cost too much.

He then says other things. I think that is right: this is a matter of balance. For those opposite to suddenly, after the government has had this conversation with various people in respect of whom it sought to obtain evidence, come in and say, `Look, we want that information' certainly breaches an understanding of confidentiality that was there. Unless we are very careful, it will set a precedent which will come back to bite not only the government but also us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate I wish to address firstly some remarks made by Senator Gareth Evans and then some remarks made by my good friend Senator Cooney. Senator Evans gave one of his rarer calm performances in this place. I do not know whether he is overtired or simply wishes to address this matter calmly. Nonetheless, I suppose we were grateful for that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans told the chamber that the information we are seeking and that we want to have provided will not help us. He says, `Trust me, I've seen all this material and you don't need it. You, the parliament, do not need it'. It does not surprise me that that kind of view would be put forward by a minister from this government. This is the executive that believes that question time is a grace and favour donation from it to parliament. Members of the executive do not seem to have ever read a book that would tell them that parliament's job is to keep a check on the executive.

There seems to be a complete blank in the minds of members of this executive. Of course, this is not the case with all the members of the backbench on the Labor side. But at least there has been a continual pattern on the part of members of this government of refusing to accept that parliament, whether it is this chamber or the House of Representatives, should have any real role in scrutinising the executive. They have put forward the view that parliament can see what the executive wants it to see and nothing else; in which case you, Mr Deputy President, I and everybody else in this place are wasting people's money. The school children in the gallery may as well go back to school if parliament does not properly have the job of keeping a check on the executive. The executive has to be forthcoming. It has to enable parliament to do its job by giving it the information that it needs. That is the debate we are having today.

This chamber is asking for some information. We will see whether the Greens and the Independent are prepared to join with us and agree with us that parliament, in order to do its job properly in this respect, does need this extra information. It is cold comfort to hear a member of the executive say, `Trust me, you don't need it'. Why would we bother with parliament if we just let executives say to everybody, `No worries, we're spending your money properly. You can go home, Senator Spindler. We can all go home'? This whole place could be set some other task if we wanted to trust the executive. Of course, the March election showed us that this is an executive we cannot trust.

This is an executive that no-one up in the gallery can trust; an executive that, through its party mechanism, went to the people and said that it was not going to increase tax; an executive that said a whole variety of things about my party's policies, and within days of being elected was planning to go back on promise after promise. So, if anything, the daily headlines in the newspapers, the daily discussions on talkback radio, the articles we read about budgets mark 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5—I do not know whether we are up to 6 yet, or whether we will even get a budget; perhaps we should all go away and come back in December and the government can have another go—all the negotiations towards that budget, show us that this is not a government we can trust. It has tried to cobble together some changes from what it promised during the election campaign, and it is having trouble putting a package of those changes together. That is my first point.

It is all very well for Senator Gareth Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the leader of the executive in the Senate, to come in here and say, `Trust me, you don't need it'. He is wrong to say that, on two counts. Firstly, it is up to us to decide what we need from the executive. It is up to members of the backbench to decide; they are part of parliament. So it is not his decision. Secondly, even if it were his decision and he said `Trust me', while he is a member of this executive which behaves in the fashion that it does—totally untrustworthy—I would not trust them. So I strike his remarks out on both of those grounds.

My colleague Senator Cooney is the chairman of the committee that will be dealing with this matter. I am deputy chairman of that committee and I say that we need this material. I note that Senator Cooney in his remarks, as best I understood them, was not prepared to say that the committee would not benefit from this material. He was not prepared to make that assumption, which does him credit.

SPEECH.PARA: But what he did say I have some disagreement with. He dragged out the old retrospectivity thing, which sends people rushing into corners saying, `We cannot do this; it is retrospective.'

PARA.TAB: This parliament passes retrospective legislation week after week, regularly, but no-one complains because it is retrospectively in favour of someone, so we do not worry. There is other retrospective legislation that we do not worry about for other reasons—for example, it might be in the national interest. Senator Cooney will well remember a recent case involving some Chinese guns that someone had imported. The executive said, `Oops, there is a mistake in this legislation'. It was passed 20 years ago, and this person who was importing the guns had imported them within the law. Normally we would say, `Retrospective legislation is a bad thing; this poor guy has followed the law and he will have a dramatic loss if we do not allow him to import these guns.'

That is the reason we do not like retrospective legislation. One should be able to do things according to what one thinks the law is. Senator Cooney is now saying, `You should be able to get advice and rely on it being confidential because that is what you agreed on at the time. You should not have to go back retrospectively and change it'. As he knows, this parliament went back and changed the law in that case because it was decided that it was in the national interest that these guns should not be imported and distributed.

Retrospectivity in itself is not something we never want; we might want it if it is in someone's favour; we might want it if it is in the national interest; and we certainly might want it if it is in the parliament's interest. In that respect, Senator Cooney and some other colleagues here might remember a pretty famous case when some person popped the question to the ABC at an estimates committee: `What is Geraldine Doogue's salary?'. What was the response from the ABC, which is funded by the taxpayer and therefore the taxpayer is entitled to know what the ABC does with its money? The ABC said, `We cannot tell you Geraldine Doogue's salary; the world will fall apart'. And what was the reason? Commercial-in-confidence. The ABC said, `We cannot go back on that now. You cannot make us go back and say to the people we did this deal with over Geraldine Doogue's salary that we are going to expose it publicly'.

The fallacy of the argument raised by the ABC was that every Tom, Dick and Harry, every government department that wanted to, could buy pencils with a contract of commercial-in-confidence, the defence forces could buy whatever they damned well liked and put `commercial-in-confidence' on it. What did we say? Do not be ridiculous. The overriding principle is that parliament has an interest in this matter and that overrides any past deal one might have made. Why do we say that? Because if parliament does not exert its right to review what the executive wants to do, we may as well all go home.

The executive will always kick and scream and wail and say that the world will fall down if it gives over some information to the parliament of the people. It will always try to protect itself, and every time it tries to protect itself in that way by saying that it is in confidence or it is retrospective—it will always drag up some reason—parliament has a job to say, `We do not care whether it is retrospective and we do not care whether it is in confidence. The overriding principle is that the parliament, this chamber and the other, is entitled to ask for what it wants from the executive'. There are some exceptions to that, but this is not one of them.

We are at a dramatic stage in Australia's political history. We have had a dramatic winding down of the economy under this government, but we are now in a situation where we have a government that many would say was elected on false pretences. It now wants to impose a range of taxes that a lot of Australians do not want, that a lot of Australians thought they were voting against. A lot of Australians voted for people down in the other chamber—properly called the lower house—thinking that their member was going to protect them from tax increases. Having been duped, they are at least entitled to see that both of these houses, and in particular this one, do their jobs in reviewing the executive. We cannot do that job unless the information is provided, and no amount of wailing, kicking and screaming and pretence of confidentiality and convention should stop anybody in this chamber supporting this chamber's right to get all the information at hand and judge for ourselves whether this information is helpful to us or not. That is what we should be doing today.

Last but not least, I come back to what Senator Gareth Evans said. This was his `Trust me, trust me' line: `I'm from the government that said we weren't going to put up taxes and now we want to'. I did not hear enunciated in his argument how the country was going to fall apart if this information was provided. There was no argument as to what the risk was to the nation or to the parliament. I understand quite clearly what the risk is to the executive: it might get caught out. Its lack of credibility will be shown bare faced to the world. So it has something to hide. What he should have done—and perhaps some other speaker would like to—was not just to tell us, `Trust me, trust me; we do not need this information', but to tell us what is the harm in letting parliament do its job. How will the country fall apart if those of us who are paid to do a job actually do it?

TALK.START.PARA: —While I actually agree with Senator Vanstone, I do not agree with all the logic she presented. I would like to begin from a different starting point. I agree with Senator Cooney's remarks regarding the retrospectivity issue. In some cases the nature of the relationship between client and service provider deserves the protection of confidentiality, and any moves to go against that should be done very carefully.

PARA.TAB: I also agree that there is some validity to the concerns that a precedent may be set, that the government does not wish to continue with that on all occasions. Particulars may be requested as a way of gaining information, not necessarily for valid purposes but for other reasons. It is natural that the government has concerns regarding these two points of retrospectivity and precedent, and I think those concerns are valid and legitimate.

I also think it is natural that the government has a concern that the use of this particular request may be for political point scoring. It would be a great shame if this debate fell into using the information gained or the desire to have that information before the parliament as a way of political point scoring. However, I do not think it will be used in that way. I do not believe that is a legitimate or valid use of either the information that is gained or the request.

I believe that the higher principle of openness to scrutiny and the opportunity to facilitate consideration of the matters that are being referred to a committee come in at this point. Several concessions have been made to the concerns that have been expressed by the government regarding its unwillingness to present all the papers. I believe Senator Spindler's amendment is a very sensible move towards that, as was Senator Harradine's amendment, but I understand Senator Harradine has withdrawn his and therefore I support the amendment put forward by Senator Spindler. In the light of the fact that there have been these concessions made to the government's concerns, I think the principle that this is operating under openness to scrutiny, a willingness to facilitate the matters that will be raised in the committee considering the constitutionality of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, is the one we should be looking at at the moment.

I believe that this does not set a precedent. I think we should weigh up very seriously each time the matters of retrospectivity and the other matters that underlie requests. I believe the merits of each case should be looked at. In this particular case, I feel it is worthy as a request and it is only for that reason that I support it. I urge the government to cooperate with the request as a way of demonstrating its cooperation with the reference to the committee so that the matter can be dealt with expeditiously and fairly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans has today been very comprehensively exposed by the Australian Democrats and they really ought to be commended for appreciating the double standard that the government would otherwise seek to impose on this chamber. If the government were consistent, it would not have provided Dennis Rose's opinion at all. It would simply have said, `We take the view that you can test it in due course. You can go off to the High Court if you want to; you can explore it through the Senate committee. Do your best because as far as we are concerned we are above all that'.

PARA.TAB: Instead, it very selectively provided an opinion which is hedged with qualifications and which does not bear a proper date in order to be able to determine when these opinions were formed—and it is critical to know whether they were before or after the event. What we are left with is transparently a damage control exercise. The opposition having tabled very detailed and closely argued opinions from a leading Queensland silk and Professor Colin Howard, whose credentials I would have thought even Senator Evans would concede are impeccable—certainly he thought so 20-odd years ago—the government has been forced—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not think they were so good 20 years ago.

—No, we did not accept his view then. What we have seen is the government forced to respond because otherwise an overwhelmingly one-sided case would be presented and, very selectively, the government trots out an opinion which is heavily qualified. But once it does that, it really does not have a leg to stand on in explaining why it is that it then does not go further and provide other opinions from the Solicitor-General, the Attorney-General's Department or, indeed, other and earlier opinions of the Chief General Counsel. That is what I think Senator Spindler is getting at—that it is proper and appropriate for the parliament to be able to take account of all of the formal opinions that have been tendered on this very important matter.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we still maintain that drafting instructions are highly relevant, I must say of the extraordinary concession and admission made today by Senator Evans that I hesitate to say that he knows not what he has done. If ever there was an admission that the government's very intention was to do what the constitution patently says should not be done—that is, to lump together a series of taxation bills so that it is very hard to unravel them, to pick out the goodies and leave the nasties—we have had this damning admission today from Senator Evans that that is precisely what the government had in mind.

Senator Evans said that the government had brought them together for policy purposes—meaning political purposes—to demonstrate their interconnectedness. That is precisely what tacking is all about. This is clearly a very tacky exercise on the part of the government. In those circumstances, I think we probably would not learn much more from the drafting instructions because we have had them tabled orally in the Senate today.

Against that background, I think we would simply say that the position adopted by the Democrats is one that is satisfactory in all the circumstances. It will enable a lot more light to be thrown on not only the true motivation but also the real constitutional legality of these very important measures. We will be supporting the Democrats accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue being debated is really the constitutional legality of the budget package as presented by this Labor government. I rise with some diffidence in arguing with Senator Gareth Evans on the constitutional issues of the government's handling of its budget and associated bills because I have had a long association with him in this place on such matters and he is somewhat of an authority.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I have some feeling of the predicament he now finds himself in. Like Mr Crean and Mr Willis, Senator Evans was obviously not present when the strategy of the lumping together of the various benefit and taxing bills was decided upon. In that circumstance, he now finds he has to defend the indefensible.

The government obtained an opinion from Dennis Rose but, as my colleague Senator Alston says, that opinion is filled with qualifications. Throughout we see, `I shall assume for present purposes' and again at paragraph 24, `I shall assume that the approach in Air Caledonie'. The issue I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate is that very often when the Tax Office finds itself in a difficult predicament in relation to a legislative interpretation or a decision handed down by the court, it comes back and says, `The circumstances are not identical to those of most other taxpayers' and for that reason the Tax Commissioner will not necessarily accept the precedent.

In relation to the citation of the Air Caledonie International case of the High Court, I remind the Senate that it was essentially about the collection of a fee by an airline operating in-flight. That was concerned with so-called section 34A of the Migration Act 1958 which purported to exact, so far as it related to passengers who were Australian citizens, a tax. That section was a law imposing taxation under section 55 of the constitution. The point at issue was essentially a Migration Act matter in relation to the application of a regulation so far as section 34A of that act was concerned. In coming back to the relevance and the qualifications of the advice of the Chief General Counsel, I would like to quote paragraph 22 of it. Mr Rose says:

SPEECH.PARA: (The result is, with respect, somewhat curious since it is contrary to the wording of the first paragraph of section 55 which requires that, if an Act contains such a combination, it is the provisions other than those "imposing" or "dealing with the imposition of" taxation that "shall be of no effect".
It goes on:
The decision also seems curious in view of the fact that the acknowledged purpose of section 55 is to protect the Senate . . .

Again, when talking about other relevant cases, such as the Australian Tape Manufacturers case, he talks about the `possible alternative approach'. So throughout, this opinion is subject to qualification and assumption and I would like to submit to the Senate that, as such, Mr Rose was given the very difficult job of protecting the government from the embarrassing predicament that it has got into. I think a very careful reading of that opinion will testify to that effect.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I think it is necessary that we get the underlying documents—the instructions that were given to the drafting officers and requested by my colleague Senator Hill—to enable this committee to have the fullest possible information available to make sure, as I said earlier, that the legislation prima facie is constitutionally valid before we proceed to consider it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to this motion. When we started this debate, there were no amendments circulating. We have now had two amendments circulated and one withdrawn, and we have Senator Spindler's amendment which is to delete paragraph (b) of Senator Hill's motion. The argument put by Senator Spindler and supported by Senator Chamarette—and, now, by the opposition—is that this should remove the government's biggest concern about the confidentiality of drafting, in which area the government has every right to maintain its confidentiality.

PARA.TAB: The point I make relates to paragraph (a), which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any opinions provided by the Solicitor-General, the Attorney-General's Department or the Office of Parliamentary Counsel concerning either:
(i) the drafting and validity of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993; or

PARA.TAB: (ii)the question whether the kinds of provisions which are contained in the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, if enacted, may lawfully be combined in a single bill. . .

SPEECH.PARA: My view on that—and I think it is a very reasonable proposition to put—is that if the Solicitor-General, the Attorney-General's Department and the Office of Parliamentary Counsel are doing their job properly, as one would want good public servants to do, one would expect them to provide a range of advice and options. That is what good public policy should be about, what good public servants and a public service is about. If they believe that in future they may have that advice retrospectively tabled in parliament, they will therefore feel constrained about the advice they provide as good officers of the Public Service. One would require them to provide that advice. Ministers will be very cautious about what they ask their public servants to provide to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has always been a problem with freedom of information anyway.

—It may turn out that information which the public servants thought was confidential could be tabled in parliament. This is germane to the development of public policy. Those opposite are establishing a precedent and issuing a warning to public servants. That warning is, `Be careful what you say to your minister, the advice you give in confidence, because it could be tabled in parliament. If the parliament does not like that advice or queries it, you can be brought before the bar of the Senate and questioned about it'. That is a possibility.

PARA.TAB: When we started this debate after the suspension of standing orders, either the motion would have been carried in its entirety or it would have been defeated. I think the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine quickly floated amendments in an attempt to see whether a compromise was possible between the government and the opposition. I suppose if one is the third, fourth and fifth force in the Senate as a minority party, one's role may be to see whether such a compromise or consensus is possible.

But the fundamental issue is still there before us. The issue is how are we to conduct decent public policy as ministers and as a government when we want communications between ministers and public servants to be ridgy-didge about the range of information available. How can we do that when we know full well there now is a precedent by which public servants can end up before the bar of the Senate or before a committee and be subject to severe penalties?

I know people believe that the Solicitor-General has a particular role and that that advice should be generally available. But when we refer to the Attorney-General's Department, we are talking about a department which is administered by a minister. That minister takes responsibility for that department and for the good, the bad and the ugly that department puts up. I think that those opposite are putting pressure on public servants about the way in which they carry out their functions and duties as public servants who are responsible to a minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might not have provided the advice.

—The point is that they may not have done so. But the precedent that is being established by those opposite is a warning to a public servant at any level in the Attorney-General's Department that if one puts a note at the side of a document, it can now be tabled in the parliament as the result of some opinion. A public servant sees as part of his or her public function within the Public Service Act the provision of advice. I think that we as ministers want public servants to provide us with a range of advice and the arguments for and against.

PARA.TAB: When talking about parliamentary responsibility, let us remember that, in this chamber and the lower house, the person who has to take the heat is the minister. That is what one gets elected to do, and that is what elections every three years are about. In the end, the minister must stand and be judged according to his or her comments and arguments. In the end, it will be the public who will decide whether they agree with the minister by electing him or not at the next election. That is the fundamental issue of sovereignty of the parliament. Ministers have to take responsibility for what is given to them, how they portray it and how they use it in the public policy debate. I think that has been lost sight of in this motion. I think that is a warning the parliament ought to be aware of.

I can think of other examples. For example, let us envisage that at some stage in the future the government had an absolute majority in the Senate. Let us assume that an individual senator went and sought advice from the Clerk of the Senate about amendments he or she may choose to move in the chamber itself. What would happen if a government used its numbers, whoever the government may be, to have that confidential information from the clerk to that individual senator tabled for debate in the Senate? I think that would be an outrage. But it is advice that a member of parliament, a member of the Senate, is using in this forum as part of argument. That is the area which those opposite are opening up to precedent.

That may be an exaggerated example, but I would ask those opposite to be very careful about affecting the confidential relationship between any senator and the advice that they get. I favour the senator, whether they be a minister or a backbencher, standing and arguing his or her case and being judged accordingly in this chamber. The public will make up its mind. I think that if we seek to put pressure on public servants, we will affect the level of advice. I have no doubt that if this becomes a trend in the future, ministers and senior public servants will make sure that they do not have advice in writing but get it verbally. That may well affect good government.

So although the minor parties here have tried to put an amendment as a compromise, I still think it does not address the fundamental issue about the confidentiality of policy making and the right of public servants to provide open and decent information to their minister, without their fearing that at a later stage it will be tabled in this place.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's), as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NUCLEAR SAFEGUARDS (PRODUCERS OF URANIUM ORE CONCENTRATES) CHARGE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill and the associated Bill is to impose a charge on commercial uranium producers in Australia to recover some of the costs of the Australian Safeguards Office (ASO) in undertaking nuclear safeguards and physical protection activities.
The Government's decision to consider cost recovery for these activities was included in the 1992-93 Budget papers.

Mr President, this cost recovery proposal rests on two fundamental principles. First, those who derive benefit from an activity should pay for it, so long as the amount recovered is reasonable having regard to the nature and costs of the activity.

Second, those who pay should have a genuine opportunity to examine and be consulted on the necessity, quality and cost of the activities they are paying for. This is required not only on equity grounds, but also because it imposes a discipline (in addition to that of normal parliamentary scrutiny) on the provider of the activities—in this case the ASO—to deliver them as effectively and efficiently as possible.

The ASO cost recovery arrangements to which the Bills would give effect, will be fully consistent with these principles. In particular, the Government accepts that a substantial proportion of the activities of the ASO provides benefits to Government and to the Australian community generally. The costs of ASO activities not specifically directed at or relevant to industry will continue to be met by the Government, which will remain the largest contributor to ASO resources.
Other countries charge their industries for nuclear safeguards and related activities, including the United States, Canada and Sweden.

Moreover, cost recovery for undertaking regulatory and other activities, based on the same general principles I have outlined, applies quite widely across Australian industry. In the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio, Mr President, it currently applies to activities undertaken by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, as well as to many of the projects of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, the Australian Geological Survey Organisation and the Bureau of Resource Sciences. Activities of the National Residue Survey and the registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals are also subject to cost recovery arrangements.

Before commenting on this particular Bill I will say a little about the ASO and its activities. Established by the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987, the Director of Safeguards and the ASO manage domestic and international nuclear safeguards and physical protection programs in accordance with our stringent nuclear safeguards policies and requirements.
ASO has a key role in ensuring that uranium produced in and exported from Australia is used only for peaceful purposes and is not diverted into non-peaceful programs.

In short, a significant proportion of ASO's program exists, and the associated costs are incurred, because of the need to safeguard our uranium industry. These are the costs the Government has decided to recover. I shall return to this point when commenting on the associated Bill.

This first Bill provides in its substantive clause (Clause 3) for a charge to be imposed on the companies which produce and export uranium in commercial quantities. Both Bills commence on 1 November 1993.

In recognition that it is reasonable for a producer to have generated a cash flow before being liable for the charge, we have provided that no charge is payable until some uranium has been exported from the relevant processing facility.

Mr President, the uranium industry has been going through a difficult period in recent years. Prices have been low and, at the Ranger plant in the Northern Territory, production has fallen and some workers have been retrenched. Happily, prices have increased quite significantly in the last few months. Although the industry is by no means fully recovered at this stage, I am pleased to note recent comments by senior officials of Ranger's parent company, Energy Resources of Australia, that the market has strengthened recently, utilities are showing an interest in talking about future demand, and ERA has a number of new contracts under negotiation.

I also note that Western Mining Corporation intends to increase uranium production from its Olympic Dam mine at Roxby Downs in South Australia as part of a mine production expansion program in the near future.

Our decision to charge the companies for nuclear safeguards has not been made without regard to industry conditions. We estimate that the two current uranium producers, both of which have remained profitable despite the industry problems, will each pay only about $340,000 annually at the present level of ASO activity, representing about 20 cents per kilogram of uranium produced. This is less than one half of one percent of the present value of uranium production.

All in all, the Government believes these cost recovery measures—fully justifiable in terms of the principles I have outlined—are not unreasonable as regards the impact on the uranium industry. Furthermore, the arrangements for determining the annual charge payable by the companies, which I shall describe shortly in discussing the associated Bill, will give them a genuine opportunity to influence through consultation the actual amount they would pay each year.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum for it and the associated Bill.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Cooney)—by leave—agreed to:

That the time for the presentation of the report on part 1(a) of the terms of reference of the Select Committee on Matters Arising from the Pay Television Tendering Processes be extended to 7 September 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report on or before the last day of sitting in March 1994:

The operations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), the Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS) and any other body, company or corporation which receives funding from ATSIC, with particular regard to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the accountability of ATSIC, ALS and ATSIC-funded bodies and individuals for the way in which they receive, spend and publicly account for taxpayers' money with particular reference to project grant money;

(b)whether there is an effective working relationship between the Department of Social Security and ATSIC and endeavour to identify the factors which have made some community development and employment projects (CDEP) successful whilst others have failed and the reasons for this;

(c)whether it is appropriate for ATSIC to continue funding all of its current programs, with particular reference to the CDEP, or whether greater levels of accountability could be obtained if responsibility for that program were transferred to the Department of Social Security;

(d)whether there are sufficient guidelines, controls, checks and acquittal procedures applied to ATSIC, ALS and other ATSIC-funded bodies to ensure that taxpayers' funds are fairly and properly applied for the purposes intended under the ATSIC Act, especially concerning the levels of spending approval authority and effective use of capital item expenditure;

(e)whether there are sufficient guidelines and procedures in place to control satisfactorily the expenditure of taxpayers' funds on travel and accommodation by ATSIC commissioners, councillors and staff, and by members or employees of any ATSIC-funded body; and

(f)whether ATSIC should continue to hold discretionary power to disregard non-compliance with conditions applying to grant money which it has distributed, or whether the ATSIC Act should be amended to require the refund of such money where grant conditions are not met.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to explain the reasons why I put this motion before the Senate. I point out to the Senate that this referral to a committee is simply and purely for accountability purposes. I am not looking at a wholesale inquiry into how much this parliament or this government should spend on ATSIC. At this stage I am not interested in whether they are spending too much or too little. I simply want accountability to make sure that the $1.3 billion or thereabouts that is spent gets to exactly where it does the best on the ground; that is, for the welfare of Aborigines. I stress to everyone—Senator Coates, the chairman of the committee, Senator Harradine, the Greens and the Democrats—that I am interested in accountability and nothing else.

PARA.TAB: This first came to my mind some time back. I have been asking questions at estimates about the actions and accountability of ATSIC for about five years and I am afraid that I have not been getting any answers. For the third year in a row, the Auditor-General—in volume 3 of Audit report No. 1, relating to the 1993-94 budget—raised significant concerns over non-compliance by ATSIC with the basic standards of accountability demanded of all other government departments and instrumentalities. The Auditor-General said that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's annual report was tabled in parliament on 5 May 1993—that is, the 1991-92 financial statement. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The audits . . . were qualified because of inadequate control over Community Development Employment Projects' participant schedules and resulting payments of $207m during the year.
On the community development employment projects, the Auditor-General said:
Consistent with the audit reports on the financial statements of the Commission for the periods ended 30 June 1990 and 30 June 1991, the audit for the period ended 30 June 1992 again—
I stress, again—

disclosed inadequate control over CDEP participant schedules and resulting payments. In particular, the audit revealed numerous instances where communities had not forwarded participant schedules to the Commission, lack of evidence of checking of participant schedules and numerous instances where payments were not based on participant schedules.
That is what the Auditor-General said. He had a lot more to say which I cannot go through in the short time that I have at my disposal at present.

PARA.TAB: In his latest report, on which the ink is hardly dry, the Auditor-General identifies a need for ATSIC to write off at least $4 million in loans to trading bodies because the outstanding money cannot be recovered; significant control breakdowns in the management of salary payments; and serious problems with community development projects, including lack of evidence of checking of participation schedules. I could go on and on about what the Auditor-General said.

This is the very latest of the Auditor-General's concerns—for three years he has been reporting to this parliament his concerns about the use of public funds. But other very serious concerns have been raised by Aboriginal communities that support the thrust of my motion. When I first gave notice of this motion, I did so on the basis of the Auditor-General's report. Since then, my office staff and I have been approached, and I have read newspaper articles about people and organisations within ATSIC that want this inquiry.

These matters should be referred to a Senate standing committee for examination now. It is no good being told by the government, the minister and others to go back to estimates committees. It has been running that line for five years and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you spoken to the chairperson of ATSIC about your concerns?
—No, I have not spoken to that person.
—You have no idea.
—Wait a minute—I will get to it in good time. These serious allegations and concerns have been raised and we should be looking at them.

PARA.TAB: Account must also be taken of the published report on page 2 of the Australian of the last few days, in which the chairwoman of ATSIC, Ms Lois O'Donoghue—who was just referred to by Senator Collins—is reported as having:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . called for the introduction of "accountability provisions" to ensure federal government funds were properly used.
I have the article and the minister has a copy of it in front of him. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: ATSIC urges tighter control of funds
By FIONA KENNEDY

PARA.TAB: The chairwoman of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, Ms Lois O'Donoghue, called last night for tighter controls over State and Territory use of funding for Aboriginal communities.
Ms O'Donoghue called for the introduction of "accountability provisions" to ensure federal government funds were properly used.
"State and Territory governments must be further encouraged to fulfil their service obligations to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens," she said.
"We believe that this can occur through providing to ATSIC greater leverage, including financial leverage in federal-State arrangements, particularly where specific-purpose assistance is provided.
She said such changes were now being discussed regarding the federal-State housing agreement and its Aboriginal residential housing program.

Greater accountability should be part of an overhaul of the funding system, which should facilitate proper assessment of Aboriginal community requirements, Ms O'Donoghue said in an opening address to a conference, Aboriginal Peoples, Federalism and Self-Determination.

"The processes by which the States receive general revenue grant assistance need to be overhauled to enable a proper assessment of needs, particularly essential service and infrastructure needs, in Aboriginal communities," she told the conference in Townsville, north Queensland.

"There must be a more targeted, needs-based assessment process and, above all, accountability provisions so resources provided on the basis of assessed need are directed effectively and appropriately to meeting that need.

In her address to the three-day conference Ms O'Donoghue also encouraged a push for self-government in the Torres Strait, but rejected moves for Aboriginal sovereignty, arguing instead that indigenous Australians could achieve self-determination in the federal system.

She said ATSIC had "acknowledged the case" of Torres Strait Islanders to form a separate authority within ATSIC, adding that the authority's formation would be "a significant step forward in the development of Torres Strait autonomy".
The proposal for an authority was made by the Island Co-ordinating Council, the peak body for Islander councils in the Torres Strait.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.
—You are not going to incorporate every single article?

—I would like Senator Collins to speak to the matter a little later. I agree 100 per cent with what Lois O'Donoghue had to say. I did not get around to speaking to her on the phone—I probably would not be able to get hold of her—but she has made her feelings public. I agree with her 100 per cent in light of the fact that what she said lines up exactly with the concerns that have been expressed about ATSIC by the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: I must also say that we in this chamber cannot expect the government to take any action whatsoever to help create the greater level of accountability for public funds by ATSIC that the Auditor-General would like to see. I would like to point out that, having reported his concerns to the parliament, the Auditor-General has done everything expected of him. It is now up to this parliament to take note of his comments on ATSIC's use of public money and to act accordingly. For three years, ATSIC found plenty of ways out of being held accountable because of the particular form of words in the act. Amendments to the ATSIC act, as proposed by the government, are a totally inadequate response to the concern raised by the Auditor-General.

Some time back I asked various questions on notice regarding the report of the Auditor-General. Unfortunately, the reply from the minister and ATSIC was inadequate. My questions sought from the minister details of how much money was involved in ATSIC's decision not to recover funds, even though it was authorised to do so when grant conditions were not met. ATSIC's answer was that it did not keep consolidated records of all breaches. The commission then sought to trivialise the matter by referring to late progress reports. My time is somewhat limited today, so I will not go through this point by point.

People have written to me or have rung my office to support me in this situation. Don McLeod has probably done more than anyone else since the 1950s to organise better conditions for Aborigines on stations and in other places in Western Australia. Incidentally, he is a person whom I have been criticising vastly for the last five years. But he came out in support of me on this issue. I will quote his letter, which starts:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator,
You are quite right in criticising the ATSIC and the way they handle their funds.
He then goes on to give his reasons for making this statement. He calls for doing away with ATSIC altogether, but I certainly do not agree that we should go that far. His was uncalled for support.

PARA.TAB: A letter from the Indigenous Elders Council of Manunda in Queensland says that I am 100 per cent correct in proposing this referral. It has held the same concerns in the past and it fully agrees on the need for precisely the kind of inquiry that I want to establish. The council fully agrees with what I have said.
A solicitor from the Aboriginal Legal Service from a state other than Western Australia rang me and told me what he thought of the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It definitely wasn't Senator Macdonald.

—No. He does not work for ALS, anyhow. This man is from another state. He told me to push hard for an inquiry into ATSIC because of what he has observed within the organisation. He listed inefficiency, misdirection, bad management, the application of payback principles to anyone who rocks the boat, a failure to answer correspondence and a failure to return phone calls.

PARA.TAB: I am also urged by leaders of the Gubrun Aboriginal community from near Kalgoorlie to proceed with this motion because they want an inquiry into ATSIC which would see them, as members of a minority tribal group, getting fair play. I know very well the people from the Gubrun tribe who have contacted me. They are very decent people who are not trying to create mischief. They just want justice for their own people.

I have been urged by journalists in Perth to do something. Senator Collins rolls his eyes when I say that. I remind him that some journalists are authentic. They try to make sure that there is accountability in the use of public money. I do not write off everything they say; I do take notice of some of them. These journalists have investigated and published details of doubtful projects undertaken in the name of Aborigines. One case reported by channel 10 in Perth showed that, of the more than $1 million that was allocated to building something like four prefabricated houses, half was siphoned off to so-called consultants.

These so-called consultants would not have been Aborigines. They would have been part of that white industry that exists simply to siphon money off Aborigines so that it does not get to the right place. I am urged by a journalist from a state other than Western Australia to push for a full inquiry into ATSIC. The journalist detailed instances of ATSIC employees ensuring that when contracts are let they go exclusively to friends.

I do not think these ATSIC employees were black people; they would have been white people. So these contracts went exclusively to friends within ATSIC. This journalist used the word `corruption' to describe the nature of the kind of offence which is now being investigated with the view to an expose being published.

I received on Friday information that one ATSIC officer paid more than $1,000 out of ATSIC funds for artworks. There was no receipt to account for the sum drawn to pay for the artwork purchased. The Auditor-General has tracked and reported on this kind of basic breach of accountability. It is not Aborigines who are committing the offences; it is people from the white industry that is built around the Aborigines to siphon money off.

I am also urged by a correspondent to specifically investigate the waste of ALS, the Aboriginal Legal Service, money. I have a letter which indicates that there was a waste of funds on a barrister who was in court for six hours a day for four days to represent a client whose case is yet to be heard. The cost of a barrister for four days of non-productive time is a waste. I will leave it to someone in the legal fraternity to cost out what that fee would be.

I have a letter to back that up. I would seek leave to incorporate this letter in Hansard, but I will not because I do not want to disclose the name of a woman who was bashed in Queanbeyan. She took action against her husband. She won the action and then the husband appealed. That is why that QC is sitting around for six hours a day for four days. That is a total of 24 hours and that is then multiplied by whatever a QC charges. If it were not for the fact that I would be disclosing the name of the woman, I would ask to have that letter tabled. I raised my deepest concerns and those of the Auditor-General about the operation and accountability of ATSIC in the Senate on 26 May 1993 before I moved this motion.

On 17 May 1993, the West Australian claimed that caretakers on Pilbara pastoral leases confirmed that they were not manned by any of the Aborigines drawing CDEP moneys for community development, infrastructure and health. It mentioned the release of $1.7 million for 1991-92, and yet these people had not been in possession of the place. State Electricity Commission employees go out to maintain the power plant on an abandoned station, even though that power plant has not been run to produce lights for Aborigines for two years. Someone is siphoning off money; again, it is not the Aborigines who are doing that—the white community is hauling money out of it.

The ATSIC act says that the commission may require payment of money not accounted for, but this wording leaves a huge discretionary power for non-accountable decisions involving grant money drawn directly from taxpayer funds. ATSIC admitted in an article in the West Australian on 18 May that it was finally and belatedly cutting off funds to the Strelley pastoral group and, of course, the Strelley group is tied up with Don McLeod, who I have mentioned. I have been criticising him for five years, but he has sent me a letter of support. How much more evidence does the Senate want that we need an inquiry into the accountability of ATSIC?

A newspaper article in the Canberra Times on 27 May points out that it is the Auditor-General's view that ATSIC may well be funding projects that are more properly the responsibility of other levels of government. An inquiry into the guidelines could stop this unnecessary duplication. An ATSIC officer was sacked for offering $100,000 to an unnamed Aboriginal organisation—this is an example of the lack of administrative control and accountability.

The front page of the Sunday Times in Perth on 8 August 1993 carried more allegations, that will probably remain unrefuted, like those dealing with the Pilbara leases. It is looking at `phantom' camps for Aborigines in the Kimberley region to which ATSIC has, according to newspapers, handed out millions of dollars.

I have to inform the Senate that, despite a large number of telephone calls to my office since I gave notice of my intention to move this motion, there has not been one single person saying that I should not proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had a chance yet.

—No person has said that ATSIC is okay, except the minister, who has obviously taken this as a joke. We are dealing with $1.3 billion coming out of the public purse, but the minister is obviously laughing at it. Not one person said that I should not have an inquiry. There was not one person saying that there should not be an inquiry into ALS. There have been demands for an inquiry into the ALS in Western Australia for years.

PARA.TAB: Those who have telephoned me include Aborigines, the ATSIC lawyer, journalists, who have been very helpful, and many others. I have said before, but I will repeat, that I am seeking only to ensure that proper standards of accountability are maintained. This parliament demands high standards of every other department but obviously not this one.

There are a few late movements on this matter. The latest point to come out was that New South Wales Aboriginal magistrate Pat O'Shane summed up what the traditional tribal elders and many others have been saying, and that is that ATSIC needs to be accountable. I have an article on that entitled `ATSIC an abysmal failure: O'Shane'. I seek leave to have this article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: "THE AUSTRALIAN" AUGUST 26, 1993—P5
ATSIC an abysmal failure: O'Shane
By Richard Jinman

The Federal Government's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission was an "abysmal" failure that had done nothing to improve the deteriorating health and conditions of Aboriginal people, NSW magistrate Ms Pat O'Shane said yesterday.

Ms O'Shane told an Evatt Foundation conference in Sydney that judged by its own performance indicators—outlined in its Operational Plan, 1992-96, as birth and death statistics, morbidity rates, hospitalisation rates, immunisation rates and infant mortality rates—ATSIC was a failure.

Quoting recent National Health and Medical Research Council statistics that show Aboriginal death rates four to five times higher than the national average and maternal death rates three to five times higher, Ms O'Shane said it was time ATSIC and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, were called to account.
"On every social indicator the position of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders has deteriorated over the past decade in the lifetime of ATSIC," Ms O'Shane said.

"It is exceedingly difficult to ascertain what ATSIC's budget is, but it is estimated at more than $1 billion a year. That Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders should suffer deteriorating socio-economic conditions against that background is scandalous.
ATSIC's chairwoman, Ms Lois O'Donoghue, declined to comment on Ms O'Shane's speech yesterday, but Mr Tickner said her views were "unrepresentative" and "bitter and twisted".

The Keating Government had delivered an unprecedented increase in resources to ATSIC in the wake of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the recent federal Budget, Mr Tickner said.

"Ms O'Shane's lofty pontification on these matters in her capacity as a magistrate is a sleight on the thousands of Aboriginal people working hard in their local community to tackle issues of disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal people," he said.
But Ms O'Shane said ATSIC policy documents made no mention of "the massive social injustices and continuing deprivation" of Aboriginal people and were couched in the language of economic rationalism.
The "overwhelming majority" of ATSIC's corporate plan was devoted to structural matters and bureaucratic procedures which were meaningless to most Aboriginal people, she said.

"All the talk and glossy documents in the world, with their meaningless economic jargon will not stop our mothers and babies dying or put roofs over our heads, or give our young people jobs and food," Ms O'Shane said.
"We have had enough of words, words and words, we want action.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no better person in the land to demand accountability than Pat O'Shane. The tribal elders who have written to me and telephoned my office say that corruption appears all the time.

PARA.TAB: I think, in the very short period I have had to address this motion, that I have given the Senate enough reasons for everyone in this Senate to agree that there needs to be an inquiry. I decided, with advice, that it should go to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration because that committee has already been set up by this parliament and it has very good and capable senators on it. I suggested that rather than a royal commission, which can run everywhere and only make money for the QCs. It is better to have an existing committee examine the matter rather than set up a Senate select committee that the government has to find more money to fund. That could run anywhere. I thought that this matter could go to the standing committee chaired by Senator Coates.

I very quickly came to the decision to refer it to a committee not a royal commission. I am looking for support for this matter. I have support on my side of politics. I am looking for support from Senator Harradine, the Greens and the Democrats. I hope it will be delivered.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collins) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. At the ACTU congress yesterday the Prime Minister told that dedicated band of true believers to keep the faith. Can the minister explain how Mr Keating could possibly ask those in the Labor movement, or anyone else in Australia for that matter, to keep the faith when Treasury's PRISMOD analysis shows that, as a result of the latest Kernot-Dawkins proposals, the groups worse off, on average, would be some sole parents, pensioners and low income couples, while the lion's share of the benefits will go to households with incomes in the top 20 per cent?

—The PRISMOD analysis shows, in my understanding of it, that the overwhelming result of the budget package as it has now emerged is to leave the vast majority of Australian households, on average, considerably better off. In terms of the impact on particular households, the change in average real household disposable income ranges between a decrease of 0.05 per cent up to an increase of 1.6 per cent for the lowest quintile of unemployment benefit and sickness benefit households. That is the distribution we are talking about. The decrease, to the extent that it is there, for some households, for some income categories, is 0.05 per cent. The increases, by contrast, are very much larger.

PARA.TAB: The situation more generally is that 90 per cent of full time wage and salary earner household types are better off. The average outcomes here range between a small loss of less than 0.2 per cent of household real disposable income to gains of over one per cent in real household disposable income. While the actual dollar gains and losses for individual households within each cell will vary, the averages again range between a loss of under 65c a week to a gain of around $20 a week. That is the balance, the distribution, of the impact of this budget. There are particular distributional cells within the total picture that, at the extreme margin, are slightly worse off, but the orders of magnitude here are measurable in cents rather than dollars and they certainly do not lead, as I understand it, to the conclusion that Senator Alston seeks to draw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If these proposals are so good, why were they not included in the budget in the first place; what possible justification is there for pretending in that seriously flawed PRISMOD analysis that all Australians use unleaded petrol; and is it not a fact that even this totally recast budget is still a viciously regressive document?

—The point of this particular budget, as has been made clear over and over again by Treasurer Dawkins, is that the overall benefits that we must deliver to the Australian community are sustained economic growth in a low inflation, low interest rate environment plus, of course, a continuing environment of micro-economic reform and industry reform and a continuing environment of assistance to exporters. It is by doing that that we will generate the job growth in this country that will redound to the benefit of the overwhelming majority of Australians. That is why the budget was constructed as it is.

PARA.TAB: Overwhelmingly, the budget's focus is on medium term fiscal responsibility, and that is in spectacular contrast to the medium term and short term and longer term fiscal irresponsibility of the opposition which would accumulate deficits of $1,400 million this year and $3,000 million by 1996-97, without any redeeming attempt that it told us about to make up for that through other forms of revenue or outlay arrangements. It is a total exercise of irresponsibility by the opposition and it is not something that lends any credibility to what the opposition is up to.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to my Western Australian colleague Senator Peter Cook, the Minister for Trade. I draw the minister's attention to the trade figures in the July balance of payments statistics released on Monday which show an improvement in Australia's export performance for that month. Do these figures confirm the continuing growth trend in exports? Do they vindicate the government's policy of broadening our export base into more elaborately transformed manufactures and services?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for his continuing interest in issues related to trade. A moment ago Senator Gareth Evans said that one of the features of the budget was to provide assistance to exporters. That is true; it is a key facet of the budget and one that we will hear much more about in the next few weeks. It is the government's intention to further strengthen and give support to Australian exporters, encourage others who do not export now to get into the export business, and help the economy grow by hooking onto the massive demand for goods and services in the near north of Australia in the Asia-Pacific region.

PARA.TAB: The balance of payments figures that came out on Monday confirm an underlying trend in the Australian economy. They are good figures from an export point of view. They show that the export performance of this country continues to improve. Seasonally adjusted for July, our overall exports for that month rose by seven per cent and our imports rose by one per cent, exports thus vastly outstripping imports.

If one looks at particular categories, one will see that exports of transport equipment for the month of July increased by 33 per cent and that exports of manufactured goods increased by 9 per cent. As I said, these figures confirm the trend in export growth for the year 1992-93. Exports of machinery increased by 25 per cent compared with the previous year; exports of transport equipment went up 22 per cent compared with the previous year; and exports of manufactured goods went up 14 per cent in 1992-93 compared with 1991-92.

The trend in balance of payments returns for the last four months are interesting. They show three significant factors. Exports have been going up month by month and, importantly, the amount of the increase has been accelerating month by month.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Imports have been growing month by month but the figures are decelerating; that is, going down at a greater rate. That is a very important and worthwhile outcome for the Australian economy. It is one that clearly does not suit the opposition because there is still an unreasonable level of interjection.

PARA.TAB: These figures have been returned, importantly, in the face of subdued international economic demand. The global economy's strength has been soft; the prices and demand levels in areas of mineral commodities have been quite soft. Despite low demand in areas of traditional excellence in export performance, Australia's overall export performance has increased, which does vindicate our strategy about hooking ourselves more into the Asian growth area and integrating the Australian economy within this region. This also shows that, when domestic demand picks up at a much faster rate than it currently is, it will not squeeze out the export component; exports will continue to rise.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude by saying that all sorts of interjections are coming from the opposition. Australian exporters would be aghast to see the sneering contempt of the opposition in this chamber to their performance. It is a pitiful display by the opposition.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Why did the Prime Minister have the gall to tell the ACTU yesterday that there would be a significant increase in jobs this year when the latest Treasury figures show that unemployment will remain at about the same level as it is today and even then only because some 50,000 people will have given up looking for work? What possible hope do one million unemployed Australians have of getting a job, in view of the government's total failure on economic reform and total lack of economic policy direction.

—My recollection of the figure in the budget, which I have just had confirmed by my colleague Senator McMullan, is that the expected number of new jobs added to the Australian economy this year will be 100,000. That is a situation which does represent a significant advance on the situation that we have been confronting over the last two or three years. There are grounds for confidence, there are grounds for optimism, about the longer term trends. Of course we are confronting a continuing serious unemployment situation, but the important thing is that new jobs are starting to be created. If the level of growth in the economy accelerates to the point that we are all hoping and anticipating will be the case, then we will start to get some really significant net impact on the total jobless figure.

PARA.TAB: But we all know, and we have known for some time, that unless that overall growth figure gets up to the order of magnitude of around four per cent it is not going to be possible to make very significant inroads into the unemployment figure. But the important thing is that new jobs are being created, new people coming into the work force are getting into the job market now. There is an element, an environment, of much more confidence around the place at the moment in terms of very high levels of profitability in industry, a very high level of appreciation of export opportunity, more and more businesses are finding export opportunities and more and more of those export opportunities are in the high employment, value added manufacturing area. There is a stack of grounds for confidence, unless you happen to be a congenital doomsayer of the kind that congenitally exist opposite. There are plenty of grounds for optimism that we will meet these targets that we are now talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the answer that Senator Gareth Evans has given deny that the budget's own figures indicate that the number of unemployed persons in a year's time will be virtually unchanged from that today? I appreciate the minister's difficulty in defending, as ACTU President Martin Ferguson so correctly described, `the indefensible'. I ask him again: is his answer not simply further confirmation that, as Senator Gareth Evans himself said on the ABC's Labor in Power series, `the choice between Bob Hawke and Paul Keating as prime minister was like choosing between arsenic and strychnine'? Could he now inform the Senate and the Australian people, whose livelihoods he so savagely slashed, whether in respect of Mr Keating he was referring to arsenic or strychnine?

—I would rather a choice between those than between limp parsley and wet lettuce, which are the options that are being given to us by the other side. We have people of real character and commitment in our show. There has to be a limit to the degree of dishonesty that can be advanced in the questions that are put and the way in which opposition people jump and slide around from one point of a proposition to another. I was asked about the number of new jobs that would be created over the course of the next year. I answered in those terms. Senator Short then gets up and talks about what the unemployment figure will be. They are two different concepts, as even a bear of the small brain that Senator Short brings to these situations ought to be able to appreciate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the minister aware of the controversy in Victoria about the failure by the state government of Victoria to fund major road construction? What action will the national government take to boost funding to allow for the completion of the Hume freeway in Victoria, and what is the significance of this project?

—I thank my Victorian colleague for this question. The federal government has announced that it will provide more than $24 million in funding to complete the last two major projects on the section of the Hume Highway between Melbourne and Albury-Wodonga. The sum of $12.3 million will be spent by the Commonwealth on the Wangaratta bypass and $12 million on the Springhurst bypass. This is a milestone for road funding in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Hume Highway connecting Sydney and Melbourne is one of the busiest roads in Australia. Over the past decade the federal government has spent more than $365 million on the Hume Highway in Victoria and over $500 million on this highway in New South Wales. All of the major towns have been bypassed in Victoria reducing traffic congestion and pollution in those towns and providing a much safer environment for residents of those areas.

The entire 285 kilometres of the Hume Highway in Victoria, from the outskirts of Melbourne to Albury-Wodonga, will be dual carriageway by Easter next year when these two projects are completed. In New South Wales more than two-thirds of the highway between Sydney and Albury is already dual carriageway. With the completion of the Yass bypass, which we are also funding, the first 250 kilometres south of Sydney will be continuous four-lane freeway.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Senator Cook. In passing, I note that the minister, in his capacity as Minister for Trade, was waxing lyrical about—
—It is Senator Schacht.
—You have the wrong minister.

—I beg your pardon. I will still pass a comment, if I may. It is germane to the question about last month's trade figures which the Minister for Trade was waxing lyrical about. Over 12 months the exports were only half of the figure for imports. I now address my question to Senator Schacht: can the minister detail the measures he is prepared to take to assist those Australian industries which are besieged by cheap imports, seeing that the budget did not contain any import replacement measures?
