Is the minister prepared to make an industry by industry assessment of the measures needed to boost jobs for Australian workers, given the low potential for retraining in some of these industries and the fact that the largest group in long-term unemployment consists of the 19 to 25 year olds? (Time expired)

—The question that Senator Spindler raises with me comes generally from Senator Spindler's objection to the government's tariff policies and to the reduction of tariffs. My colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Mr Griffiths, to whom this question is directed, has made it quite clear that so far as this government is concerned the tariff debate is over. We are reducing tariffs to an appropriate level.

PARA.TAB: I say to Senator Spindler that a lot of industries in Australia are now taking up the challenge of lower tariffs, realising that they cannot survive in a restricted market in Australia but have to become export oriented. I would point out that although we have reduced tariffs, we did not follow the tariff policy of the coalition at the last election which was basically zero everywhere. We are selective and careful in our gradual reduction of tariffs. Senator Spindler ought to realise that there is a significant difference between our tariff policies and the policy of the opposition which involves zero tariffs.

In this last budget there were a number of new measures to help small and medium size enterprises, including $94 million for various programs to help such enterprises towards better management, better quality and greater exports, building on the McKinsey report and study for the Australian Manufacturing Council. I would have thought that Senator Spindler would have welcomed that report which showed that over 700 small and medium size Australian firms have become exporters—

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?
—Over 700 in that study.
—But there are 6,000 of them.

—Yes, and it identified quite correctly 6,000 further potential exporters. The measures in the budget are aimed at getting at least another 800 to join that 700 over the next two to three years. If that happens and those figures double, instead of exporting $8 billion this year, in three to five years time we will probably be exporting elaborately transformed manufactures of over $20 billion. That will make a significant improvement in the balance of trade figures.

PARA.TAB: Finally, one of the issues Senator Spindler has raised with Mr Griffiths is a view put forward from a group called Enterprise West about identifying products on the import registers.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been asking for it for a year.

—Yes, Senator Spindler has been asking for it. It has been raised with me as minister for customs and it has been raised with Minister Griffiths. Both of us are sympathetic to the view that we need to get more statistics for Australian industry to identify the imports. The real problem is that the present Australian Bureau of Statistics Act, which controls all these figures, prevents us, for reasons of confidentiality and privacy, from getting that information. Mr Griffiths and I have indicated that we want the matter looked at. It may mean that we will have to come back to the parliament to achieve Senator Spindler's end with an amendment to the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act. When we do, remember that there will be a considerable debate on the privacy issues and the confidentiality issues—
—What about the national interest?

—Of course, balanced with the national interest. I will be interested to see how the Democrats respond because when we introduced the Australia Card proposal they were all on about privacy and confidentiality. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science. I note that on 25 August the minister announced a review by the Australian Science and Technology Council of the 30 per cent external earnings target set several years ago by the government for its research agencies, principally CSIRO, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation and the Australian Institute of Marine Science. Given the foregoing, is the minister now able to advise the Senate on the background of this review and whether formal or anecdotal evidence has indicated how much this target has assisted research application and innovation in Australia?

—In recent months there have been a number of reports, as well as anecdotal information and comments to me and to other ministers, that the excellent research and development that is going on in our public institutions, as mentioned by Senator Loosley, is not flowing through to the small and medium size business sector. CSIRO recognises, from the initial McKinsey report on the Australian Manufacturing Council, that the small and medium size enterprises are not able to click into that excellent research that our science institutions are undertaking.

PARA.TAB: CSIRO commissioned a further study by McKinsey, which was released last week by CSIRO and by me. It made a number of major recommendations on how CSIRO can connect better and provide a better diffusion of its excellent research to the small and medium size business sector to get a commercial outcome. Some of those ideas include making scientists available on secondment for various periods and encouraging scientists from CSIRO and other agencies to become entrepreneurs and establish their own businesses with their ideas.

In relation to the 30 per cent target for commercial funds that the government had given all science agencies, CSIRO is getting around 30 per cent at the moment; ANSTO is getting around 30 per cent; and AIMS is getting around mid-20 per cent. It is becoming clear that the way that is being applied internally means that people are spending too much time trying to get commercial agreement at the big end of town, where it is easier to make an arrangement with a larger firm. How does one deal with smaller firms that do not have the infrastructure to negotiate a commercial contract?

A lot of small and medium size firms say that what they want is immediate help, maybe only a few hours of assistance to get them over a particular hurdle, to further develop a commercial product. Alan Griffiths and I have asked ASTEC to conduct an independent review of the operation of the 30 per cent target to find ways in which we can make the 30 per cent more flexible in its operation so that small and medium size enterprises can be assisted.

I point out to the Senate that this was one of the recommendations that came from the Joint Committee on Public Accounts of this parliament in a report last year. Amongst other things, it recommended that this 30 per cent figure be reviewed in the way we are now doing. Honourable senators can see that the government is responding not only to the interests and comments from the private sector but also to a recommendation from an appropriate parliamentary committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the government's budget of betrayal, and in particular to the pre-election lie that taxes would not be increased. Can the minister explain why prior to the election the government did not tell the truth and promise the Australian people up-front that it would increase sales tax on wine by 55 per cent, increase the excise on petrol by 7c per litre, increase sales tax on food, clothing and other necessities and fail to deliver in full the promised tax cuts?
—There is no tax on food. It was you who were going to put it on food.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator McMullan for making that particular contribution. I have said in this place a dozen times, 20 times, 50 times since we have been back that there is no basis whatsoever for that kind of allegation being made against the government. The statements that were made during the election campaign were to the effect that there would be no increase in taxation in rough terms as a proportion of GDP. That is what was said. That is what has been documented. That is what has been the subject matter of debate in this place and that is all those opposite have ever been able to refer to in arguing that there has been some default on the part of the government. Mr Keating did say:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . to maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment. In other words, what I am promising is not to put up tax.

That is as much as was said. We did of course make it clear that we were not in the business of broadening the base by opening up the broad base consumption tax, the GST, and we also made a number of other specific points clear, but none of them going to the particular issues that Senator Ellison has raised.

PARA.TAB: Of course, it is the case that no government can deny absolutely revenue options available to it, in particular if a government is going to maintain fiscal responsibility over the medium term. That is the difference between this government and this opposition. This is an opposition that is simply incapable of coming clean to the Australian community about the kind of balances that are necessary to maintain fiscal responsibility and economic responsibility.

This is an opposition that has gone to the Australian community, in terms of Dr Hewson's budget reply, saying that it would increase the deficit in each of the next four years and leave the deficit in 1996-97 over 50 per cent higher than it is under the government proposals. He is talking about increasing the deficit, with the stance the opposition is taking on taxes in this particular budget, by almost $1,400 million in 1993-94 and about increasing the deficit by $3 billion dollars in 1996-97.

So what is the opposition going to do to reduce that deficit? Is it going to increase taxes? Is it going to come clean on what it might be going to do in that respect? If the opposition puts the GST to one side, what is it going to do to compensate for that? Is it going to be in the wholesale sales tax area? Is it going to be in personal income taxes? Is it going to be in corporate taxes or is the opposition going to get there by reducing outlays?

When Mr Downer, the shadow Treasurer, was asked at the press club recently what he was going to do about the Fightback outlay cuts, whether they still stood, he ducked and he weaved and he slid all over the ice. The truth of the matter is that the coalition went to the last election with unacceptable proposals for tax increases. It went to the last election with unacceptable proposals about outlays and expenditure cuts. The only way it can face the community now is by telling lies. It is only by telling lies about what they are going to do that those opposite can keep their heads up, because that is the only environment in which they can live with themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister now assure the Australian people that budget mark 3 will remove all of those elements for which the ALP was not given a mandate?

—The ALP was given a mandate by the community, which the coalition conspicuously failed to get, to deliver responsible, effective government to this country, to bring to this country a style and approach to economic management that does not have unresolved dangling deficits of $3 billion in 1996-97. It is a style of management that is guaranteed to bring fiscal responsibility, decently low inflation rates, decently low interest rates and a decent growth environment in which people can be confident about investing and building jobs in that way. That is the commitment that we made to the electorate at the last election, and is the commitment on which we are delivering. Those opposite are incapable of doing either.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to the recent decision by the Western Australian government to overturn the decision of the previous government with respect to the purchase of the Creery Wetlands site at Mandurah in the south-west of that state. I ask: firstly, is the federal government prepared to purchase the Creery site to prevent the destruction of this internationally important wetland and migratory bird breeding area; and secondly, if not, what action is the federal government prepared to take to protect the area and ensure that Australia's obligations under the Ramsar convention and the Japan-Australia and China-Australia migratory bird agreement are met?

—I have been provided with the following information from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly. The Creery Wetlands are on privately owned land within the boundaries of the Peel-Harvey estuary which was listed by Australia as a wetland of international importance under the Ramsar convention in 1990. The estuary is also regarded as important for a number of species listed under the bilateral migratory bird agreements Australia has with Japan and China.

PARA.TAB: Under the former Western Australian government, a similar development proposal to that now under consideration was approved but modified to ensure protection of the more environmentally important areas and parts of the Creery wetland. Following the election of the Court government, a revised development proposal was submitted on 6 August 1993 to the West Australian Environment Protection Agency which recommended that this should be allowed to proceed. Minister Kelly wrote to the WA Minister for the Environment, Mr Minson, on 5 August, seeking his assurance that the WA government would take into consideration the international significance of the Creery Wetlands in its consideration of the development proposal. At this time Mrs Kelly has still received no response.

In response to the recommendations of the Western Australian EPA, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency is to make a submission appealing against the development proposal as it stands and urging that environmentally significant areas be set aside under conservation management.

In Australia, the Ramsar convention and the migratory bird agreements are implemented by the state and territory governments in cooperation with the federal government. The Commonwealth, in effect, delegates responsibility to the states and territories with respect to the management of sites recognised under the Ramsar convention. The federal government is determined that state and territory governments will act responsibly in the management of such areas and is prepared to take whatever steps are available to ensure this happens.

The Commonwealth government does not have funds available to purchase every threatened wetland in Australia, and we would hope to negotiate suitable agreements to protect such areas with the respective state or territory governments. Such an approach is consistent with the terms of the intergovernmental agreement on the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for the detailed and encouraging answer he has conveyed, but I also ask: does Australia stand to be in breach of the International Convention on Biological Diversity, which has been recently signed, if the federal government fails to act to protect the biodiversity of this irreplaceable wetland area?
—I have no information on that specific question, but I will—
—You were pretty good on the first one.

—I had the briefing; that is why. I would have thought even Senator Macdonald would have been able to read that out—maybe not after 10 o'clock at night. I will refer the question to the minister, Mrs Kelly, and get an answer hopefully by tomorrow.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of members of a delegation from the National Congress of Chile, led by Mr Munizaga. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate. I trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Fortunately, my question is not directed to the rude Senator Schacht but to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Does the Labor caucus support the government's harsh and unfair income test on pensioners' and veterans' shares; and will the government immediately repeal this hard-hearted measure?

—As all honourable senators will know, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer put out a press release the night before last, following—from what I could glean from the papers this morning—quite lengthy, full and frank discussions with, apparently, at least 40 caucus members. It has been decided to review implementation issues associated with the budget decision to assess capital gains and losses on shares for pensioners. I shall endeavour to report to the Senate as soon as a decision has been made by the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and Mr Baldwin on this issue.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Is it true that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, Mr Sciacca, and the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, met this morning about the shares issue? Has the government made a decision about the shares issue? If so, what is the decision? It does take effect on 23 September. Will the government extend the reported review of this uncharitable legislation to a total overhaul of the pensioner incomes and assets test and finally start listening to the thousands of pensioners who have written to parliamentarians, the Senate committee and the media, universally condemning the government's proposal?
—One wonders where Senator Patterson was last year when this legislation went through the Senate.
—Which you voted for.

—It is as if she were absent, along with all those silent—mute—colleagues around her. They all sat there and voted for it—every single one of them sat there and voted for it. I do not keep tabs on the diaries of Mr Willis and Mr Sciacca. I do not actually know whether or not they met this morning. I do not think I will bother to find out. I will be informed, however, when a government decision has been made. When it has been made and I have been informed, I will inform the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to the fact that the government's telephone interpreter service, the only such service in the world, is now in its 20th year of successful operation. I ask the minister to inform the Senate of the steps that have been taken to improve and upgrade this service over time and whether the government intends to continue this valuable service.

—Senator Murphy is right: the TIS has been operating for 20 years. It has been operating more and more successfully over that time. He is also right that it is the only such service in the world. It has developed from a very small organisation.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators may be able to remember when some 20 years ago three Turkish-born women who needed urgent medical attention could not get it because of language difficulties. As a consequence, tragically, they died. At that time, in February 1973, the Whitlam government set up the telephone interpreter service. The purpose then was to help migrants to overcome language and cultural barriers and to improve their access to a whole range of education and welfare services. It very quickly took off as a great success.

I think in the first six months there were some 18,000 inquiries of the service. Since then it has developed from a two-city, eight-staff, 20-language service to now being national, having some 2,000 professional contractors, and being able to operate in 100 different languages. It is also operating in country areas, including through the use of 008 numbers. It has both on-site interpreters and telephone interpreters, operates around the clock, and is now both a translation and interpreting service. It has also expanded its activities from the mere crisis role that it used to have to now accommodating everyday needs.

The usage figures for 1992-93 are an illustrative reflection of its success. Some 290,000 telephone inquiries were made in 1992-93 and there were some 76,000 on-site acts of assistance performed by the translating and interpreting service. It is not used solely by those of a non-English speaking background. Some half of the clients of the TIS are now of an English speaking background, either public utilities or private sector operators such as medicos and legal professionals. I am told that Senator Collins had the opportunity to use it at the Darwin airport to assist people with a Japanese background.

TALK.START.PARA: —It works like a charm.

—To the government it is a vital communication link and it is an important part of our social justice policy. In fact, it opens doors to those who otherwise would have language barriers keeping such doors closed.

PARA.TAB: Senator Murphy says that this is an important year in its development. This year it will take its five millionth call for interpreting assistance. In view of the fact that it has been expanding for some 20 years, it is a vital part of the landscape in this society. The Government has decided to evaluate this service to ensure that it is adequately geared for the future.

In summary, we see it as an important part of our social justice strategy and an important part of our access and equity policy. It enhances access to government services. As Senator Murphy also says, it is more particularly special for Australia because it is the only such service—and a successful one—in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I refer to the extraordinary admissions by the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy that they were not informed in advance of the budget of the Prime Minister's calculated decision to break his election promise on tax cuts or to increase taxes on wine and wool. Will the minister inform the Senate of the role he played in the original budget decision to dramatically slash funding of Medicare optometry services? Why does the minister believe that many of his senior cabinet colleagues are being excluded from key government decisions?
—I will not be discussing my role or the role of any of my colleagues in any cabinet decision ever.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Richardson gave his usual oleaginous prevarication to get outside the answer, and it is about time he gave a direct answer to a direct question in relation to his role. If the minister did participate in the original government decision, why did he advise the government to break its election promise and why, since this issue has hit the fan, has the minister so quickly distanced himself from it?
—I think my previous answer covered it more than adequately.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to proposed budget changes increasing repayment rates and levels of HECS, imposing a 50 per cent increase in HECS for students who fail to complete their course within a minimum time and doubling HECS for a second degree.

PARA.TAB: How many students will be affected by this double whammy, where both increases apply? What is the definition of a second degree, and how will HECS for second degrees be administered? Will they be through institutions or DEET, for example? Is it true that these changes are retrospective in that they will apply to students who are currently enrolled and not just new students in 1994?

Finally, is the government aware of National Union of Students figures which show that a student, who undertakes a second degree and takes out a loan at 91 per cent of the poverty line, will incur a debt of over $43,000? If so, how can the government justify the imposition of such crippling levels of debt on the students of Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—It is estimated that about 11,000 students would have been liable to pay the double HECS in respect of the second undergraduate degree in 1992. It is also estimated that had the 1.5 HECS been payable by students who completed degrees in 1991, having taken more than the minimum number of units plus one seminar unit, 12,000 would have been liable. It is expected that the number of students liable in 1994 would be of the same order.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the second part of Senator Bell's question, a second `degree' for the purposes of double HECS is an undergraduate qualification at the same or higher level as the degree already held by the student, whether it be undergraduate or postgraduate.

In regard to the third question, as was the case when HECS was first introduced in 1989, existing students will be liable for double or 1.5 HECS only in respect of units of study commenced from 1994. We cannot yet understand on what basis the calculation was made by the NUS study. Irrespective of the size of the student's debt, it does not become repayable until the student's income reaches average weekly earnings, which is well above the poverty line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Science and Small Business aware of comments by the new head of Adelaide's proposed multifunction polis, Mr Ross Kennan, condemning its direction prior to his appointment and describing MFP proposals as `desperate', `ethereal' and `about urban form and aesthetics instead of attracting investment'?
—That is not what he said. That is very selective, and you know it.
—That is exactly what he said. How much taxpayers' money has been wasted on these proposals that have been described by Mr Kennan as `poppycock'?

—Senator Bolkus quite rightly interjected that that is a very selective quote from quite a lengthy follow-up story of an interview that Mr Kennan gave to the Adelaide Advertiser two days ago. As the minister responsible for the MFP, I find the remarks of Mr Kennan, which I read in the newspaper yesterday and followed up today, quite reasonable. He made it quite clear that, until the new board was appointed towards the end of last year and operating early this year, and his appointment, the operation of the MFP was not as focused as it possibly could have been. But that is no reflection on the individual public servants and people involved and the people who worked very hard on the interim board.

PARA.TAB: Mr Kennan's appointment should be welcomed by all, particularly those who have an interest in a project of vision such as the MFP. With his experience, he is now giving commitment and clout to develop the MFP as a major project not only for Australia but internationally. I believe that Senator Chapman's remarks and his slanted quoting to try to do everything possible to undermine the MFP, which has enormous potential for South Australia, means that he is not doing the constituents from South Australia whom he represents any good.

Mr Kennan has pointed out, quite rightly, in the briefings he has given in recent days to me and other ministers that we want to get commercial and private investment into the MFP within the four major areas of interest that have been designated by the board. If Senator Chapman does not understand the concept of the MFP and he has trouble with Mr Kennan's remarks, we will arrange for him to have a briefing from Mr Kennan. Even if Mr Kennan gives it to him in slow time, I am sure that in the end Senator Chapman will get a better appreciation of the advantages of the MFP project for South Australia and Australia. There is no doubt that people with limited imagination, of whom there are many opposite, have trouble dealing with a project that contains an element of vision, which the MFP does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the minister's failure to answer my question with regard to how much taxpayers' money has been wasted, given Mr Kennan's criticism of the project. The minister's attempt to divert attention through abuse is simply not sustainable. My concern relates to the good stewardship of taxpayers' money. I again ask: given the federal government's, and therefore the federal taxpayers', financial commitment to this project, why has it allowed this waste of money and lack of focus to go on for so long? Is this claimed change of focus occurring only because of an imminent state election?

—Last week at the estimates committee Senator Ferguson asked a series of detailed and intelligent questions to which Mr Trenberth from the department answered as a member of the board. I thought the exchange between Senator Ferguson, with his intelligent questions—unlike those of Senator Chapman—and Mr Trenberth put a lot of information on the record about where the MFP is and how it is developing.

PARA.TAB: I also understand that today in the state parliament of South Australia, Mr Kennan is, as is required, going before the state parliament's committee on public accounts—or whatever is its equivalent name—to give that information to show that taxpayers' money is not being wasted. Questions and answers were given last week in the estimates committee. I know that Senator Chapman may have been present, but it is clear that he had his ears blocked when Senator Ferguson asked questions and got very detailed answers. The issues that Senator Chapman raises have been more than adequately dealt with. If he is concerned now, why did he not ask those questions last week at the estimates committee?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Trade to reports about the speech delivered yesterday by Mr Bill Ferris, the chairman of Austrade, at the Scanning Technology `93 expo in Sydney. Can the minister tell me whether it is true that Mr Ferris said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . a move by Australia to a republic status would, in my view, present a windfall marketing opportunity to Australian exporters?
Can he tell me whether he also said:
The republic comes in as a rare, indeed one-time, opportunity to focus the world's attention on a fresh and invigorated Australian image.
Did Mr Ferris seek the minister's approval to make these remarks? Does the minister agree with Mr Ferris's comments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see reports of Mr Ferris's speech yesterday. One appeared in the Financial Review and one other that I saw appeared in the Canberra Times. I note that the Canberra Times article concluded by saying:

PARA.TAB: Mr Ferris rejected the view that the republicanism debate was diverting attention from the main economic gain.
"The process is not a distraction from the real issues," he said.
"Handled sensibly, it will provide a very real boost to national exports.

ANSWER.PARA: I did see the reports and I think they express a point of view which is certainly well worth having in this national debate.

PARA.TAB: Did Mr Ferris seek my approval to express that point of view? No, he did not and nor should he. It is not my function to require heads of authorities such as Austrade to clear their speeches with me. They are his own views and I strongly believe he is entitled to express them. I am advised that he delivered to my office, out of courtesy, a copy of his remarks before they were delivered, but I have not actually read the full remarks.

I am now asked: do I agree with what he said? The answer to that question is, yes, I do agree with what Mr Ferris has said. There are two things that ought to said here. Mr Ferris is one of the few Australians in this country who knows a great deal about trade opportunities for Australia and how we are seen overseas. As head of Austrade he travels widely around the world and in our major trading markets, deals with complex issues and is across the detail of trade negotiations at both macro and micro level.

Mr Ferris is, if you like, a true reporter of Australia's image abroad. It seems to me that what he is saying in his reported remarks is that our image can be refurbished—that Australia can be seen as its own country and framing its own destiny as a republic, rather than as a constitutional monarchy. That will help Australia's export image because in markets in which we deal we will be seen to be genuinely part of Asia and part of the region.

I also think that his views are valuable from another point of view. In my own travels on trade issues for Australia, one of the matters of great interest in the republican debate in this country from overseas is: what does this mean? Certainly within Asia, the area of our boom markets, the republican debate is interpreted as being a debate about not only our constitutional arrangements but also our presence as part of this region. It is seen as us making a commitment to our own sovereignty and our integration and role in this region.

It is therefore important that Australia is not seen as an external country trying to batten on to growth of the Asian economies, but as integral and part of that growth and a welcome member of this regional community. While the views expressed by Mr Ferris are his own, I think they are fair and are a welcome contribution to this important debate in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the actions of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the government in not speaking to Mr Crean, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and not allowing him any look-in in the budget, leading to his allegations of a conspiracy against him over the wine tax, and in view of the fact that Mr Crean is meant to represent primary industry, the nation's major export earner, I ask the minister: as the minister for primary industries is being made even more ineffective than he already was by the Prime Minister's no talk, no consultation approach, in the long-term interest of primary industry and the continued good health of the Australian wine industry, will the Prime Minister replace Minister Crean with someone as minister that he and the Treasurer will talk to and consult with?

—Mr President, Senator Boswell ought to take notice of that old nostrum that Reg Withers used to enunciate in here on so many occasions: do not believe everything you read in the newspapers. Senator Boswell will get a terribly distorted and cock-eyed view of the world if he does. Simon Crean is a big, tough, strong boy; he can look after himself and, at the same time, look after the interests of all those many, many constituencies that he has responsibility for. He is an extremely effective minister. He has been totally on top of his portfolio. He has done a brilliant job in advancing and articulating the interests of all those different constituencies even if, on occasion, he is confronted with rather graceless commentary of the kind that Senator Boswell has just offered.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Arts and Administrative Services

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Arts and Administrative Services. Is the minister aware of allegations that his department's businesses compete unfairly with the private sector? Could the minister say whether the allegations are true and, if they are not, would he outline the real situation?

—The matter which Senator Childs raises relates to quite a complex situation because there is a range of elements in terms of benefits and disadvantages relatively between businesses operating within the department of administrative services and the private sector. On balance, the evidence suggests that DAAS businesses do not have an unfair advantage in competing with the private sector. In fact, the evidence suggests that collectively DAAS groups operate under cost structures that leave them neither better nor worse off than their private sector competitors.

PARA.TAB: The process of commercialisation which the government started in 1987 has meant that well over $700 million in potential revenue previously controlled by the DAAS operations has been opened up to competition. In the budget we announced a review of the direction of commercialisation within the department. This will allow the commercialisation strategy to achieve its full potential in benefits to taxpayers and to the economy in general.

Right now, fully commercial DAAS businesses operate under arrangements consistent with those prevailing in the private sector—for example, the accrual accounting requirements, the business regulations under legislation such as the Trade Practices Act, and the accountability framework consistent with the corporations law. While most DAAS businesses do not pay most taxes—this will be reviewed in the lead up to 1995—payments are set aside in lieu of Commonwealth and state indirect taxes and charges for non-Commonwealth work. Of course, some taxes are paid—for example, customs duty and fringe benefits tax.

The most robust independent analysis of the relative position between businesses operating within the department of administrative services and their private sector competitors is that done by Ernst and Young. Ernst and Young concluded that the net effect for DAAS is that, across the board, DAAS businesses are disadvantaged by some two to three per cent of sales revenue when compared with their private sector competitors.

As I said in my opening response to Senator Childs's question, a range of complex factors is involved and discussion of it is never assisted by simplistic assertions which we have had from time to time from, for example, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory in his enthusiasm to have the government sack 160 of his constituents. There are pluses and minuses involved. There are advantages and disadvantages that come with operating within the public sector. More than slogans and prejudice are needed to analyse it. I have to say that all too often in the past we have had from the competitors and from some political observers nothing more than slogans and prejudice.

The important thing is that those who seek to analyse and comment on this matter and participate in debate base their decisions on an assessment of the public interest—that is, the public as taxpayers getting a return on their investment in these businesses and getting an efficient service from these businesses. The public are the ultimate consumers of the services provided. On that basis, I think we can establish a basis for businesses operating within the department of administrative services to continue to be viable businesses competing fairly with the private sector and open to competition from the private sector which benefits enormously from that. It, therefore, has to accept the corollary that, if it gets the enormous benefits of competing for this work, it will have to accept that competition will apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the minister confirm that the CES recently paid over $12,000 to relocate two Hobart wood machinists, their families and pets, to the warmth of sunny Queensland? Can the minister further confirm that the CES recently flew a Melbourne woman to the Gold Coast for an interview as a receptionist and a South Australian man to Queensland for a job as a storeman? Given Queensland's high level of unemployment and the skills of the jobs involved, how can the CES justify this outrageous expenditure which completely ignores the claims of the local unemployed? Recognising the obvious inefficiencies in the present scheme, will the government give a commitment to examine the relocation priorities of the CES or are Australia's taxpayers to be expected to continue to fund this working holiday scheme?

—I am unfamiliar with the first example cited by Senator Calvert but I am a little familiar with the second and third. I think this matter received some publicity in the newspapers. DEET has launched an investigation into this matter. I understand that the minister is considering—if he has not yet finalised—a change in the guidelines to prevent what is a rather curious decision in at least two cases that I know of. To Senator Calvert's question, `Will the government do something about it?', the answer is yes.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Yesterday, Senator Gibson asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question about the extension of fringe benefits tax to payment of education and training fees for employees. I am now able to give him the following answer.

PARA.TAB: The government has decided to make expenditure by employers on non-deductible fringe benefits subject to FBT and deductible. This measure will come into effect from 1 April 1994. It will cover expenditure on entertainment expenses, the payment of club fees, provision of leisure facilities, travel expenses of an accompanying relative, and the payment of HECS and the student financial supplement scheme, or SFSS, liabilities where provided to employees as fringe benefits.

This reform will ensure equality of tax treatment between those currently untaxed non-deductible benefits, other fringe benefits and cash remuneration. The reform will also close off an increasingly utilised loophole in the fringe benefits tax provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Alston asked me, in my capacity of Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question about the impact of the budget on low income earners. I sought to take that question away and give him a further response, which I now do. Senator Alston's question did not provide sufficient detail to allow for a full analysis of the impact of the budget decisions for the individual case that he raised. For example, the marital status of the person concerned, the income earned by a spouse, if any, and the number and age of dependants would all, of course, have an impact on how any one individual would fare out of the budget.

PARA.TAB: The government has announced changes to the budget measures which will improve the position of low income people. These measures are the latest of many which the government has taken since coming to power in 1983 to improve the position of low income Australians. The most comprehensive distributional analysis of the budget measures was announced in the Treasurer's press release of 31 August. That analysis does show, as I said in question time today, that the vast majority of household types and income groups will make small average gains as a result of the budget measures.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the Senate asked me to lay on the table documents pertaining to the selection of companies to the short list of tenderers for the contract to market the government's disability reform package. I table the documents supplied by the Office of Government Information and Advertising in response to that resolution.

QWN.TITLE: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to a multi-part question which Senator Knowles asked me yesterday about the extension of SBS into rural regions of Western Australia and, in particular, the number of inquiries SBS itself had received and so on. I have been advised by SBS that most inquiries to SBS itself are by telephone. It does not keep figures on the actual number of inquiries received, but each year the SBS annual report lists the centres from which the inquiries come.

PARA.TAB: The SBS Perth satellite signal does not have sufficient coverage or power for other areas in Western Australia to access the service easily. It is in eastern standard time, not local Western Australian time, requiring the provision of time delay equipment on the ground, which is not an inconsiderable expense. There is insufficient satellite capacity at this stage which could be used to transmit SBS services to rural Western Australia without displacing one of the existing services currently available to rural Western Australian viewers.

Limited resources are available to extend SBS television to all areas which have expressed interest in receiving it. Therefore, extensions must be considered on a phased basis. Under the current extension program, SBS television has been extended to the La Trobe Valley, Bendigo, Ballarat and Toowoomba, and it will be extended to the remainder of the Darling Downs by 1993. It is now available to over 85 per cent of the Australian population. Extensions for Darwin, the Spencer Gulf, Cairns and Townsville are due to commence in December this year and north-eastern Tasmania in April 1994. Further extensions to SBS television have not been approved by the government. The government will give further consideration to this matter prior to the 1994-95 budget. The needs of residents of rural Western Australia will be taken into account, along with those of other areas, in that consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Patterson this day, relating to proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Acts.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's handling of the pensioner shares issue is deplorable and nothing short of an absolute disgrace. Month after month the government has told us and the pensioner community that it will not change its mind on this harsh and inequitable income test, and time and time again it has told pensioners that the measure is fair and equitable. Less than a month before the commencement date, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), as part of a massive budget backdown, unprecedented in Australia's history, announced that the government will review the implementation of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: It is tough luck for all those pensioners and veterans who have already sold their valuable share portfolios. If any honourable senators on the other side of the chamber have read the letters that they have received from pensioners, they would know that many of them have accumulated those shares by saving over a long period; some have inherited small shareholdings from their husbands, which they had as a result of their work; some of them have inherited small shareholdings from their families. Some of them have now been forced to sell them.

There is no indication of when this review will be undertaken. There has been no announcement about whether any decision will be made prior to 23 September, which is the start-up date. That is only three weeks away and pensioners have to make a decision. After Tuesday, we will not be sitting again until 27 September. So, when we come back after this sitting period, the event will have come and gone. Pensioners need to know.

What do the thousands of pensioners and veterans who have to decide whether or not to sell up their shares do now? Do they wait and hope? Do they sell up and lose portfolios which they have built up over a long period? What on earth are they supposed to do? In a press release of a couple of days ago, the Prime Minister made this half-baked comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Following this evening's Caucus discussion, it has also been decided to review implementation issues associated with the 1992/93 Budget decision to assess capital gains and losses on shares for pensioners.

We know that when the Prime Minister was Treasurer he used to try to legislate by press release, and he is trying to do it again now. But pensioners know that that is not law—l-a-w. Even if it is l-a-w, it can be changed. This law ought to be changed; it ought to be repealed. The government ought to tell pensioners now what it is going to do about it.

PARA.TAB: We are told that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) met with the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) this morning. The gossip we have heard around the corridors is that the shares issue is going to the wall. The public, particularly the pensioners who are affected, ought to know today what is going on.

A committee was set up by the Australian Democrats and the coalition to look at this. Two hundred submissions and over 2,000 letters were received. Mr President, if you were able to read those letters, you would find that there were stories which told of great hardship and great concern. In fact, I have had two indications of people who have even contemplated suicide because of the implications that this will have for their finances. The letters almost unanimously call on the uncharitable measure to be repealed.

Hundreds of people turned up at the hearings in the freezing cold in Melbourne to watch the committee proceedings, to give their support and to show their concern. The interest in this inquiry has been virtually unprecedented, but the attitude of the government to this official inquiry has been contemptuous from day one. It has disregarded the concern of pensioners. Numbers of people have been ringing up my office and many of my colleagues' offices saying that they voted for Labor last time but that they had been hoodwinked and they would never vote for it again.

This morning the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, Senator West, moved to postpone the presentation of the committee's report. It has been finished. The staff have worked day and night to produce the information. But Senator West moved to postpone the presentation of the committee's report to a later hour this day—not until after question time, but to a later hour this day. Why? So the government's part of the report can match what the government is going to do. Senator West does not seem to know what is happening over on the other side. If she puts out a report and it does not agree with what the government is going to do, she will have egg on her face. So this report is being delayed. The government wants to prevent the Senate from being able to take note of this important report because we would have been able to speak on it. The government also wants to ensure, as I said before, that the committee report mirrors the government's decision in terms of what is happening down the way. But we know that it has no idea what is happening down the way. The ministers do not know what is happening and we are about to get budget mark 3. I am sure three-quarters of the people on the other side do not know.

This attitude is absolutely contemptuous. It shows that the government senators on this committee are quite content to ignore totally all the submissions, letters and oral evidence presented to the inquiry. They do not care if the pensioners are forced to the sell their shares needlessly, nor do they care that many older Australians have been worried sick for months about this measure. They have rung my office and they have come into my office expressing their concern. They tell us that they do not know what to do and they ask whether this measure will be repealed. We cannot tell them. The Prime Minister issues a press release and then does not get on and do something about repealing it in these last couple of days of sitting before the measure comes into place. The concern is that this committee has been railroaded. The committee report ought to be here and on the table. We on this side of the chamber want to know when the government will make its decision. I ask, on behalf of pensioners: when will that decision be made?

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion of Senator Patterson to take note of the answer. This particular answer is consistent with the confusion that has been part of this sorry story. It gives a clue to the desperation that we see from the government in trying to deal with this, because it cannot be dealt with in a consistent way following the arguments that the government has put up for this measure.

PARA.TAB: Right from the beginning this particular issue could have been questioned on equity grounds, and I did question it. It just was not fair. Right from the beginning it could have been questioned on administration grounds, and I did question it. How on earth could it be administered? By whom would it be administered? Where would it be administered? So many older citizens who know better than this government, who have a lot more commonsense, could see that it could not possibly be administered in a fair way, as it had been proposed.

It could have been questioned on commonsense grounds and consistency. If some of our citizens were to be treated in this way, why not all PAYE taxpayers? Why not all shareholders? Why not treat the capital gains that other people benefit from in the same way? Why is not the capital appreciation of all properties being treated this way? As a matter of fact, I questioned this matter on the grounds of it not being good English. To define capital gains as income is to defy the English language. It just is not so.

These arguments have all been well rehearsed. They have all been heard by the committee and the government. Although they have been well rehearsed and well presented, there is yet to be an answer to any of them. Because of that, Senator Patterson is quite right: we can anticipate a final denouement from this government. It has woken up. It cannot get away with it. It was a stupid idea and it will not wash.

The more experienced, the older, members of our community are quite rightly saying that at last there is an inkling that this decision might be changed. But do we see common sense in the application of this change? No—we see prevarication, we see shuffling about, we see a planting of feet and a great confusion. The great confusion, I am afraid, is only part of the battle that I have seen to get this matter under way. I had to provoke the coalition—and, I must say, the provocation was accepted and responded to—into acting on this by writing to all senators in this place and asking them what their attitude would be—

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't need it, thanks very much.

—Senator Watson asked for this provocation; now he is going to get it. After the coalition voted in support of this measure before Christmas, after Christmas I wrote asking its members what they would do if I introduced a private member's bill to repeal it. In that provocation—I also had to initiate petitions to get things under way—I was almost sidelined by their refusal to do anything with the private members' bills that were introduced. But in provoking the issue by suspending standing orders, we finally got some action and managed to refer it to the committee.

PARA.TAB: This place deserves to see that committee report as soon as it is ready, and I understand that the report is ready and should be tabled today. There should not be any shuffling about or any attempt to hide it behind an imminent adjournment of the Senate later this day. It ought to be here now. I agree with Senator Patterson that we ought to see what the government is going to do. It is not us in this chamber who will be directly affected by it; it will be those people who in a few days' time will have their personal affairs affected greatly by this. They should not have to wait another moment to make those decisions. Far too many people have been provoked into making decisions already which have been at great cost to their personal arrangements. They should not have to wait any longer at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation will come into effect after 12 months of enormous insecurity for pensioners. During that time, the evidence that I have gathered at the public hearings on this matter has indicated to me that it has been extremely difficult for pensioners to obtain information on this issue. Not only that, but during the past few months a 50 per cent cap on the maximum increase in shareholdings has been announced which is not in the legislation and which has further confused pensioners.

PARA.TAB: The Government's rationale for adopting this measure is that savings of approximately $60m per annum will be effected. This is debatable, as one would think that a quarterly assessment of all pensioner shareholdings would be more than eaten up in additional salaries. Long-term, it will mean that pensioners will sell their shares and ultimately return to a full pension.

The insecurity of pensioners on this issue has been especially marked by the moving accounts of those people who devote most of their pension money to paying for accommodation in nursing homes. If the level of their pension is affected by this measure it will mean that their accommodation in those nursing homes could be precarious. Not only that, but we encountered many carers who have given up a full-time income and a full-time career to look after aging or dependent relatives. They have a carer's pension but in the event of this measure taking place their income will be very insecure.

I would also like to mention the position of many women in the 55-plus age bracket who, because of their position in history, have not had access to superannuation. They are dependent on money that they have inherited or money that they have put together and they have bought shares to try to bolster their pension income. If this measure goes through, they will be deprived of even that small comfort. Many of them have inherited shares from their husbands or other relatives, as Senator Patterson mentioned, and again this will be placed in jeopardy.

As I mentioned, the savings to the government are debatable, as many pensioners indicated that they would sell their shares because of the complexity and worry of dealing with this situation, and revert to a full pension. Not only that, but the cost of hospital and other associated health care will ultimately be higher to the government as part pensioners cut out private health insurance and, with quarterly assessments, the entrance and departure of pensioners to and from fringe benefits and the associated administrative costs may be a factor that has not been added into departmental costs. It may also encourage the hoarding of pharmaceuticals, a practice that the government is trying to overcome by spending appreciable sums on this now.

These proposals encourage pensioners to dispose of productive assets to maximise their pension entitlements. This is highly undesirable when national savings are at a record low. As we had pointed out to us earlier in the year, the Fitzgerald report detailed how it is absolutely essential to raise the level of national savings. The government's argument that the proposal would result in a more equitable treatment of pensioner investments is fundamentally flawed. Listed securities are treated more harshly than real estate, art, antiques and non-listed securities, all of which are non-assessable under this legislation. But once pensioner money is in them, it then becomes difficult for the pensioners to realise them for income purposes.

It is not appropriate—I agree with Senator Bell on this—that assessment be made of the same or part of the same amount under both assets and income test. The use of the word `income', and the insistence that a gain is a capital income gain, concerns investors in shares and in those investments treated in a similar manner. In addition, some witnesses pointed out that they have already paid income tax on the money that they used to buy their shares. They do accept that the dividends should be taxed but they objected that another form of taxation of unrealised gains was now being assessed.

Given the above reasons, it is quite amazing that the government seems to consider that there are large numbers of millionaire pensioners. On the contrary, the attendances of 250-plus at each of the public hearings I attended, the 2,000 letters that members of the committee received and the 200 submissions that were made to the committee indicated to me that this group are the members of the forgotten group of Australians whom the government is hitting hardest in its budget proposals.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many pensioners and part pensioners out there—an estimated 60,000—who are worried sick about their financial future because of the government's money grabbing tactics, another group of true believers who may want their votes back. From 23 September, when unrealised capital gains on shares will be treated as income under the pensioners income test, many pensioners' security will ride the roller-coaster of the Australian Stock Exchange. Their entitlements will become a lottery. The government apparently cannot see the stress it is putting the elderly under. Presently, share dividends received by a pensioner are included in the pensioner's income for income test purposes, and any unrealised growth is assessed under the assets test.

PARA.TAB: It is very unfair to treat unrealised capital growth as income. The very nature of unrealised capital growth is that no income is received. Yet, under the proposed formula it is possible for someone's pension entitlement to be wiped out because of the paper gains which have never been realised.

This proposal is not equitable when it treats listed shares differently from unlisted shares and other investments. Desperately needed dollars in national savings and investments will suffer as these people divert their funds to less productive areas of the economy to escape the new measures. Furthermore, this move will establish a very worrying and dangerous precedent that may be extended to other areas. We are dealing not with jetsetting retirees here; we are dealing with ordinary Australians who have made provision for their retirement. They will now be penalised for their foresight.

When this legislation was introduced in December last year, the government cynically included this proposal in an omnibus bill which contained a number of other amendments which gave benefits to pensioners. That has been forgotten now. It is a major disappointment that this Labor government did not use the budget to repeal the discriminatory legislation. It is time to act. It is time to throw out this legislation. Pensioners are an easy target for any government, but this government must direct its revenue raising measures elsewhere to repair its budget deficit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to support Senator Patterson's motion. On Monday in this chamber a senator opposite said that the Labor government was a caring and responsible

SPEECH.PARA: government prepared to respond in a caring and responsible way. Call me a cynic, but I believe that the only people this government cares about is itself. As for being responsible, the events of the past few days have shown just who it is responsible to: self first, party second and Australia last. If this government is indeed a caring government, why is it responsible for systematically destroying the hopes and futures of so many retired elderly pensioners in our society?

PARA.TAB: I am referring to the iniquitous legislation proposed by this so-called caring government to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income. This government wants to attack the defenceless members of our society, those people who are dependent on the purse strings of government. These are the people who are being singled out for no other reason than that they worked hard and were led to believe that they were going to be provided for in their retirement.

This so-called caring government is not concerned. So long as it can rob old Peter the pensioner to pay `Paul the Cheating's' extravagances, it can go about its business of destroying the future of another generation of Australians. This government legislation is riddled with problems which would be obvious to this so-called responsible government if it took the time to open its eyes to see past its ever growing nose.

The first obvious flaw in the legislation is its inequity. Under the current proposal Australian pensioners will be placed in a unique category of income assessment—assessment that is not applied to any other member of society, rich or poor. Or is this just the first sign of future taxes on realised income for all Australians?

The government must be prepared to listen to its people. These people in their thousands want to know: why should the Department of Social Security take into account unrealised gains on shares and investment when the tax office does not? Why should the government penalise those pensioners who invest in this nation's future by investing in Australian companies? Would the government prefer pensioners to take their money offshore? Or would the government rather pensioners hide their money under their mattresses? They are certainly not sleeping well these days, so why not put it to good use. The Senate will recall that Malcolm Fraser was laughed at years ago when he suggested the safest place to keep our money was under the bed. How appropriate it is today that this remains the only place you can keep your money safe from the Treasurer's tax pack.

Heaven help these pensioners if they own a car. Let us look at a typical pensioner who owns a vehicle more than 10 years old—and I suspect that most of them do. With the new tax on leaded fuel, these vehicles will depreciate at a greater level than ever before. This will come on top of the government's legislation to reduce pensions based on unrealised gains in share values. An embattled pensioner will be driven into a lower standard of living via reduced pensions and expensive petrol, and the journey will be made in a vehicle that is losing value faster than this government can save face.

The inequity of this issue is most apparent when one looks at who the main targets of this legislation are. I refer to the submission by the Department of Social Security and its demographics of affected clients. The figures highlight the inherent discriminatory nature of this legislation with 91 per cent of affected clients being born in English speaking nations, 60 per cent of those affected being women and 17 1/2 per cent being over 80 years of age. I conclude that Australian born women aged 80 years or more are a prime target of this bill—defenceless targets under the government's relentless attack on our senior citizens.

When I hear the claptrap from time to time about equal opportunity, and we have this discriminatory approach to elderly females in our community, I ask where are the feminists coming out of the woodwork over this?

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Senator West?

—Where is Senator West? With this legislation the government hopes to scrape some $44 million from the already shrinking pockets of our pensioners. And for what? To pay for the grand expenses of its election promises. By following simplistic logic and applying it to an often unsympathetic stock market, the government is playing with the livelihoods of thousands of Australians. I put it to the Senate that the only certainty about the market is its uncertainty.

—I am a senator who has taken a great interest in this decision of the government to reduce the value of the social security and veterans' pension as a result of a rise in the stock market value of shares. Recently, the government commissioned a report on national savings by Dr Vince FitzGerald for the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). He pointed out very clearly that Australia's national savings, now at 16 per cent of GDP in 1991-92, was at its lowest level in two generations. Apart from national emergencies, the two world wars and the Great Depression, it is at the lowest level of savings this century.

PARA.TAB: What this government has done in this legislation in victimising the pensioners who happen to own some shares is discourage the level of saving in this country even further. Dr FitzGerald in his report makes a very significant comment in relation to the importance of national household savings. I suggest that government senators read this closely. Therefore, I call for the tabling and presentation of this document by the committee at the first available opportunity, since this is relevant.

The government recently sold some of its shares in the Commonwealth Bank through a public float. It encouraged thousands of Australians to become shareholders for the first time. Shares in the Commonwealth Bank was a safe, secure shareholding. Those people who were lured into that investment to provide and to save have now been quite disillusioned as a result of this decision by the government. What it really means is that the value of those shares has increased as a result of good management but, according to the legislation brought before this place, from 1 September—unless a decision has been made to the contrary—pensions will reduce as a result of the increase in that share value.

Those pensioners do not receive any cash flow, so what are they forced to do? They are forced to sell some of those shares that they purchased in the Commonwealth Bank. How else are they to maintain their standard of living? How else are they going to buy their vegetables and their groceries? They do not have the cash resource.

I believe that the Senate should have taken action long before now. Some time ago, I think going back to 1978, similar provisions were brought in to reduce the value of the pension where there was an increase in the value of friendly society bonds and investment bonds.

The problem is: why just public company shares? Why not private shares, trusts, antiques, property and all the other sorts of issues? I think it is appalling that the Department of Social Security has encouraged the government to go on this divergent course. Why should those people who are less able to defend themselves, namely, the elderly and those with special disadvantages, be treated in this way? The government already has two determinants for determining the level of pension: an assets test and an income test. Now it is bringing in an unrealised capital gains or growth tax. This is just the thin end of the wedge, I believe, for the introduction of a wealth tax. A wealth tax is currently being imposed through this mechanism on that section of the community that can least afford it.

I remind the Senate that the superannuation guarantee charge must not be the only vehicle for saving in this country, and we are tending to move down this path. I wonder whether it will be a vehicle for saving. If the government had lifted the level of taxes on the SGC charge, as it had wished, the charge would have had to go up even higher, which would make it even less defensible. I call upon the government to ensure that this report is brought down expeditiously. We have to have a speedy, satisfactory and honourable solution to a problem that is affecting up to 80,000 Australian people.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, the National Health and Medical Research Council, as you know, was established in 1936. This report is its first annual strategic plan for this triennium; it goes under a triennial budget. There are two aspects of the report to which I wish to refer. The first is the ethics of resource allocation, and the National Health and Medical Research Council has a subcommittee which has this as part of its reporting requirement. The issue of the ethics of resource allocation is extremely important. In the Courier-Mail yesterday a full page article entitled `A national disgrace' referred to the health rationing that is occurring in my state, Queensland, particularly in relation to cardiac surgery and the use of angioplasty catheters. There is a heading `Heart attack while waiting'.

PARA.TAB: It is important that the National Health and Medical Research Council devote a considerable amount of its efforts to the resource allocation and rationing that is occurring in relation to Medicare in this country at the moment. We are witnessing and will continue to witness, under the Medicare agreements as they exist, continually diminishing resources devoted to trying to cut costs and distribute the cake around even more thinly to an ever increasing number of elderly people in our community. The largest growing sector in our community is people over the age of 60, and two-thirds of the health care dollar is spent on people over the age of 60.

The second matter I wish to refer to in relation to the ethics committee is the challenge of the future. A book was published earlier this year called Predicting the Future. In the section relating to the changes that will occur in health care, it points out that the biggest challenge of the future is not technology, it is not the ageing of the population; it is the ethics of resource allocation. The ethics are in relation to genetic engineering. At this moment, the biggest advance that is occurring in health care is the identification of diseases related to genes. Already, some 170-odd genes have been identified that are responsible for particular diseases, for example, muscular dystrophy and the neuromuscular wasting diseases.

We have not reached the stage in this community, nor to my knowledge has this been approached by any body in this community, where serious consideration is being given to genetic engineering and the manipulation of genes in embryos to counteract the production of disease in the community. It comes down to the expense of doing this. Various articles have been written about designer babies in relation to the in-vitro fertilisation program, but we have to consider this issue. As I see it, it is the responsibility of the National Health and Medical Research Council to take this aboard in relation to its strategic plans in the future, as it was not mentioned in this first strategic plan.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 4 of 1993 dated 1 October 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the adequacy of existing mechanisms to maintain the rights of clients and shareholders of non-bank financial institutions, with particular reference to Metway Bank and the Queensland government's failure to return certain contributions. I also table a volume containing the submissions to the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report discharges a reference given by the Senate on 11 November 1992. Metway Bank, whose dispute with the Queensland government was the central issue in the reference, took action in the Supreme Court of Queensland the day after the Senate reference, and it would not have been appropriate for the committee to have pursued the reference actively while the issue was before the court. We did, however, seek written submissions from interested parties and proceeded promptly to consideration of the reference after the court's decision was handed down on 20 May 1993.

PARA.TAB: The report sets out the background to the reference. Essentially, this is that the board of the former Metropolitan Permanent Building Society, MPBS, recommended to its members in 1987 that they agree to the conversion of the society to a bank. This was done in the knowledge that, if it converted to a bank, the society would have no claim to its contributions to a contingency fund established some years earlier to stabilise the building society industry in Queensland. A postal ballot of members approved the conversion, and it proved to be a commercially wise decision. The Metway Bank, which replaced MPBS, has been a very successful institution and has greatly increased its growth rate over that achieved as a building society.

The dispute with the Queensland government arose in 1992, when national arrangements for the regulation of non-bank financial institutions were adopted which rendered the building society contingency fund obsolete. The Queensland government then decided to apply part of the fund to the cost of establishing the new supervisory arrangements and to refund the balance to the nine building societies still in operation. Metway Bank sought a share of the refund in recognition of past contributions by MPBS.

As the submissions to the committee clearly showed, there were competing policy imperatives in this case. It is important to note that they were overwhelmingly matters for state policy and not for this parliament to review. In the event, the Queensland government opted for a policy that would enhance competition in the provision of financial services. Metway has argued that this was at the expense of equity or of some moral right that the bank had to a share in the contingency fund.

The committee's report notes that this argument should not be overstated. The members of MPBS made a commercial decision which involved surrendering their interest in the contingency fund and benefited handsomely from that decision. It can be argued that their prior contributions to the contingency fund were in the nature of insurance premiums against instability in the building society industry and that they had benefited from the confidence and stability provided through the existence of the fund. In any case, the Queensland Court of Appeal decisively rejected Metway's arguments about equity.

The detailed terms of the reference from the Senate link the dispute to the responsibilities of the federal parliament by relating it to effects on business confidence and to the adequacy of mechanisms for protection of the rights of shareholders and clients of financial institutions. The evidence presented to the committee in relation to these questions clearly indicates that there are no problems in these areas.

The first term of reference concerns possible competitive distortions, effects on business confidence and effects on the financial system of the Queensland government's decision. The submissions from the Treasury and the Reserve Bank, which share administrative responsibility in this area, were unambiguous on this. The Queensland government's decision had no adverse effect on the financial system. The Reserve Bank told the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not see any significant implications for the financial system in the dispute which seems to arise from a special set of circumstances.

The committee noted that during the period of the dispute, Queensland economic indicators were among the best of any of the state economies, which would hardly be compatible with any loss of business confidence in the state. For the Queensland government's decision to have an adverse effect, it would be necessary for adverse perceptions of the decision to be widely held. In fact, there are arguments for and against the decision and it is unlikely that perceptions of it would be generally adverse. The Queensland Association of Permanent Building Societies, representing more than one million members, strongly supported it. The clear finding of the court of appeal against Metway would also have weakened any adverse perceptions that do exist.
