PARA.TAB: To the extent that the decision creates any competitive distortion, it is in the direction of stronger rather than weaker competition in the provision of financial services—something we should all support. In any case, this is an isolated incident depending on circumstances which cannot recur. It should therefore have no long-term or systemic implications.

The second of the committee's terms of reference was the technical question of whether Metway Bank is the same entity as MPBS. This appears to have been rendered irrelevant by the decision of the Queensland Court of Appeal but, on the understanding that the committee's conclusion does not constitute a legal opinion, it is that Metway Bank is the same entity as MPBS.

The third term of reference relates to the adequacy of existing mechanisms to protect the rights of clients and shareholders in non-bank financial institutions in circumstances where such institutions become banks. The provisions that applied when MPBS became Metway Bank required, among other things, the approval through a pre-paid postal ballot of 75 per cent of the society's members. This requirement has been transferred to the new national system for the supervision of non-bank financial institutions with the added proviso that at least 20 per cent of the members vote. It represents a powerful protection of the interests of clients and shareholders of these institutions. The Queensland government is accountable to its parliament and the parliament to the people for decisions like those taken in the Metway case. This also is a powerful protection.

The committee sees no need for stronger protections than those which already apply. I would urge any who doubt this conclusion to read the submissions to the committee's inquiry and the decisions of the Queensland Court of Appeal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to cover one particular issue in relation to this report; my colleagues will be covering a wider range of issues. The issue I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate is one that I regard as a serious issue. I am delighted that Senator Coates is in the chamber to hear this.

PARA.TAB: We had a reference from the Senate to conduct an inquiry and in discussions with the committee there was a desire that there be a public hearing. This was resisted and we decided then to seek the wider feeling of the chamber. As my colleague Senator Parer and as Senator Kernot will confirm, the committee sought their views about whether, from the point of view of the coalition and the Australian Democrats, we should have a public hearing. The responses that we received to those requests were that indeed the coalition was keen—Senator Parer, as one of the initiators of this matter, was keen as was Senator Kernot.

There was a strong feeling amongst the coalition members of the committee that there should be a public hearing. This was disputed by the Labor members of the committee. We then went back and sought to better gauge the feeling of the chamber. It was very clear that the feeling of the chamber was that we should proceed, as we generally do with many of these references, to a public hearing. Having raised this matter again with the committee, Senator Coates then exercised a casting vote to prevent a public hearing occurring.

I have to say to you, Mr Deputy President, that I regard this as a quite improper use of the casting vote, particularly in this case where we had sought the feeling of the chamber. I think this highlights one of the major problems we have with the committee system at present in that the chairmen of committees are in virtually all circumstances, with a very few distinguished exceptions such as Senator Watson, from the government side of the chamber.

It is my view that the Senate should look very closely at what happened in this particular circumstance. Flowing from a perfectly reasonable request and following proper procedures, the government attempted to muzzle the inquiry through Senator Coates. I have to say that in general Senator Coates attempts to conduct himself according to normal, tried procedures. But in this case I believe a fundamental error was made and Senator Coates by his casting vote prevented the committee conducting a public inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that is allowed under standing orders.

—That is quite right, but I suggest to Senator Schacht that this raises the wider issue. It was the feeling of the majority in this chamber that we should proceed to a hearing and there was an attempt by the Labor members of the committee to veto this. I suggest to you, Mr Deputy President, that the Senate will have to look very closely at what happened on this occasion and see whether, as I believe, some sensible changes should not be made to the committee system to better reflect the numbers in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I strongly support the view that now that this report has been brought down, the Senate should give a further instruction to the committee to do the work that it should have done in the first place and conduct a public hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.
—At the conclusion of the debate.
—Order! It is quite in order at the conclusion of a speech for a senator to seek the call of the chair if they claim to have been misrepresented. The honourable senator may proceed.

—Senator Kemp claims that I used my casting vote at the committee to prevent a public hearing in this matter, which is not so. There was a motion that the report as drafted be tabled. There was an amendment to the effect that there be a public hearing before that happened. The voting on that matter was equal and therefore was negated. The motion to table the report was then put and carried. It was on that motion that I used the casting vote, as is the normal process in committees and as provided in standing orders. Otherwise there would have been no decision.
—Who got to you?

—Nobody got to me, Senator McGauran. In view of that interjection, I think I need to quickly read to the chamber the letter that I wrote to Senator Watson when this matter first arose to put the exact position.
—Senator Coates, does it go directly to the matter?
—It goes absolutely directly to the matter, in defence of Senator Kemp's accusation that I misused my position on the committee. My letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing following the consideration of the Committee's Metway reference at our meeting this morning. As you know, I provided a draft report to all Committee members on 9 June. That draft canvassed all the relevant issues thoroughly and I had hoped that the committee would have settled the report today so that it could be tabled in the Senate as soon as any dissent could be prepared, preferably next week.
I interpose that there is a brief minority report on the question of a public hearing rather than on the substantive issues of the report. The letter continues:

I confirm that the Committee decided, however, to authorise you to inform certain senators and other relevant people that the Government majority is proposing that the Committee report to the Senate on the basis of the written submissions without also taking oral evidence. As the Committee did not decide to make any public statement, I believe your information must be provided only on a confidential basis.

There is no obligation on a committee to take oral evidence if the written submissions are sufficient. You and your colleagues agree with me on this point but do not accept my very strong contention that, in this particular case, a public hearing is unnecessary and highly inappropriate for the following reasons.

Firstly, the written submissions provided all the information needed to reach conclusions on the terms of reference. Secondly, the matters which Metway would wish to raise at a public hearing are substantially questions of law and of state government policy. The legal questions have now been decided in the Supreme Court of Queensland. At the time the reference was moved, its proponents were hoping that the outcome of the dispute could be influenced by a Senate committee inquiry, but the Queensland Government and Parliament took irrevocable action immediately after the Court decision which has brought the matter to a conclusion.

As the Court determined, the matters in dispute were within the powers and responsibility of the Queensland Government and Parliament to resolve. To the extent that they raised issues which were relevant to the Australian Parliament, a hearing would add nothing to the authoritative written evidence from the Treasury and the Reserve Bank which is discussed in my draft report. It would be wrong for the Federal Parliament to involve itself in a dispute such as this, especially as it has now been settled within the state in question.

I acknowledge that Metway might wish to take every possible opportunity to publicise its complaint against the Queensland Government. However, I believe that to hold a hearing for this purpose would be a misuse of the Committee and would incur costs which could not be justified. As you are well aware, we are already having difficulty finding the time and staff resources to deal with inquiries on matters which are undisputed responsibilities of the Federal Parliament.

That is the letter I wrote to Senator Watson. I very strongly believe that it would be a misuse of the committee to involve ourselves in a matter which is entirely a Queensland government and parliament matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coates, I think, with the generosity which comes with my soul, you are justifying your position rather than dealing with the matter raised by Senator Kemp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The important part of this report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is the minority report. That minority report recommends that the Senate refer this matter back to the committee with a direction that it hold a public hearing and report again on the important issues that were referred to it for inquiry and report.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coates has not addressed why the committee should not test the evidence. That is an appropriate role for the committee—testing the evidence as presented in the various submissions. By using his casting vote, the chairman voted to veto that very democratic right of the committee to test the evidence. So we are asking this Senate to refer this matter back to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which Senator Coates chairs, and for that committee to test the evidence as presented to it. Otherwise, we will be left with a slanted report, such as the majority report—a report concocted only because the chairman used his casting vote.

This issue has a lot of ramifications for the Senate. We will recall that the reference proposed by our colleague, Senator Parer of Queensland, supported by Senator Kernot of the Australian Democrats, related to action by the Commonwealth government in confiscating moneys which were the property of the Metway Bank. This is a very serious issue which has not only local ramifications but national ramifications.
Mr Deputy President, let me remind you of comments made by one noted Queensland investment adviser who writes prolifically on investment issues. Austin Donnelly said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is no business or moral justification for the attitude of the [Queensland] government. The government claims to be interested in open and fair government and in good financial management of the resources of the state. Its attitude in this manner is completely at variance with those standards.

It is true that the court was asked to rule on the legality of a decision taken by the parliament. That was quite a simple term of reference. The issues that we are addressing are far wider than that—the implications of the decision by the Goss government to confiscate moneys. We are talking about $20 million—a very significant amount of money. What are the implications of this decision? Let us go through them.

PARA.TAB: This matter involves the disenfranchisement of the Metropolitan Permanent Building Society's customers and shareholders. It involves the discrimination against a nationally licensed bank in favour of its competitors, including a state government-owned institution. It involves a clear identification of the Metropolitan Permanent Building Society and the Metway Bank as one institution, which was enshrined in the banking authority and the banking licence; it is one and the same body.

It is no use trying to convince honourable senators that that government took the money away not from Metway Bank but from the building society, because they are one and the same institution. This is in their banking authority and in their banking licence. Because it is in their banking licence, this Senate has the authority to conduct this inquiry to test the evidence in open public hearings.

What else is involved? A clear conflict of interest has been displayed by the Queensland government in using Metway's contributions to fund the supervision of its competitors, including the government-owned Suncorp Building Society. There has been a total denial of natural justice to Metway in terms of the government's refusal, through the chairman of this committee, to have a full, open and public scrutiny. That is really what the problem is.
The Reserve Bank even suggests that the Metropolitan Permanent Building Society was incorporated as a building society under section 122A of the Queensland Building Societies Act enabling:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the building society to convert to public companies for the purpose of carrying on a business banking licence under the Banking Act.
Section 122B provides further that when a building society converts to a public company it retains its legal identity.

That comes from none other an authority than Mr Bernie Fraser. Everywhere we look we see conclusive arguments of the need for the evidence to be tested in a public open hearing. That is what we require—nothing short of that, nothing less. I think it is a reflection on the Senate committee system that any chair in this place should have acted in this manner. There is provision for committees not to hold public hearings in cases where something is obvious—but it is not obvious in this instance.

PARA.TAB: I put to the Senate that, for the various reasons I have submitted, what we have to do is ask Senator Parer to move, and Senator Kernot to second, a motion to make sure that this matter is referred back to the committee for appropriate scrutiny. I put it to you, Mr Deputy President: is it not reasonable that we should take this particular approach? I think the issues are particularly important. The Liberal-National party members have believed from the beginning of this inquiry that the issues which flowed from the decision of the Queensland government to pay moneys collected from a major non-banking financial institution to its competitors, including a wholly owned one of the Queensland government, should be dealt with at public hearings. A lot of the people who put in submissions did so in the belief that they would be called to give oral evidence to amplify and support what they had already said.

TALK.START.PARA: —So did the movers of the motion.

—As Senator Parer has just said, so did the movers of the motion. I remind honourable senators that the majority report is really based on a limited number of written submissions, some of which, as I say, appear to have been written on the assumption that they could have been amplified by an oral presentation at a public hearing. This is why we are calling for such an inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The Queensland government, which we say has a central involvement, has declined to provide any information. So it is not possible for the committee, as such, to reach conclusions on important issues raised in the reference until it has heard oral evidence from the main party to the dispute and from others who have had first-hand knowledge about the facts and the issues. The fact that the Queensland government does not want to put in a submission or does not want to have anything to do with it does not really matter. I think that is all the more reason why this Senate should conduct a far-reaching wide inquiry to test the evidence.

Senator Barney Cooney could not disagree with the concept of Senate committees testing the evidence. He is a lawyer. The issues clearly are within the scope of the Senate committee, given the Commonwealth's constitutional jurisdiction over banking and its role in regulating both banking and non-bank financial institutions.

Even if the decision of the Queensland government in the Metway case were within its proper powers, the important thing is that that decision will have far wider implications, extending well beyond the borders of Queensland, which justify a Senate committee. The case involving the confiscation of moneys of depositors and shareholders, in this instance to the extent of $20 million, raises doubts about the propriety of governments in this country.

The actions of the Queensland government raise serious questions about the adequacy of the mechanisms to maintain the rights of clients and shareholders in non-bank financial institutions. It is appropriate for the Senate committee to review all these issues fully. I call upon the Senate to ensure that this matter is referred back to the committee to ensure that the evidence can be tested in an open public inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, am a member of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. The remarks I want to put on the record are specifically in relation to the holding of a public hearing. I agree with the chairman of the committee, Senator Coates, that not on all occasions are public hearings demanded whenever a matter is required to go before a Senate committee. There are some matters which do naturally lend themselves to dealing with evidence given in writing. However, I have to say—being relatively inexperienced in these matters—that where there is a broad community of people virtually demanding to give evidence orally and physically before a Senate committee, and where there is a matter such as this which is controversial, quite often it is impossible to judge the merits of arguments which are put in simply in report form or letter form.

PARA.TAB: Regarding the Metway matter, for many months I have felt that a lot of the conflict and crisis that we are having in the Senate chamber today would be solved if we were to hold a hearing in Queensland, the home of the people who have been affected by this decision of the courts and now of the Queensland government. That would enable those people to have their day in court in front of the Senate committee. I would suggest that Senator Coates and the Labor members of the committee have political reasons for not wanting to embarrass the Queensland government—which, of course, is a Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all.
—I take it, Senator Coates, that you have no political motives whatever in this area.
—I am defending the Senate committee system.
—That prompts me to go on to one other thing Senator Coates was defending in discussions on this issue. I refer to Senator Coates's strong defence of states rights—
—It is amusing, yes.
—It is very amusing for me, and I am an avid defender of states rights.
—It just shows you how objective I can be.

—I have never hidden that fact. In fact, I tended to agree with Senator Chris Evans's speech in that I do not defend states rights just because States by themselves are a good thing. I think that often in the history of man states have tended to be bad things and have tended to subjugate individual rights. But I believe that wherever possible we should get decision making as close to the people as possible. Within our federation, states are closer to the people than the federal government, and local government is even closer. Indeed, community action groups are even closer than local governments.

PARA.TAB: I think that where there is an overwhelming demand by the local community to have a say and to put evidence before a Senate committee, this committee has an obligation to make a public hearing available. I believe this is even more the case when the committee system is a part of the Senate and when formal soundings were taken of the views of both the Democrats and the coalition in relation to whether a public hearing should be held. Those views were put back to the committee through the deputy chairman, Senator Watson, and they were very clearly to the effect that a public hearing should be held. To continue to say, `No, we shall not have a public hearing, we will go back to the Senate and will have a fight in the Senate chamber'—a fight we are now having this afternoon—is tantamount to a Senate committee snubbing its nose at the Senate and its view.

We are here this afternoon and we will have this little debate and all of the views will have been put. Of course, there will be a reference back to the Senate committee and we will be told by the Senate to hold a public hearing in Queensland. Little will have been achieved except for this fight that we have had in the Senate this afternoon.

I think that in general the principle should be that we cannot bend over whenever a noisy interest group says, `We want your Senate committee up here so that we can create a platform to put all our views forward'. But clearly from the evidence put before this committee in the Metway hearings, some very sound, well-based views were put before the committee by some solid citizens of the community of Queensland and also by some solid corporate citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you read the court's judgment?
—I have read it, and I do not think that it is impinging on the Queensland government or the state if the Senate plays its role in holding a public hearing. I support what Senator Watson said.

PARA.TAB: I looked at this matter very carefully because I had reservations about whether we should have a public hearing. Indeed, for many months I had reservations as to whether we should even be inquiring into this matter. Senator West will probably attest to my credentials because I refused to take evidence in the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts hearing on sport in schools. I thought that sport in schools was purely a matter for state governments and for the schools. I refused to attend any of the hearings because I thought that it was not a matter in which the Commonwealth should have any role whatsoever. I had to look very carefully at this Metway inquiry because I shared some of Senator Coates's strong states rights views on this matter.

On balance, I think that what Senator Watson is advocating is correct. The Senate does have a role in this inquiry. I do not think the inquiry can properly be completed to the satisfaction of many of the constituents of this Senate and the Australian people unless there is a public hearing held in Queensland to finalise the evidence. As Senator Watson quite rightly says, there should be a testing of the evidence in a public Senate hearing, with all the privileges that attach to it.

I support Senator Watson's comments and commend that the Senate refer this matter back to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and hold what could be a brief hearing—it does not need to take more than a day—in Queensland so that the stakeholders in this decision have a chance to put their views on the evidence they have submitted in writing to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. Senator Campbell has just made some reasonable points. He said that he was not in agreement with all matters going to a public hearing, which of course is a position that we take. Essentially he was saying that it is a matter for judgment. What has been demonstrated here today is that there clearly is a difference of opinion on what ultimately is a matter for judgment.

PARA.TAB: The conservative members of the Senate took the view that this matter should go to public hearing; the Labor members said that it should not. In essence, that is the point. I think that for Senator Watson to suggest that there has been some impropriety by the committee's chairman—that there has been a concocting of a report, which is what he said—is totally wrong, and I take some offence at that.

In all the meetings in which I have participated Senator Coates has acted with the utmost courtesy and consideration for the views of the other members of the committee. At all times he has sought to involve members in proper discussions. In my experience, he has taken his responsibilities very seriously. He did not misuse his vote. On the question of the amendment, the motion was lost because it was a tied vote. He used his casting vote on whether or not the report should be tabled in this chamber. If he had not, there would be no report at all; no decision would have been made.

In essence, we are talking about the proper use of the chairman's vote, not the improper use, as has been stated by Senator Watson, who said that there had been a concocting of a report. I think that is totally wrong. Senator Coates wrote to all members of the committee and pointed out that there were a number of sound reasons for the decisions that had been taken in terms of the fact that the written submissions had provided all the necessary material. As Senator Campbell indicated, it is possible for that process to legitimately take place. In Senator Coates's view—which I accept—all the necessary material was before the committee: the matters of law had been determined by the courts in Queensland; the whole process had demonstrated that the use-by date for this inquiry had expired; and, finally, the Queensland government had taken actions because, essentially, this was a matter for the Queensland government to resolve.

I am a bit of an angler and I enjoy a bit of fishing but it is reaching the point where we are finding requests for fishing expeditions being made almost on a daily basis. In this place, I suggest we probably have better things to do—such as passing a few pieces of legislation and occasionally addressing some of the problems confronting the people of this country—than engage in these politically motivated fishing expeditions which are in fact a misuse of the Senate committee system. I suggest that some people, unlike Senator Coates, are not acting entirely with clean hands in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the remarks made by my colleagues, I wish to move an amendment to the motion to take note of the report. I move:

PARA.TAB: At the end of motion, add—

SPEECH.PARA: ``, but in view of the fact that the committee chose not to hold any public meetings prior to finalising its report:
(a)the report be referred back to the Finance and Public Administration Committee for reconsideration and report to the Senate on or before 28 September 1993; and

(b)in reconsidering the report, the committee shall hold at least one public hearing for the purpose of testing, with the assistance of oral evidence from relevant witnesses, the integrity and adequacy of the written evidence on which the committee based its report''.

I was the mover of the motion to hold a public hearing, supported by Senator Kernot, the Leader of the Australian Democrats. It was our expectation that when the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration heard this matter, it would not only take written submissions but also have a public hearing. In his remarks, Senator Coates said that it was a `misuse of the Senate'. Quite clearly, it was not a misuse of the Senate. When this motion was passed we had a reporting date of the end of the budget sittings of 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said it would have been a misuse of the committee.

—I accept that. Senator Coates came to see me and Senator Kernot and said that because of the workload of the committee this was a bit tight, but he gave us his assurance that the inquiry would occur in an expeditious way. A remark was also made and, of course, this did not happen. Now Senator Coates explained this by saying that as this matter was before the court, it could prejudice the outcome of the court proceedings. We received advice on that from the clerks, who indicated that in no way could that happen.

PARA.TAB: Frankly, in view of the fact that Senator Kernot and I both advised Senator Watson, following a suggestion by the chairman that he approach us, that there should be a public hearing, and then his use of his casting vote to prevent that from happening is really an abuse of the committee system.

This matter raises with me—and I am sure it raises it with other senators in this place following the election—the question as to whether the committees of the Senate should not more adequately reflect the numbers in the Senate. In the past, the government was able to steamroll things through this place. Well, let me let it know that it cannot do so any more.

The reason this matter was referred to the committee, as has been clearly outlined by Senator Watson, is the implications of what happened. The fund that is referred to was established in 1985 to protect building society members following the collapse of the Queensland Permanent Building Society. All building societies made compulsory contributions. This included the then Metropolitan Permanent Building Society, which became Metway Bank on 30 June 1988, by which time the total contribution by the then Metway Bank was $17 million. The question arose: was it or was it not the same entity? Quite clearly, it was the same entity. I think this was also the conclusion reached by Senator Coates. There is no dispute about whether or not it was the same entity. The Queensland government then decided to snatch this money away, and, in the view of Metway and its shareholders, it was the equivalent of pilfering money which belonged to the shareholders of the bank.

Senator Coates made great play about the court decision. All the court decision did was reaffirm, quite naturally, that governments can legislate to do what they like. That is exactly what the Queensland government did. There is no doubt whatsoever in my mind and in the minds of others that it was expected that the people who made written submissions, particularly those who were more closely affected by this outrageous decision by the Queensland government, would be given the opportunity to present evidence at a public hearing. I do not dispute the fact that in many cases written submissions themselves suffice. But the expectation was there that those people would be given the opportunity to enlarge on the written submission which they gave.

I am concerned about this quite deliberate action by the chairman of the committee, with the support of his Labor colleagues, to prevent a public hearing. It raises the question: why has he done that? It is not just simply a workload. No-one will swallow that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of principle. That is what I explained, if you wanted to listen.

—Senator Coates has introduced an interesting matter of principle. Because this Senate decides to refer something to a committee, he decides that he will determine as a matter of principle that there should not be a public hearing. That is the sort of blatant arrogance we have come to expect from this government. It is the sort of thing we expect in the other place from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), but not in this chamber. I can tell Senator Coates that there is no way in the world this chamber will allow that sort of behaviour to occur again.

—I am a bit saddened by some of the comments that have been made by speakers from the other side, especially Senator Parer, accusing me of all this wrongdoing. I guess the thing that saddens me is that he obviously did not listen to what I said in the first place when explaining—
—How much did you listen to him?

—I was listening; that is why I need to, once again, remind Senator Parer of the sorts of arguments that I put before. First, there was no casting vote used on the question of a public hearing. The committee was evenly divided and it was therefore in the negative.
—That was the effect of it.
—No. There was no decision on that because it was negatived.
—The effect of it was to do precisely that.

—I used my casting vote on the motion to table the report. If I had not used my casting vote at that point, once again the vote would have been three all, there would have been no report and we would have been left in limbo.

PARA.TAB: There was no use of the casting vote on the question of a public hearing, but I agree that it is a side issue. I am happy to argue it on what I regard as a matter of principle—that I genuinely believed it was inappropriate for us to have the public hearing or to explore the matters beyond the terms of reference. I thought that the committee members accepted the genuineness of my position on that matter, accepted that we had a difference of view and that was that.

The main point about getting the thing tabled and over with, and not exploring at a public hearing matters which are beyond the responsibility of the Commonwealth, is to be very strong about the fact that we are not here to review each and every decision of state governments on state matters that we happen to disagree with. We have enough to do at the Commonwealth level in looking after Commonwealth matters—matters which this parliament is responsible for—without going after everything that we happen to disagree with at a state level.

I could say, `Let's have an inquiry into some Tasmanian government decision' or some appalling things that the legislative council in Tasmania does, but it would be misusing the Senate and its committees. I very strongly believe that. That is why I went to the extent of not just saying, `Well, all right, we'll have a public hearing' because I thought it would have been wrong to do so.

The matters where we did have a Commonwealth interest were very clear-cut and easily dealt with by the written submissions. As I acknowledged in my earlier remarks, I know that Metway wants to continue to jump up and down about it, but we are not here to provide that sort of forum in a matter which is not our responsibility.
I need to respond to another of Senator Parer's remarks. I did not argue that the court's hearing would be prejudiced by our having a—

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you say that earlier?

—No. I said that we decided it was inappropriate to be holding a hearing while it was being dealt with in another forum. I was not claiming the question of prejudice of an appeal court because of our hearing. I thought it was appropriate to do things one step at a time. Metway had its day in court where it was appropriate that the legal issues it wanted to raise be settled, and it is not for us to review that.

PARA.TAB: On the question of how expeditiously we dealt with it, I remember our discussions last December when we agreed that it was inappropriate to have a firm, very early reporting date because of all the other things that were on our plate. I agreed that we would get the matter under way by mid-December. In fact, it was something like 6 December that I wrote off the letters seeking the submissions. So there was no delay or attempt to delay the matter getting under way.

Finally, I should point out that, as far as the proposal that we waste the time of the committee dealing with the matter again is concerned, the issue is very much all over. Not only has there been the court decision, but immediately after the court decision the Queensland government moved in the Queensland parliament, and the Queensland parliament passed the necessary legislation, for the funds which had been frozen temporarily to be passed in the way in which it was proposed that they be passed. So it is too late for any action anyway, even if it could be argued that there should have been the slightest involvement by the Commonwealth.

It is not acceptable for us to have a public hearing. I strongly oppose that. However, I understand that the Australian Democrats propose to vote for Senator Parer's amendment so I will not waste time by calling a division on the matter. I guess we will have to accept that, inappropriate as I strongly believe it is, the amendment will be carried and the matter will be referred back to the committee.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the cost of justice entitled Checks and Imbalances.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs deals with the cost of justice in the context of the part played in the legal system by parliament, the executive parliament and the ministry. In the course of looking at that, it deals with the relationship that exists between the parliament and the executive. It says, amongst other things—I will not go deeply into it—that that relationship between the executive and parliament must be looked at to make sense of it in terms of the party system, because it is through the party system that the executive, on the one hand, or the shadow executive, on the other, play their part.

PARA.TAB: As it says at the beginning, this report was prepared prior to 30 June this year. Paragraph 1.20 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Commonwealth sphere, Government is formed on the basis of the support of a majority of members of a single House of Parliament—the House of Representatives. A particular party gains government at a democratic election when a majority of the members elected to the House of Representatives are chosen from that particular party. Australian voters by and large vote for the party rather than the candidate as an individual. Hence the party which gains the majority and forms government has an extraordinary capacity to influence and discipline its members. Its members are also keen in their own right to see their party maintain executive power. Consequently the Executive has, with rare exceptions, been able to impose its will on the House of Representatives.
The final sentence of that paragraph states:
However, the Executive has not always had such success in controlling the Senate.
We are looking at an example of that—and it might not be an unreasonable one—in the present situation in this place. The report goes on to say:

The processes used by the Executive, the Party Room from which it is drawn, and the Parliamentary Committees of that Party, to prepare and refine legislation are of great importance to the fairness, efficiency and cost of the legal system. It is right and proper that those processes should, as far as practicable, be open to public scrutiny.

I think the way this place works and the effect that has on legislation can be better understood if the party system is seen in the light that it casts. The committee went on to recommend that more support should be given by government—I use the word `government' in the sense of the executive and parliament—to the party system in parliament. I think that legislation would be much improved if the committees of the parties, as distinct from the parliament, could be given more support and more resources. Oftentimes the executive of any particular party has the ability to put legislation before the party room but the party room has insufficient resources to deal with that legislation as well as it might.

PARA.TAB: The report also says that the parliamentary system—even though the executive has such a vital influence, and properly so, on our system—needs to be strengthened. There is a quote in the report from Mr Justice Brennan of the High Court of Australia—taken not from one of his judgments but from a speech he gave at the 1990 Blackburn memorial lecture—in which he dealt with that point.

A reading of the report will show that parliament would work better by being given more resources. I do not necessarily mean that money and personnel should be given simply to a particular party or parliamentary committee. I mean that the level of the ability of the personnel made available to the parties in parliamentary committees should be as high as possible. I hasten to add that I do not mean by that statement that the people who look after our committees and look after us in parliament are not of outstanding ability. All I am saying is that there should perhaps be more of them.

I go on to deal with the selection of judges which has been of some interest in recent times. The point to be made here is that the judges themselves have received some criticism, but it is the executive that appoints the judges. Paragraphs 128 and 129 of the report state:

It is an unquestioned principle that judges should be independent. It is essential that those who go to court have confidence in the independence of their judges from governmental, political or other community pressures. In addition, it is essential that litigants see those who judge them or their cases as having acted impartially, fairly, courteously and competently.
It is similarly an unquestioned principle that judges ought to be highly competent. These are matters for the Executive, which bears sole responsibility for the appointment of judges.

SPEECH.PARA: That is so. Under the Commonwealth constitution it is for the Governor-General in Council to appoint judges. In effect, that means that it is for the executive, and in particular the Attorney-General, to appoint judges. The committee believes that even though that is the process set down in the constitution, it would be consistent with that position for the process by which judges are appointed to be made more open than is presently the case. That is one of its recommendations.

PARA.TAB: The report deals with primary and subordinate legislation and makes points that have been made before. They have been made before because they are true. Legislation, whether from parliament or from some body that makes subordinate legislation, ought to be clear to the people who have to obey it. After all, if we are going to obey the law it is something of an advantage to know what the law says.

Also, legislation should be as succinct as possible and only made when it is needed. There is a tendency for parliamentarians to get up and either pass or propose legislation as a means of exhibiting the trade that we are in. I suppose everyone is subject to some problems with his trade. Lawyers like to go to court and doctors like to go to the operating theatre because that is what they do. I think parliamentarians like to legislate—and a good thing too—but perhaps we sometimes—

TALK.START.PARA: —If we ever get to legislation!
—That is right; that is a very good point. It is always worth while asking whether we are legislating at a proper level and at a proper rate.
—Very slow.
—It is very slow, but that is the process of the Senate.
—Democratic process.

—Senator Panizza says that that is the democratic process and that is true. On the other hand, Senator Panizza would not want to use the statement that it is a democrat process to hold up legislation that is essential to the welfare of the country. It would be a bad thing, in my view, if legislation that was needed for the country was not passed and the country suffered as a result. For example, if the country suffered because of not getting the budget through, whilst the democratic process was operating, the good people of Australia might say, `Have all these great people in the Senate over the other side, such as Senator Patterson'—these people who they know love them so much—
—Depends which budget they are trying to put through.
—They might say that Senator Patterson might be not adjusting the proper balance in refusing to pass legislation which is needed to see that things are properly run and properly done for Australia.
—They will change their attitude if they ever get back into government.

—That is right. We cannot argue with that. It is clear that the way things look from the government benches is different from the way things look from the opposition benches. That is a matter of balance. I am wandering from my point.
—You are doing very well; you are still on track.
—It is a very interesting contribution nonetheless.

—I thank Senator Evans. The next point I want to raise is court fees and charges. Senator Spindler dissented on this and he will no doubt address the chamber at a later time. In my view, courts should be available to all parties and people should not be penalised by way of costs when they want to use the courts. In my view, it is a fundamental obligation of government to provide courts. Again, I use the word `government' in the wider sense. People, whether they be corporations, trade unions, medical associations or anybody else should have access to the courts and should not be penalised at different rates for using them.

PARA.TAB: I will leave it at that, except to thank all the members of the committee who contributed to this report. Their names are set out on the frontispiece of the report. I pay tribute to Senator Vanstone, the deputy chair, who did a great deal of work and showed a great deal of patience, which is in contrast to the way she sometimes acts in this chamber. May I say that when she does not show patience, it is only in the best interests of the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is warranted.

—Well put, Senator Patterson. Senator Chris Evans, who is on my left, will make a great contribution to this committee. We should pay special tribute to Senator Giles because she was a magnificent senator and her departure is a great loss to this chamber. Fortunately, Senator Chris Evans, in a different way, has made up for our considerable loss. Senator Kemp—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am saying some nice things about Senator Kemp. Can everybody restrain themselves while I say something nice about Senator Kemp? He has left the committee. I say publicly that I am a bit disappointed that Senator Kemp has left this committee; he should not have done so.
—Are you sure about that?

—Yes, I am. I publicly thank him for the work he did; it was great. Senator Julian McGauran was on the committee for a fortnight and made an outstanding contribution. I should not pass over Jim McKiernan without paying tribute to him. Senator Graham Maguire has left; again that is a loss not only to this committee but to the chamber. When Senator O'Chee is here—tremendous. Senator Reynolds has become a member of the committee and is doing a great deal of good work for us. Senator Sid Spindler is not here, but I thank him. Last but not least is Senator Peter Walsh, who had plenty to say as a member of this committee.
—I bet he did.
—Senator Patterson is right; he had a great deal to say. I also thank the committee secretary, Paul Griffiths—
—You had a lot of members on that committee.

—Yes, they come and go. Whenever they come they do great jobs and whenever they go we thank them. I thank the research staff—James Warmenhoven, Virginia Buring who has been with us since 12 July 1993, and Paul Palisi. I thank the executive assistant, Angela Misic, who has also come and is about to go.
—Does this say something for your chairing, Barney?

—It might say something about my chairing. I think Senator Vanstone will make the point that this is a very important report. I would like to hear everybody in this chamber say a word on it—not now, later on. I thank members of the committee and I thank the executive.

—I endorse the remarks made by Senator Cooney. I say that not only because I do endorse them but because it will save me going through the litany of people who have served on this committee for extended or limited periods of time. Senator Cooney is right when he says that he hopes every member of parliament looks at this report. From other committees that I have served on, I know that when we have been involved in something and have put a considerable degree of work into it, ego can lead us to believe that everyone, if they had the time, would find the report fascinating. That is not the case here in that, while I do believe people will find the report fascinating, it is not because it is something that I have spent a large amount of time on—as Senator Cooney and others have—but because The Cost of Justice second report has something to say about the involvement that every one of us has in increasing the cost of justice.

PARA.TAB: It is all too easy for parliamentarians to take a free kick against the legal profession on radio and in the media. It is easy to have a crack at a lawyer. We could not find an easier ride into the media. If we ring them up and say we want to get stuck into the legal profession, we will be on radio for sure, because it is so easy to say, `People cannot afford to use the courts. It is all those lawyers. They all drive Mercedes; they all have big houses; they all overcharge; and they are all crooks'. Of course, that is simply not true. The legal profession does have a role to play in reducing the cost of, and increasing access to, justice. But sometimes it is very easy for us to neglect to look at the impact we have on increasing that cost.

I refer to the table on page 18 of the second chapter of this report. We cannot judge the complexity of something simply by its length. In fact, I think when we put the Social Security Act into plain English it became longer, but it did become more comprehensible. So I do not say that size alone is an indicator of complexity and therefore cost. But it is of some interest to note that, in 1980, 177 acts were passed with a total of 1,860 pages. In 1991, we passed 216 acts—not a very big increase—but with a total of 6,905 pages.

What if there is a similar increase in delegated legislation? My colleague Senator Patterson would be interested in this as she has served for a long time on one of this chamber's delegated legislation committees. The 1,199 pages of delegated legislation in 1980 increased to 3,144 pages in 1991. This massive, exponential increase in legislation makes access to the law much more difficult for someone who does not have the capacity to go to the government bookshop and buy the relevant legislation and read it all themselves—the nightmare that that is, even for the legal profession. It does restrict their access. Those who do not have that capacity have to pay someone to do it. No-one expects the legal profession to be good Samaritans and do this work for nothing.

We sit here saying, `This is very important; we need this amendment; we need this act of parliament' and then we just toss it on to the pile of complex legislation. We somehow imagine that it will be easy to put into practice, that it will be easy for people to operate with that legislation at a minimal cost. Every time we add to the pile, we add to the cost of implementing that legislation, to the cost of complying with it and therefore to the cost of and access to justice. We could do well to pay significant attention to this report if only to look at chapter 2.

Senator Cooney paid significant attention in his very well considered speech to chapter 1. That is the chapter which I would recommend members and senators pay significant attention to. In short, it says this: the theory may be that parliament keeps a check on the executive, but the resources are such that the executive holds nearly all the cards in the deck. Someone may say, `So what? It has been like that for a long time'. We say that it is getting worse.

If we actually believe in the parliamentary system, if we think parliament is meant to be here to keep a check on the executive, and if we realise that parliament is under-resourced, then we should not be embarrassed about saying that parliament needs more money and more resources to do its job properly. Surely that is what the system is about.

When people elect you, Mr Acting Deputy President, me, and members of the Senate and House of Representatives, it is not just a contest to see who will become the executive and then, `All over red rover, everyone go home'. If that were the case, firstly, we would have a unicameral system and, secondly, the party that formed a majority would simply form an executive government. Everyone else could say, `Bad luck, you entered the contest but your team did not get enough players, so you are out'. We would not bother having an opposition; we would not bother having Greens and Democrats and Independents. We cannot bring ourselves to say that because we do not want that to be the case. We want there to be a healthy opposition and a range of parties keeping a check on the executive. If we believe that, then we have to resource it properly.

If senators and members care to reflect on the first chapter in this report, they will see what may look to some like pretty boring reading, but it goes right to the heart of what our task is all about.

The third chapter in this report deals with court funding. After all, we are responsible for that in the end. The judiciary wants its independence. It is entitled to it. That is the system we need. Nonetheless, it needs enough money. As the population rises, more people find themselves in a position where they need to go to the Family Court or the AAT and they should not have to wait weeks and weeks. The courts should not be jam-packed, lousy, tatty backroom offices, because that is what they are. That is where people go to get some adjudication as to whether the laws of this nation have been followed properly in their favour or otherwise.

In the nine years that I have been here, I have not heard—I say this to my own embarrassment because I could have raised it—a really shebang debate on court funding. Yet the courts are the administrators, if you like, of the system that we produce. We seem to dish them out a bit of money, give them a little bit of an increase here and there and think that we can leave it at that.

Court fees and charges are dealt with and that is also worth looking at. By and large, a lot of court fees and charges cannot be put up without our approval, although a lot of those changes need to be made. They may be made by instruments that are tabled and perhaps not brought to our attention. An example has been raised—in the end, I think it got left in this report—of changes to the Family Court rules requiring pleadings to be reintroduced. That went through here without a whisper.

The Family Court practitioners came to us and said, `This is massively increasing the costs for our clients. If we have to plead things properly, it means we've got to cover every option and that, of course, is something we have to charge for'. What do we find now? We find that the Chief Justice of the Family Court has announced that the Family Court will start to do something about that, if it has not already in practice. We all sit here and get paid to do our job, but it just slipped through and increased the cost of justice to people who needed courts for perhaps the most unsatisfactory of reasons; namely, that their marriage had broken down and they were no longer able to resolve the dispute between themselves.

A very particular aspect of court fees and charges is worth mentioning and that is transcript charges. I cannot put my finger on an example that was raised, but I will run it from memory to give an example. I am sure it is in this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —One dollar a page in the IR Commission.
—I think the Commonwealth charges about $7.50—it might be $9.50—a page.
—Seven dollars and 50 cents a page?

—There may be a couple of hundred pages in a day. If you have a three-day hearing, then an adjournment and you want to come back to it a couple of weeks later, and you want your barrister to have access to the transcript, you have to pay for it. What is worse than that is that the judges have to pay for it. The Family Court judges do not get a transcript sent up from down below; that comes out of the Family Court allocation and goes to Auscript.

PARA.TAB: There are, quite frankly, thousands of black market copies of transcripts all over the country. It is a shameful situation. Judges will ring up practitioners and say, `Did you get a transcript? Do you think you could sheet feed it and give us a copy'. Obviously, a copy would be 5c a page. On other occasions the judge might ring that practitioner up and say, `I've got a transcript. Would you like a copy? I'll sheet feed it through my photocopier'. People should not have to shillyshally around like that because we are so stupid in the way that we run our courts and the transcript charges.

The example that I was looking for was where a company said it could do the job for $4 a page and all of a sudden we found that Auscript was also able to do it for $4 a page. Then this company offered $3 a page, and Auscript still does it. The reason it still does it, as we understand it, is that there was going to be a mass walk-out by Auscript. In any event, the paragraph that I just cannot put my finger on will highlight this example to show that there should be competition for the provision of transcripts in courts. That is the only way we will get the price down.

Senator Sherry was surprised at the figure of $7.50; I think it is $9.50. I am sure everyone understands the consequences of leaving those charges at that level. It is just robbing Peter to pay Paul. We appropriate money to the Family Court so that it can give it to Auscript. It is just dancing around paying some money to people when we should be letting that out to private enterprise.

I cannot recommend strongly enough that members of this place read this report. Firstly, they will appreciate the good work that has been done, and the warning signals that we all experience every day as to parliament being under-funded to keep a check on the executive; and secondly, they will realise the impact that we have every day in increasing the cost of justice and reducing access to it for Australian citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the proposed treatment of unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities under the income test for pensioners.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to present this report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs on issues relating to the treatment of unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income for pensioners. I would hasten to add that it has not been delayed in its presentation to this chamber in any way at all. If honourable senators look at the Notice Paper, they will see that it is coming on at the time that it is supposed to be coming on, and the fact that we have done no legislation today is another matter.

PARA.TAB: The report is that of a majority of the committee and a dissenting report is included. That has already been alluded to in a motion to take note of a question.

The committee has decided to make a short report on this matter because it considers that it is important to advise government and the community of its findings as quickly as possible, given the planned commencement dates for this measure. It may be that the committee will wish to make a fuller report at a later date.

The committee received this reference on 27 May 1993 and was due to report on 18 August. It sought an extension of time to 1 September in order to take evidence from key departments and organisations on 20 August. The committee received 174 submissions and nearly 2,000 letters, all of which have been taken into consideration in the preparation of this report. Public hearings were held in four cities on 9, 10, 11 and 20 August, during which evidence was taken from 77 witnesses.

A wide range of issues was canvassed through both written and oral evidence. These included the different needs of pensioners; the reasons why people purchased and retained shares; the use by pensioners of share dividends and the extent to which this income reduced dependence on the pension; the perceived problems with the method of calculating a rate of return on share investments; and the benefits or otherwise of the provisions for offsetting gains and losses.

We also heard evidence on the possible disadvantages of measures for people with smaller parcels of shares and/or those who had limited access to expert advice or who could not afford that advice; the need for a diversified investment portfolio to minimise risk—it cannot be highlighted enough that investing in the share market does have a risk involved with it and people with a small amount of money to be invested have to decide whether it is worth taking that risk of going into the stock market; the appropriateness or otherwise of share investment at different stages of life; and the possible disadvantageous treatment of some forms of investments compared with other investments.

A number of other issues arose during the course of the inquiry which would merit further investigation. These include the use of shares as a form of superannuation, whether women may be particularly disadvantaged if they cannot maintain some form of substitute superannuation and whether the income and assets tests need to be re-examined in order to ensure that equity is maintained. The committee would have liked to have examined some of these issues, but felt that time constraints prevented it from doing so in a sufficiently detailed manner.

The committee has made four recommendations which it considers will address both short- and long-term factors. Rather than recommend a number of exemptions or short-term adjustments to the measure, the committee has agreed that there is a need to postpone the implementation of this measure. Consequently, the committee's first recommendation is that implementation be postponed until June 1994. This is followed by a recommendation that a review of the assets and income tests should be undertaken by both the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security in order to identify possible inconsistencies and inequities of these tests. As part of this recommendation it is suggested that those undertaking the review should consult with a wide range of groups.

The committee has recommended that the findings of this review be reported in parliament in April 1994. A review of the administration of social security payments, including veterans' payments, has also been recommended. This recommendation has been made to take account of a number of concerns about efficiency and cost-effectiveness which were raised during the inquiry. The minority report varies in regard to the dates that are involved. One of the reasons for the majority report going for postponement till June 1994 was to fit in with financial year criteria. I think that is quite important when people are looking at budgetary items.

I would like to thank the committee secretariat, because we certainly had a hefty workload in undertaking public hearings around the country in three capital cities—Adelaide, Melbourne and Sydney. I would like to make sure that people are aware that they were public hearings. Some of the people who arrived to listen were a little confused, thinking that the hearings were public meetings. When people are advised that something is a public meeting and it is a hearing of the committee it is a little difficult. But we did not have any grave problems with that. There is a very marked difference between a public hearing and a public meeting. The secretariat had to deal with many phone calls, letters and submissions and certainly had their workload cut out.

We would also like to thank Hansard, who had to record the proceedings under some rather difficult acoustic conditions in some of the venues that we chose. Some of the larger venues do not have good acoustics for reproduction or, if they have good acoustics for reproduction which Hansard can use, that makes it a little difficult for people to hear if they are up the back of a large room. In closing, I place on record the committee's thanks to both the secretariat and Hansard for their assistance in providing this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the proposed treatment of unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities under the income test for pensioners lists the 174 submissions and over 2,000 letters that were received. The committee was asked to find on the following matters. The first matter was whether the government's costings for this measure are valid. The report states that the committee does not believe that several important factors have been taken into consideration. The second matter was whether the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses is fair and equitable. The report states that the committee believes that the method is inequitable.

PARA.TAB: The third matter was the effect that the implementation of this measure is likely to have on national savings and investment decisions made by pensioners and veterans. Well, we were not sure, but we said in the report that it would need further examination. The next question was whether this measure will result in a more or less equitable treatment of the various types of pensioner and veterans' investments under the relative income and assets tests. We said that the argument by the two departments concerned that equity is ensured through imposing similar controls on similar investments sounds reasonable but is not wholly correct.

The final question involved the wider implications of creating the precedent of deeming unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income. The report states that `it is the committee's belief that the piecemeal application of a measure of this type will create more inequity than it will solve'. What more an indictment can one have of a measure that has been taken by government than that?

There are only three sitting days to go before this legislation can be repealed. It is an imposition on the pensioners of this country to be kept in further confusion as to what is going to occur in relation to the capital gains on their shares. In presenting the minority report on behalf of the coalition members and Senator Lees from the Democrats, I believe that this whole legislation should be thrown out, just as I throw out the report concerned. It should be repealed straight away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs has completed an eagerly awaited report on its inquiry into the government's planned treatment of unrealised gains on shares as income for social security and veterans' affairs which has been tabled here in the Senate today. It is important to recollect the circumstances that led to this Senate inquiry.

PARA.TAB: Last December, the government included this income test on listed securities as part of a package of social security bills that contained a number of significant benefits, including an across-the-board increase in age pensions. At that time we were in an invidious position. We supported that legislation. I stated in the Senate that the coalition would review the shares provision after the election.

This promise was reiterated by the then shadow minister for social security during the election campaign. Obviously, we had hoped to be in government. No doubt many Australians who have found that they have been misled by the Labor government would now hope we were in government. But that was not to be the case. We kept that promise as best we could in opposition by, in the post-election period, looking to review that as best we could from this position. We decided to make moves to repeal this provision.

During the May sitting of parliament I introduced on behalf of the coalition a private member's bill seeking to repeal this provision. With the support of the Democrats, Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine, this bill was passed by the Senate. However, when the shadow minister, Mr Ruddock, introduced a similar bill into the other place, the Keating government refused to support it. So it had two opportunities: one when our bill went down to the other chamber and again when Mr Ruddock introduced the issue into the other house.

It was decided to seek to achieve our objective by amending government social security and veterans' affairs legislation. We tried another tack to give the government the opportunity to repeal this legislation. Again the coalition's amendments were passed in the Senate with the support of all the non-government senators. However, in the other place, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) responded by claiming that the opposition was `into revenge, obfuscation and just being villains'. That is what he called us. He calls us `unrepresentative swill'; now he says that we are obfuscating and are just being villains. He called the opposition `irresponsible, stupid people'. Let me tell him that the pensioners who came to those public meetings did not think that we were irresponsible, stupid people or that we were obfuscating or that we were villains. They actually saw us as heroes; they see Mr Keating as the arch villain and Mr Dawkins, I suppose, as the Artful Dodger. But that is what Mr Keating was telling the people. They did not believe in that.

In the light of this tirade, it is ironic that the Prime Minister was forced by a rampant and angry caucus to announce a review of this provision. I would have loved to have been a fly on the wall at that caucus meeting, as no doubt you would, Mr Acting Deputy President—and I acknowledge your position in the chair, Mr Acting Deputy President; I think it is the first time I have been able to speak when you have been in that position.

I would have loved to have been a fly on the wall to hear what was said. Maybe I should have blocked my tender little ears, given what I have heard about some of the words that came out of that meeting. The Prime Minister was forced to announce a review of this provision, which he did in a press release. He believes that a press release equals legislation; it does not. We have seen him do that with all sorts of taxation issues in the past. He has issued a press release and said that from the day the press release came out it is law. That is how much he understands about the process of parliament. That is not law.

Pensioners are waiting desperately to find out what this government is going to do. They have to make a decision in the third week of September about whether to sell their shares or not. Many of them have already sold their shares. Some of them will be furious that they have been misled and that they have sold shares that they have held for years because of their belief as to what the government was about to do. As I said, the pensioners should never believe what is l-a-w because the government changes those sorts of things.

It is the same caucus, bar a handful of senators, who voted against the amendments last May and who have now forced a review of this provision. In particular, one must wonder whether the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), who labelled our amendments as an act of vengeance, was at the forefront of the caucus revolt. We will let his marginal seat of McEwen decide. It was a sad day when those people were cheated out of the representation of a tremendous member, Mrs Fran Bailey. The constituents were told so many untruths that, by a handful of votes, they voted in Mr Cleeland—a man who said that our amendments were an act of vengeance.

In the interests of ensuring that the shares issue is not some government diversion to remain at the forefront over the winter recess—which is the tactic it always uses; bring in some diversionary tactic to try to get people's attention away from the real issues—it was decided to withdraw the amendments and set up an inquiry instead. This was done with the support of the non-government senators. Today's report is as a result of that inquiry.

As has been said, the Senate inquiry received almost 200 submissions and more than 2,000 letters. Almost unanimously, they sought the repeal of this harsh and inequitable proposal. Many thousands of people have signed petitions that have been presented to the Senate in the last fortnight. During 1992-93, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) must have received more correspondence about this issue than he has received on any other. It is reasonable to presume that he has received many more letters since 30 June. During the last two months, the talkback radio stations and letters to the editor columns have been inundated by people concerned about this initiative. I quote these figures and this information because they show the degree of angst that is required before this boneheaded Labor government gets out of its ivory tower, opens its ears and starts to listen to the community.

Even now we find that the Prime Minister has merely said that the government will review the implementation of this proposal. We have three sitting days left—2 1/2 in the Senate—before this is implemented. When will the government do something? A very simple solution would be for the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in the House of Representatives to bring on the private member's bill. It is there, it has been through the Senate, and no debate is necessary. The government could have this legislation through the House of Representatives tonight.

Pensioners could then go to bed tonight knowing what their situation was. They could sleep for the first time for many nights. They have now almost become insomniacs through worrying about what is happening. Tonight, if our private member's bill went through, they could sleep.

Will the government have the gall to let a private member's bill go through down there? We have got the legislation which has been through the Senate with the support of the Democrats and the Independents. All the government has to do is pass the bill in the House of Representatives. We wonder whether it will do it. It is no good just telling the pensioners that the government is to review the implementation of this proposal. It is there on its doorstep and the government has to make a decision.

The government's announced review is also totally unacceptable to the thousands of pensioners who have to make a decision before 20 September. Are they to keep their share portfolios? Should they sell them? What are they to do? The government has to make a decision and has to make it now. As I said, the easiest way the government can implement that decision is to pass the private member's bill that is now sitting on the table in the House of Representatives.

The minority report by the opposition and Democrat senators on the committee recommends that there is only one respectable decision to be made, namely, to repeal this ill-considered legislation. It would be unfair to pensioners and veterans and would represent an undermining of the important work of the Senate committee not to do so.

I commend the staff of the committee. I have attended a couple of those committee meetings and a hearing because I was concerned about the issue. I was one of the people responsible for bringing that issue before the committee. I have been impressed by the enormous effort that has gone into that committee by the staff. They have worked tirelessly to ensure that the views of pensioners were brought before the members of that committee. Again I say that the simple solution for the government is to take the private member's bill that is sitting on the table in the House of Representatives and put it through the House tonight to let every pensioner in Australia who is affected by this legislation sleep peacefully this evening. I move an amendment to Senator West's motion:
Leave out all words after "That", substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the Senate takes note of the Report;
(b) the Senate also takes note of:

PARA.TAB: (i) the massive public outcry against, and universal condemnation of, provisions to reduce pensions in real terms, by reference to a notional capital gain in the value of shares held by a pensioner or veteran; and
(ii)the fact that this measure commences on 20 September 1993 unless the Parliament takes urgent and appropriate legislative action to prevent that; and

(iii)the statement by the Prime Minister himself that the Government has decided to review the implementation of the decision to assess unrealised capital gains on pensioners' and veterans' shares; and

SPEECH.PARA: (c)in view of these considerations, the Senate calls on the government to act urgently to:

PARA.TAB: (i)facilitate passage through the House of Representatives of the Oppositions two Private Senators' Bills to repeal the grossly unfair provisions to assess unrealised capital gains on pensioners' and veterans' shares; or

(ii)introduce, as a matter of urgency, its own bill to repeal those measures and, with the agreement of the Senate and House of Representatives, facilitate its passage through the Parliament and its commencement before 20 September 1993; or

(iii)at the very least recognise the enormous confusion, anxiety and stress which has been caused to thousands of pensioner and veteran share holders because of this measure and introduce, and facilitate the passage of, a Bill to delay commencement of these provisions pending full consideration of the Senate Committee's report, and to show that the Prime Minister's stated intention to review the legislation is not either pointless or another cruelly misleading promise waiting to be broken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the proposed treatment of unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities under the income test for pensioners. As a former member of the committee up until 17 August, I have been very closely associated with this matter, and also from a portfolio perspective in terms of dealing with people from the ethnic communities who have been as concerned about this matter as the wider pensioners groups and advisers.

PARA.TAB: I am amazed to see the recommendations of this committee. I am delighted to see that there is a dissenting report from the four senators who are trying to act responsibly towards the older community in this matter. That the Australian Labor Party can ultimately try to bring down a report that simply recommends a postponement of this frightful measure until June 1994 and not act upon the legislation that is before it in the House of Representatives is nothing short of a disgrace.

It was fascinating to go to most of those hearings and to find that there was only one Labor senator out of the whole committee who was prepared to attend.
