These are technical changes that the opposition will not be opposing.

PARA.TAB: I would like to use this opportunity to refute totally a number of misguided claims about the coalition's interest in the arts which have appeared in the media from time to time over the past few months. The claims are that the coalition does not share the alleged artistic integrity of the ALP. Those claims are fallacious; they are totally wrong. What has happened is that some of the media have fallen into the trap of believing the Labor Party propaganda. They have been fed lies and they have fallen for them.

If people from the media talked to Senator Newman, they would find that she played a bassoon; if they talked to the new shadow Attorney-General, Daryl Williams, they would find that he had his AMusA in music and that he plays the piano for recreation. I am sure the Deputy Clerk would be interested in that, since she shares an interest in playing the piano as well. One of my colleagues consumes books in a way that would most probably leave nothing in his pay packet because he reads constantly. Many of us attend the arts and we have a long history of that.

I also want to take a moment here, because I do not want to take up time in an adjournment speech on Monday night, to mention one of my particular interests in the arts. It is very timely because I want to speak about an artist of great stature in Australia; that is, Celia Rosser. Mrs Celia Rosser is a Victorian artist. Anybody who has visited my office will know that I do not have artwork on my walls from the collection; I happen to have my own artwork. That is the interest I take in the arts. I have around my walls six prints of banksias done by Mrs Celia Rosser in the late sixties for the herbarium in Victoria.

Celia was working as a graphic artist at Monash University when she was asked if she would do some illustrations for a book entitled Mosses of South-East Australia. They were trying to decide whether they would do pencil sketches or photographs. When they saw the work that Celia had done, they were so overwhelmed by it that they asked her to illustrate the book. Behind each moss is a pencil drawing of the cell structure of that moss. That book, Mosses of South-East Australia, is not only a fine scientific book, but also a magnificent example of biological illustration.

It was the foresight and vision of the founding vice-chancellor, Louis Matheson, that resulted in Celia being commissioned by the university to paint all banksias in Australia. At the time she started the banksia project, there were about 68 or 69 of them and more have been discovered since then. She started that project about 20 years ago. It was the time I was at Monash University undertaking my PhD. Celia was there finishing each banksia, but nobody really took much of an interest when she would finish one. It was a bit like finishing a chapter of a thesis. Because one had not finished the whole project, people did not rejoice over the fact, yet it was a great achievement for the person who did it. Celia, a friend of mine and I used to have a drink every time she finished a banksia. So I became more and more involved in each of these banksias and more and more involved in this great project.

Celia has now finished two volumes of the project: the first volume has about 25 banksias in it; the second has another 25 or 26. Those banksias are large. The book weighs about 16 pounds or kilograms; I cannot quite remember. It is huge when it is in its book form. Volumes were bought for this Parliament House and they will be in some people's rooms.

Celia is currently working on the third edition of her volume. Next Thursday the originals of all her banksias will be on display in Kew Gardens. Senator Schacht might frown and ask what relevance this has. It is about the arts. It is about botanical art. It is about one of the greatest botanical artists that this world has known.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just asking where it is covered in the bill.
—It is an arts bill, and I am talking about the arts.
—I have seen them.
—I thank Senator McGauran.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—I take it this has relevance to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has absolute relevance to the bill. It will be exhibited at Kew Gardens. Unfortunately, because of my other duties, I will not be able to be there to congratulate Celia Rosser. I believe that honourable senators here would want to convey to her our best wishes on this achievement. It is unusual that such an exhibition should be held at the Kew Gardens. It is a great honour for her, a great honour for Australian art and a great honour for Australian science. Since Senator Schacht and his government have destroyed almost all the scientists in Australia, how would he know? She is an artist who is involved in a science project.

PARA.TAB: Celia Rosser is one of the great artists of Australia. People who are better able to judge than I have said that she is one of the best botanical artists of this century, if not ever. I would encourage honourable senators to visit my office to see some of her earlier work and also a studio rough which is on my wall and which was a gift to me by Celia. My congratulations go to Celia, as do, I am sure, the congratulations of all honourable senators. I hope honourable senators who are able to do so will go to her exhibition in England. That is just one of my interests in the arts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise. There is a clause in the bill which says the name will be the National Gallery of Australia; so there is a chance of relevance here.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! Minister, let Senator Patterson continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not go on tonight with all my other interests in the arts; that is just one that is very relevant at the moment. All these attacks that the Labor Party has made on the coalition share a common characteristic; they are bland assertion and they are not true. There is no evidence for what the Labor Party says. I have heard a number of people say things about our interest in the arts. The authors of the stories that have appeared have obviously fallen into the old trap of believing everything that the government's propaganda machine tells them, without checking their facts first.

PARA.TAB: Where did the great interest and vision which the Labor Party has in relation to the arts spring from? Where did its insightful—it thought it was insightful; I did not think it was—cultural policy come from? Did it come from a long-time Labor interest in the arts? The answer is no. Did it come from the collective passion of Labor Party members? No. I will tell honourable senators where it came from: it came from a big slice of consolidated revenue. The ALP bought its cultural policy through consultancy. We have seen consultancy after consultancy in these estimates. The Labor Party bought it; it was paid for by the Australian taxpayer.

The sum of $9,000 was paid to a former press secretary of one of the ministers to prepare the Prime Minister's cultural statement. The sum of $9,000 was paid to another consultant to prepare the cultural statement, and $5,000 was paid to somebody else to do the cover. The Labor Party's cultural policy was paid for with taxpayers' money. That is what happened. That is how the Labor Party generated its cultural policy—not out of a deep and abiding and long-term interest in the arts but because it thought there were a few votes in the arts. And, $23,000 of taxpayers' money later, the Labor Party had its cultural policy. We stand on a long record. Keating said—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Patterson, would you please refer to members of the other house by their proper titles, or full names.
—`Mr Keating', I am sorry. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course we're for the arts but what have we done for them? Answer—not much, and we ought to do a fair bit for them.

What is the history of the Liberal Party? We established the Commonwealth Literary Fund, the Institution of the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust in 1954, which in turn established the three major national touring bodies: the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and the Marionette Theatre of Australia. The Menzies government set up the National Library of Australia. The Gorton government in 1968 established the Australia Council for the Arts.

PARA.TAB: More recently, in 1977 Malcolm Fraser introduced and incorporated the Community Arts Board into the Australia Council; he introduced the tax deductions, which were augmented in 1980 and which included 150 per cent write-off in film investment expenditure. In that same year the Fraser government legislated to establish the National Museum of Australia. In 1983 the Fraser government announced the creation of the Touring and Access Fund of the Australia Council.

What else did the Fraser government set up? It set up the Australiana Fund. Thank goodness for the Australiana Fund because what it did—here and now this year—was to stop the purchase of the Thai teak table for the Lodge. It was an initiative of the Liberal Party in government to set up the Australiana Fund to make sure that we encouraged Australian artisans and so that we would have in our residential facilities for our prime minister Australian works of art and Australian furniture. But no, Mr Keating wanted to buy a table from Thailand, when there are large numbers of gifted crafts people in Australia who can make beautiful works of art in the form of furniture. So much for the rhetoric.

What we want is record. The Liberal Party, as individual members and senators, can stand on its record of a long and proud history of interest in the arts; a long proud record when we were in government of doing real things for the arts, not rhetoric bought at the taxpayer's expense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Among the many acts that this bill corrects is the Australia Council Act 1975. The reason I stress `this bill corrects' is that we are once again today dealing with a bill that corrects mistakes in previous legislation. The Senate would be aware of the fact that the opposition has objected continually to the flood of bills that is forced through this place late in the session. It is inevitable that when one gets that flood of bills one gets a flood of errors. So here we are, dealing with part of that flood of errors to legislation. Not only is the Australia Council Act being corrected for a drafting error, but we have the Australian Heritage Commission Act correcting the citation of the Remuneration Tribunal Act, we have the National Gallery Act correcting a drafting error, and the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act correcting a drafting error. That is apart from the other parts which I have not directed my attention to relating to the ACT.

PARA.TAB: I particularly want to follow some of the comments made by Senator Patterson relating to the arts policy of the coalition and the arts standing of members of the coalition. Senator Patterson was quite correct to point out that this newfound interest in the arts by the government—which is almost as enthusiastic as the new found interest in the environment that Senator Richardson discovered for electoral purposes a few years ago—is extraordinarily phoney and bears a greater relationship to electoral need than to the real interest of the people concerned.

I think it worth pointing out that despite comments in various newspapers where people have fallen for this garbage, I was on the Council of Musica Viva Australia before I entered this place. Musica Viva happens to be the second biggest concert giving organisation in Australia. I have some sort of passing interest in and knowledge of how the arts operate.

Before coming into this place, when I was a journalist, I was a music reviewer for a Sydney metropolitan daily newspaper. I was the record reviewer for the Observer magazine. I, for my sins, wrote a very interesting book which sold out on the Sydney Opera House and I have been attending ABC Symphony concerts since I was a child. Of course, I had to do my AMEB exams as I think so many of us in this party, in particular, did. I do not know how many members of the government, in their new found enthusiasm

SPEECH.PARA: for the arts, know what `AMEB' means, let alone have done the courses.

PARA.TAB: Apart from my protest about this kind of phoney interest in the arts which is getting such a ludicrous run in the media, I want to deal with matters, for example, affecting the Australia Council, the bill for which is being corrected for a drafting error in this legislation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard—I gave this table to Senator Sherry when he was on duty—the budget allocations to art form boards for last year, and budgeted for this year, for the Australia Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The reason I wanted to incorporate this table is that it demonstrates one of the greatest frauds this government has perpetrated on the arts. There has been monumental propaganda saying that there has been a massive increase in funding for the arts from which anyone who even looks as though they are related to the arts will benefit.

PARA.TAB: The facts are that the highly publicised, well promoted special grants to the arts have to some extent been at the expense of existing clients of the government, existing arts organisations, whose allocations in real terms are being cut. Who is paying for the big increases? I will not deny that there are some overall increases. But the basic clients of the Australia Council are having their total allocations cut in real terms. Apart from a specific instance of a fall in one program, all of the boards of the Australia Council are having their money funding increased by only about half of the inflation factor this year—I think inflation will go up about 3 or 3 1/2 per cent.

We see that funding for the Literature Board will go up by 1.67 per cent; in other words, after one accounts for inflation its funding is cut. Funding for the Performing Arts Board will go up by 1.64 per cent, but after accounting for inflation that board's money is being cut. Funding for the Visual Arts/Craft Board will be cut; it will get a 1.56 per cent money increase which is a cut in real terms. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Committee will get a 1.56 per cent increase; inflation will mean that is a real cut. The Community Cultural Development Board funding will go up by 1.55 per cent, which also represents a real cut.

The funds for the council's own programs and strategic development will be cut in money terms, let alone real terms, by 2.67 per cent. Advocacy travel will go only by 1.26 per cent, another real cut. However, I should add for the purposes of rounding it out, that creative fellowships—in other words, the big ticket Keating ones—will go up by 20 per cent because they are called Keatings. Obviously they have to go up because that is the big-noting one, the one that the Prime Minister identifies with.

Here we have the highly promoted increases in arts funding being, to an extent, at the expense of traditional art forms and traditional arts bodies that depend on the Australia Council for their funding. This is despite the fact that it has become evident that the demands on many Australian arts organisations, particularly those which have a national flavour and travel interstate, have increased. One reason for this is that many of them have had very difficult seasons in that economically disastrous centre, Victoria. That extends across quite a lot of arts bodies.

There is no doubt that some of these bodies will have to approach the government for an increase in their funding, particularly after their basic funding has been cut in real terms. By the way, this includes the Australian Opera in that its basic funding has been cut in real terms because its money funding increase is less than the expected inflation rate. I understand from the debate in the Senate estimates committee that the government, when dealing with these increasing appropriations to keep pace with inflation, has been using an inflation rate of only about 2.3 per cent. These cuts have not met the government's own rate. Yet the government's budget says the inflation rate will be some three to 3 1/2 per cent this year. There is simply no way in which the government will meet this kind of target.

I repeat that it is a disgrace that this government is hiding behind its special allocations, its vote buying schemes, at election time—I have to say that it is delivering those vote buying schemes—but at the expense of traditional arts organisations. This can be shown even more dramatically when one looks at funding for film. Unfortunately, the appropriation figures did not reveal in clear, unequivocal terms just what the cut was, but the budget figures indicate that funding to the Film Finance Corporation is falling by about $5 million this year—a cut.

Today we heard Senator McMullan getting up and saying, `Isn't it wonderful how all these Australian films are doing so magnificently?'—by inference all because of this government. What is the government doing? It is cutting the allocation to the Australian Film Finance Corporation by just under $5 million. Next year it will cut it further by about $9 million; the year after, a further cut of—heaven's above—quite a bit. Over the three years we will end up with a cut of about $12 million. When one goes back a year it will involve a cut of some $17 million.

Honourable senators will remember the enormous furore when the coalition in the run up to the election said that it would limit the cut in film funding in the next parliament. We said that we would only cut film funding by about $20 million, which is almost exactly the same ballpark as this government is now aiming at in these budget figures. There is a difference between us of only $3 million or $4 million. The reason that the government is cutting film funding is exactly the same reason that the coalition said it would cut film funding; that is, because the films are earning revenues. It is that revenue and the hope that there would be greater investment income that would enable the government to lower the grants.

But the coalition policy had something extra going for it. It was providing increased incentives for investment in film. There is no incentive under this government to invest in films with the result that there has been a dramatic collapse in private sector investment in Australian films.

This government was crowing before the election about its magnificent contribution and was damning the coalition for even suggesting that there might be a cut in film funding under a coalition government. What do we have? We have a $5 million cut this year. We have a $9 million cut next year and further cuts the year after. In 1996-97, the budgeted figure at the moment in the projections is that instead of a total assistance to the film industry of $81.4 million, it will go down to $19.9 million—a cut of over $60 million. This is what the government states in the budget papers:

Following reviews of film funding in 1991-92, funding of the FFC falls to $57m in 1993-94 (from $61.9m in 1992-93), with funding continuing at declining levels through to 1995-96. Funding beyond then is subject to further review.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet here we have these actors conned by this government to appear in a vicious campaign against the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bryan Brown.

—I accept the interjection. These actors were conned by this government into supporting a policy which involves a reduction in film funding. Let us get that perfectly clear. This is another area where meeting the government's election promises has resulted in making a cut to some traditional areas of funding.

PARA.TAB: I hope that earnings from some of these successful activities will offset the reduction in government funding. But the absence of any stimulus or incentive to investment will make it very difficult, whereas I believe that our policy and incentive system—with a reduction in government funding which, as I said, is in the same ballpark as the government's own reduction—would have made it a lot easier for the film industry to increase the revenue made available to it. We were much more interested in using taxation incentives than grants because that means it is market driven, not bureaucratically driven. But this government would much rather dictate, through the bureaucracy, the nature of this industry.

I will also mention in passing that it is unfortunate when the minister for the arts puts out a press release which quite wrongly claims that the Australia Council's allocation this year is $58.73 million when it is $58.13. It is a difference of only $600,000, but it is a little boost, a fiscal stimulus on paper, which does not exist in reality. The same thing happened in relation to a grant of $24 million to the Sydney Cove authority to smarten up Sydney Cove. That grant appears in this year's estimates but it appeared in last year's as well. It made it look good last year—an extra $24 million going to the arts. It was not spent last year so it appears as an estimate again for this year. The government is getting twice the joy for the same amount of money—or for the appearance of big spending, the appearance of meeting obligations, when the reality is often so different.

Since this budget, which reduces the total allocation in real terms to the Australia Council, I have not heard a peep out of all those people who attacked the coalition saying that we were trying to destroy the Australia Council. The Australia Council's total appropriation has gone up by 1.96 per cent—that is, about $1.12 million—of which $288,000 relates to the creative fellowships, the Keatings. So the rest of the boards have had lower increases.

The total grant appropriation available for grants for the Australia Council has gone down by $733,000, but that is explicable; I understand what that situation is all about. Nevertheless, there is a clear reduction of $733,000 in the appropriation from this government available for grants by the Australia Council. I hope this table clearly indicates that.

By the way, I had some difficulty establishing what the cuts were because they were not clearly shown in the appropriations. I am grateful to the Australia Council for providing this information. But what I am concerned about is that this government has required these individual boards to fund some specific interest groups out of existing reduced appropriations. For example, the literature board has introduced a new type of grant—the Asia-Pacific fellowship. I think it is great to have it. Last year $48,000 in fellowships were approved. The problem is: that is at the cost of other fellowships that the board can grant.

The same applies in respect of the Visual Arts Crafts Board approving the allocation of 21 per cent of its budget towards the council's arts for a multicultural Australia program. I am all in favour of a multicultural Australia program, but the problem is: should we rob the non-multicultural program element in order to pay the multicultural program? That is what is happening in this situation. We are robbing Peter to pay for Paul's promises. That is simply unacceptable. It is unacceptable that there should be this phoney campaign on the arts before the election—a campaign which has now been shown to be partly a fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Tasmanian, I feel it is my duty to rise and speak against the foreshadowed amendment by Senator Bell of the Australian Democrats. I think it is important to scotch this issue at a very early stage. I notice that my colleague Senator Calvert will be joining me in just a few moments. In fact, it is so important that I will confine my remarks to no more than two minutes to ensure that the proposed amendment is defeated tonight.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats have done enough damage to the orchard industry in Tasmania without adding salt to the wound with this wide-ranging amendment. I think they should hang their heads in shame. Surely these orchardists have had retribution enough. As such, Mrs Kelly, the Democrats and others have a very heavy cross to bear in terms of the damage that they have done to orchardists in the Huon River region as a result of the closure of that lime quarry at Lune River. What this decision has meant to the orchardists is that a considerable cost will be added to producing apples, which will have to be recovered in the export price of the fruit.

Lime is an essential ingredient for the propagation of the fruit. It is not a question of opening any quarry for any lime. The quality and the chemical composition are important factors. As a result of this, trucks will have to come down from the north and north west coast on a daily basis to service the needs of these orchardists—more trucks on the highway and higher production costs which, as I said, must be recovered in the export price of the fruit. I foreshadow my opposition to Senator Bell's foreshadowed amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also foreshadow that I will vote against the foreshadowed amendment.
—Oh!
—I do not know whether Senator Woodley has ever been down to have a look at this area.
—Yes, I have.

—He has. Then he would know as well as I do that Bender's Quarry has been closed down. It was a very small operation, but a very important operation to the area. I would like to know, looking at this foreshadowed amendment, just what Senator Bell is on about when he says, `. . . in relation to the area known as Exit Cave, Tasmania'. I would like to know how big an area he means. Obviously it takes in Bender's Quarry. He is trying to stop any other operation opening up to provide limestone to the apple industry. I find that quite astounding.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell has only this week been talking about concerns about the use of chemicals. That is fair enough; I support him in that, being an orchardist myself. I know the damage that has been done and can be done by the use of chemicals without proper knowledge. But this decision to close Bender's Quarry has burdened the fruit growers of the Huon with about half a million dollars extra cost. They use that lime because it colours their fruit. I do not know whether Senator Bell wants all the red apples in the Huon to remain green in memory of him or not, but what it means is that a lot of those fruit growers will be tempted to use chemicals to colour their apples, as he knows very well, and it has been proved that some of the chemicals that have been used to colour apples are rather toxic and dangerous to people.

Senator Bell got publicity from the stunt he carried out last year and I thought he would have been satisfied with that by now. He got headlines in Tasmania, he got the publicity and Bender's Quarry was closed down. There was evidence given by more than one expert that no damage was being done to the cave by blasting it to quarry. It was a stunt to create support for the Democrats and support for the Greens before the election.

I would have thought that, now the election is over, Senator Bell would have given up and found something else to talk about. I just think, quite frankly, the people of the Huon would be very disappointed to know that Senator Bell, a self-professed free spirit in politics in Tasmania, would come in here tonight and try to create another stunt, as he did last year, to the detriment of the people and jobs in the Huon area. It has cost jobs and it will cost more.

Senator Baume vented his spleen about being the former shadow minister for the arts at the time of the last election, and about the arts policy of the government compared with the coalition. Senator Baume does not understand that the arts community supported the Labor Party not because of any question of money, but because they know that in our present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and within the government there is a genuine commitment and understanding of the arts. I do have to agree with Senator Watson and Senator Calvert that that is another issue and it should be debated at another time. It is not part of this bill, so we will also be opposing that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to address some human rights concerns which relate to the Macedonian ethnic community living within the borders of Greece. I do so in the context of Australia's international human rights obligations which are grounded in the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights agreed by the United Nations assembly with 48 supporting votes, including Greece, and eight abstentions, mainly by the socialist republics of Eastern Europe, including the then Yugoslavia.

PARA.TAB: Together with the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, ratified by Australia in 1975, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, ratified in 1980, this United Nations covenant constitutes what is generally accepted as the international bill of rights. It sets standards of human rights which all nations should not only aspire to observe within their own borders, but should also actively seek to have accepted on a global scale. .

It is important to note that in contrast to the United Nations predecessor, the League of Nations, these documents speak of `peoples', which has generally been accepted as including ethnic communities within a nation. This is an important definition which, for instance, includes the Aboriginal community in Australia.

However, tonight I wish to address in this context the human rights concerns of the Macedonian community living within the borders of Greece. The past year has seen more than 20 people sentenced to prison terms for opposing government policy on the subject of Macedonia.

By way of example, three such prosecutions raise concerns about the Greek government's treatment of ethnic Macedonians within its borders. I briefly name the people in the three groups who have been treated in a way that I believe is a breach of human rights before Greek courts.

The first example concerns Christos Sidiropulous and Tasos Boulis. Both received five-month sentences for `spreading false information and instigating conflict'. They did this, apparently, by telling a Greek magazine that they feel `Macedonian' and by asserting the existence of an ethnic Macedonian minority in Greece. The next example concerns Michael Papadakis, a 17-year-old school student, who received a one-year sentence for distributing a leaflet which contained the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Macedonia belongs to its people. There are no races. We are all of mixed descent.

The third example concerns Archimandrite Nikodimos Tsarknias, an ethnic Macedonian priest and well known human rights campaigner who was defrocked by the Greek Orthodox Church and subsequently charged under the guise of insulting his Archbishop. His trial is set down for April 1994. I believe that we should raise our voices to ensure that these prosecutions do not continue.

PARA.TAB: It is useful to quote the concerns expressed by human rights agencies, Amnesty International and Helsinki Watch, which have made the following comments on what they judge to be a denial of basic human rights to ethnic Macedonians in Greece. Amnesty International states:

SPEECH.PARA: Amnesty International is gravely concerned at these restrictions on the right to freedom of expression which the Greek Government guaranteed to uphold when it ratified the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.

That is the European convention of 1974, in addition to the one that I mentioned before, the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Amnesty International has also stated that any persons convicted by the Greek authorities on the basis of contradicting the Greek government's official policy on Macedonia will be considered prisoners of conscience.

PARA.TAB: Helsinki Watch states that it used these trials `as disturbing violations of freedom of expression rights guaranteed by international law'. In none of these cases has any of the defendants been charged with violent acts or any other criminal behaviour. The charges are based purely on publicly expressed opinions that conflict with the views which the Greek government says is in contradiction of its laws. All of the defendants face possible sentences of several years as well as large fines. Helsinki Watch calls on the Greek government to immediately drop charges against the defendants in each of the cases. It adds:

SPEECH.PARA: These trials are based on statutes that violate international law on free expression. They are aimed at peaceful political expression. The government can stop these prosecutions if it wants to. Until it does, and moves to repeal the repressive laws it is using to muzzle dissenter views of Greece's friends around the world—and everyone concerned about freedom of expression ought to speak up and tell the country's misguided government to pursue its Macedonia policy through persuasion, not coercion.
These concerns are now being given some exposure in the media. The Economist in an article entitled `Greece and Macedonia: Do Not Disagree' states:

Many countries suppress free speech. But these trials are taking place in a member of the European Community . . . Although the undersecretary for foreign affairs has said that some of the trials are a mistake, the government has not dropped any charges. In one case, the public prosecutor even appealed against a unanimous verdict of not guilty.
The Times says:

Freedom of expression has been hit by a series of astounding criminal convictions of people who were foolish enough to question the Greek hard core line toward Macedonia. These trials are disturbing because they are antidemocratic, intolerant, deeply destructive and contrary to the European convention for human rights.

I believe it is time for Australia to play a part in conveying the message to the Greek government that Greece has an obligation to observe international human rights standards. The Australian government also has a moral responsibility to represent the interests of some 200,000 Australian Macedonians by taking an active role in adding its weight to pressure the Greek government to cease its discriminatory policies and stop prosecutions
aimed at ethnic Macedonians which cannot be justified on legal grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has Australia been criticised in an Amnesty report released on 12 May 1993 for its treatment of Aboriginals.
(2) Did the report find that Aboriginals were arrested at a rate 29 times higher than that of other Australians.
(3) Did the report further find that police harassment of Aboriginals was widespread.
(4) Has the United Nations designated 1993 as International Year of the World's Indigenous People.
(5) Will the Minister be attending the United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Vienna in June 1993; if so how will the findings of the Amnesty report be explained.
(6) What action is being taken to ensure that Australia is not named in future reports on human rights abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Amnesty report does not criticise the Australian Government but is critical of the operation of aspects of the criminal justice system of State and Territory Governments. It describes the findings of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody outlining deficiencies in the standard of care afforded to Aboriginal people. The Amnesty report identifies Aboriginal people as a group which is distinctly vulnerable to incarceration.
(2) The report found that Aboriginals were being arrested at a rate 29 times higher than other Australians.
(3) The report found that Aboriginal people were often arrested in circumstances which may not apply to other citizens.
(4) Yes
(5) The Minister did not attend the United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Vienna.

(6) The Australian Government is continuing to strengthen its commitment to the pursuit of a range of programs and initiatives to address the continuing effects of disadvantage experienced by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. Areas covered by the programs and initiatives include law and justice, youth, education, employment, health, housing and infrastructure, land and a range of changes to policies, procedures and practices in agencies whose responsibilities affect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

The Commonwealth Government in response to the Royal Commission Into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody recommendations has allocated $400 million over the five (5) year period commencing 1992/93 which comprises;
$150 million for law and justice initiatives and also assisting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people overcome alcohol and substance abuse, and
$250 million to confront the economic and social disadvantages facing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in present society.

Another major initiative has been amendments to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission legislation to enable the appointment of Mr Michael Dodson to the position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner as a response to a specific recommendation from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.
It is not possible for Australia to ensure that it is not named in future reports on human rights abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the report of the study into the rationalisation of the health staff of the Headquarters of the Australian Defence Force (HQADF) and the Service Offices, considered by the Chiefs of Staff Committee in December 1992 and which recommended integrating all staff into one organisation in HQADF;
(1) Do the changes being considered involve reserving the four most senior positions for doctors;

(2) Does the exclusion of dentists, nurses and other appropriately qualified and experienced health professionals from the most senior health positions in the Australian Defence Force reflect modern health service management practice and the broad policy formulation and management responsibilities involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The responsibilities of the Surgeon General and two of his directors general are predominantly medical in nature necessitating that medical qualifications be a prerequisite. The responsibilities of the third director general are such that the position is available to both medical and other health professionals.

(2) Yes. This arrangement is entirely in keeping with modern military medical practice. The health services in the Australian Defence Force provide a service not available from the civilian sector: a field service in support of military operations. At the most senior levels of management, the task is to situate the provision of health services in the military context. This involves the provision of health advice and the development of health policy with an appreciation of the impact that such advice and policy will have on the provision of military health services to meet military operational needs. Considerable military experience is necessary and, as the advice requested and the policies generated are predominantly of a medical nature, the Service medical officer stream would seem to be best placed to provide candidates for these positions. Nevertheless, as indicated in answering the first question, the responsibilities of one of the one star health positions in the Australian Defence Force are such that the position is available to both medical and other health professionals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the report entitled Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC)
(1) On what date were the NHMRC recommendations for banning the use of cyclodiene pesticides first referred to the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC) for implementation.
(2) What action has been taken by the AAVCC on each of the recommendations from the NHMRC.
(3) If no action has been taken to date, when does the AAVCC propose to implement these recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The NHMRC Report "Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia" was referred for consideration by the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC) at its December 1992 meeting.
(2 & 3) The NHMRC Report directed 3 of its 11 recommendations to the AAVCC. Specifically, the recommendations to the AAVCC were
1) that the cyclodienes aldrin and dieldrin should cease to be registered for all pesticide uses when current stocks are exhausted. Further importation of those chemicals should not be permitted.

As aldrin and dieldrin have not been imported since 1991 and 1987 respectively and will not be approved for import in future, the AAVCC has been able to establish that current stocks are thought to have been exhausted and the chemicals no longer used. This is being confirmed with State authorities so that a formal withdrawal of registration can be undertaken for both chemicals.

The Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ), which met in July 1993, agreed to totally prohibit the use of aldrin and dieldrin in Australia from 30 June 1994.
2) that chemicals of the same class (that is endrin and isobenzan) not be considered in the future for registration as pesticides.

The AAVCC established that endrin has not been used in Australia for many years and isobenzan was never approved. As these chemicals have no place in Australian agriculture and are unlikely to be proposed for use, steps are being considered to ensure that these pesticides will not be registered in future.
3) that registration of the use of chlordane and heptachlor in agriculture and other non-termiticidal applications should cease.

Chlordane was never approved in Australia for use in agriculture while heptachlor now has only one minor, but important use in the control of funnel ant in sugarcane. ARMCANZ has also agreed to prohibit this use on sugarcane from 31 December 1994.

In addition to the NHMRC recommendations directed to AAVCC, the Council investigated with State authorities the possibility of an early phase-out of chlordane in the control of termites. While alternative control measures are suitable in some parts of Australia, and may allow an early phase-out of the use of cyclodiene insecticides, there is some uncertainty as to their effectiveness in the control of the more voracious Mastotermes species of termites which are present in the northern part of the continent. The use of chlordane as a termiticide has been referred to the newly established National Registration Authority for Agricultural And Veterinary Chemicals (NRA). The Authority is to establish a working party to examine alternate termite control methods and if appropriate, propose a timetable for implementing further changes, including a phase out of all remaining use of organochlorine insecticides.

The NRA has announced that it will be holding a public hearing into the continued use of chlordane and heptachlor for termite control in Australia. The hearing, to be held in Canberra, has been scheduled for 8 September 1993.

Coastal engineering—studies of silt and sand movement and beach replenishment.
chromium-51; copper-64; gold-198; iridium-192; scandium-46

Thickness gauging

argon-41; bromine-82; chromium-51; copper-64; gold-198; technetium-99m;

(3) and (4) All these isotopes may be produced by non-reactor technologies, which require bombardment of a selected target isotope with appropriate sub-atomic particles to produce new parent radioisotopes, followed by recovery of the required isotopes from the resulting chains of decay products. However reactors are the cheapest means of producing useful quantities of these isotopes. Consequently these radioisotopes, when obtained commercially, are the product of a nuclear reactor.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 28 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the recent government initiative which will help parents with the cost of the HiB vaccine for meningitis, although the refund for this vaccine is only available for children born on or after 1 February 1993:
(1) Is the Minister aware that children up to the age of 5 years can be affected by meningitis and that this restriction is discriminatory.
(2) Has the Government considered the possibility of a part rebate for all children up to 5 years rather than the full rebate for a selected few.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) I am aware that a major cause of meningitis in children up to the age of five years is infection with haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib). On 23 July 1993, I announced that the Government will provide funding for a full catch up program for Hib immunisation. This program will enable all children up to the age of 5 years to be immunised against Hib.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When will the Australian Customs Service finalise the tender program for Coastwatch.
(2) What is the proposed timetable for:(a) requests for proposals; (b) requests for tenders; (c) tender evaluation; and (d) contract award.
(3) What are the details of the process to be used in the calling of tenders and when does the Government hope to finalise an order of costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Details of the next Coastwatch tender will be announced following budgetary and other considerations by the Government. The program which will apply for the forthcoming Coastwatch contract is being formalised between Australian Customs Service (ACS) and Department of Arts and Administrative Services (DAS) in accordance with the Government's Procurement Guideline No. 5 specifically as it relates to Staged Procurement.
(2) At this stage it is proposed that the timetable of the tender process will be as follows:
Request for Proposals—3 months—close 31/1/94
Negotiation of Proposals—3 weeks—close 21/2/94
Best and Final Offers—1 month—close 15/3/94
Evaluation Process—3 months—close 15/6/94
Prepare Contract—1 month—close 15/7/94

(3) The process will involve the DAS inviting "Requests for Proposals" (RFP) on behalf of the ACS. At that time a Task Requirement prepared by Customs Coastwatch will be released thus specifying the nature and extent of the service required. An industry briefing will be conducted to explain the requirements and to facilitate feedback to potential bidders. Proponents will be invited to bid in terms of a 5, 7 and 9 year contract.

A two tier evaluation process will be implemented at the technical and senior management levels. Staff from both DAS and ACS with appropriate and relevant commercial and aviation expertise will work in these groups and will be supplemented by officials from outside agency(s) to be engaged on a needs basis. The selection criteria and processes to be followed in the evaluation will be publicised at the time proposals are invited and will also be explained at the industry briefing.

In respect of estimated cost, this will depend on a number of factors including the contract length, hardware offered and the supporting infrastructure bidders believe necessary for the contract. The inherent uncertainty of tendering also makes estimating a very imprecise science. It is envisaged that a statement on cost will be made at the time the RFP is published.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the Australian Government's assessment of the current situation in the Israeli occupied Palestinian territories.

(2) What effect is the decision by the Israeli Government to close off the West Bank and the Gaza Strip having on the health conditions and economic welfare of Palestinian people living in these territories.

(3) What is the nature of Australian Government representations to Israel concerning the increase in the number of killings of Palestinians, evidence of use of torture by Israeli military authorities against prisoners, and other violations of human rights.
(4) What progress has been made in the implementation of United Nations Security Council resolution 799 concerning the return of 400 Palestinian deportees.
(5) How has the Australian Government involved itself in addressing the concerns set out in United Nations Security Council resolution 799.
(6) What is the nature of Australian Government representations to Israel concerning the implementation of the Fourth Geneva Convention on the Occupied Territories.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The situation in the occupied territories remains unsettled and tense. Israel's indefinite closure of the occupied territories is causing hardship to the Palestinian population. While the closure has been successful in reducing the incidence of violence by Palestinians against Israeli civilians, violence continues in the territories between Palestinians and Israeli security forces. The number of Palestinians—including children—killed or wounded by Israeli Defence Force gunfire has drawn international criticism, including from organisations such as Amnesty International and the International Committee of the Red Cross. Details of economic and social conditions in the territories are given in response to question (2).

(2) The closure has in effect divided the territories into four separate regions: the northern West Bank, East Jerusalem, the southern West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Special permits are required for entry into Jerusalem and Israel, including travel between the West Bank and Gaza. This has resulted in disruption to the daily life of Palestinians, caused high unemployment, and negatively affected commerce, medical care, education, and access to services.

The economy of the occupied territories, already unstable, has been adversely affected by the closure. According to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA), "losses from wages previously earned by an estimated 130,000 Palestinians with jobs in Israel can be conservatively estimated at $US2.75 million per day. In the West Bank nearly half of the total labour force, or about 100,000 labourers, worked in Israel just prior to the closure; in many villages bordering Israel the percentage was as high as 80 per cent. In Gaza, 25 per cent or about 30,000 labourers had jobs in Israel before the closure, half of pre-Gulf war levels". Overall, unemployment in the territories is now conservatively estimated at 50 per cent.

The deteriorating economic conditions are having adverse consequences for the health of the Palestinian population. UNICEF has warned of the risk of widespread malnutrition and anaemia unless the economic decline is reversed, or widespread food distribution organised to the families of the unemployed. The closure has restricted access to medical care for Palestinians in the territories. Two major hospitals—Maqassed and Augusta Victoria—are located in East Jerusalem, and are therefore unavailable to patients from the West Bank and Gaza.

The Government is concerned about the situation and, in response to an appeal, has recently provided further emergency relief worth $325,000 to the occupied territories, to be channelled through UNRWA. This is in addition to the $2.6 million core contribution that Australia provided to UNRWA in 1992/93.

(3) Australia makes periodical representations to the Israeli government expressing our concern at the human rights situation in the occupied territories and the conduct of the Israeli Defence Force. The last such representation was made by our Charge d'affaires in Israel in April this year. We also raise with the Israeli authorities individual cases of alleged human rights abuse, some of which are referred to us by the Amnesty International Parliamentary Group.

During my visit to Israel in May 1992 I raised with the then Prime Minister and Foreign and Defence Ministers the Government's concern about the use of administrative detention, collective punishments such as curfews and demolition of houses, conditions in prisons, the issue of family reunification, and the shooting of unarmed Palestinians by undercover units of the Israeli Defence Force. I made it clear that the Australian Government views such practices as violating the Fourth Geneva Convention and other internationally accepted norms of human rights behaviour.

(4) While Israel has yet to comply with United Nations Security Council resolution 799 calling for the return of all the 415 deportees, over 100 of the deportees have been allowed to return, and the remainder are expected to be able to return by the end of this year.

(5) The Government supports United Nations Security Council resolution 799 and we have made representations urging Israel to comply with it. On 18 December 1992, I issued a statement deploring the deportations, and on 22 December 1992 officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade called in the Israeli Charge d'affaires who was advised of the Government's condemnation of Israel's action. Our Charge d'affaires in Israel was also instructed to protest against the deportations to the Israeli Foreign Ministry.

(6) In addition to the representations mentioned above, at the United Nations Commission on Human Rights this year, Australia urged Israel to accept de jure applicability of the Fourth Geneva Convention to the occupied territories and expressed concern over continuing human rights abuses against Palestinians. Australia has also made representations to the Israeli government protesting against the closure of the occupied territories which the Government considers constitutes a collective punishment prohibited by the Fourth Geneva Convention. I reiterated these concerns in discussions on 28 April this year with Israel's Deputy Foreign Minister, Dr Yossi Beilin.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 16 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an article on page 11 in the first edition of the Herald-Sun of 31 May 1993 entitled `Telecom puts service on hold':
(1) What is the `confidential' Government report referred to in the article.

(2) Is it a fact that more than 35 per cent of callers to directory assistance services, 013 and 0175, in December 1992 hung up without being connected, as suggested by the article; if not, what is the true figure.

(3) Is it a fact that calls "lost" in the network reached a one year high in December 1992 and almost 10 per cent of IDD calls from country areas failed to reach their destinations, as is also suggested by the article; if not, what was the true situation.
(4) Could a copy of the report referred to in the article be provided; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The report referred to is entitled "Quality of Service Report, December Quarter 1992". It was prepared by AUSTEL for the information of AUSTEL's Consumer Advisory Committee. It consists of a precis of quality of service data supplied by Telecom with a brief analysis by AUSTEL.
(2) Yes. The report indicates that in December 1992, 36 per cent of callers to directory assistance services entered the queue and left without being answered.

(3) Statistics contained in the report indicate that network loss for local calls, STD calls between 8 am and 6 pm and IDD calls were at their peak for 1992 in December. This was not the case for STD calls between 6 pm and 10 pm. In the case of IDD calls from country areas, the figure shown was 9.4 per cent.

The data provided by Telecom stated that the network loss figures for local and STD calls were inflated due to incorrect system interpretation of network signals. It also drew attention to the heavy demands which occur in the Christmas period.
(4) A copy of the report has been provided separately to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Small Business, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Given that a large part of the work of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Divisions of Oceanography and Fisheries involves close collaboration and sharing of resources with non-marine Divisions of CSIRO, what institutional arrangements are planned to ensure that this cost-saving collaboration will continue if the proposed restructuring takes place.

(2) What institutional arrangements does the Minister have planned to ensure that the long-term project being undertaken by staff within the Division of Atmospheric Research and Division of Oceanography dealing with the coupled ocean-atmosphere-ice system will not be affected by the proposed split of the Division of Oceanography from the CSIRO.
(3) Does this project provide the opportunity for Australia to play a leading role in research into year-to-year climate variations and Greenhouse induced climate change.

(4) What effect will the proposed restructure of CSIRO have on the Memorandum of Understanding between the Sydney Water Board and the CSIRO, under which the Division of Oceanography is engaged in experiments in Sydney's near-shore region to examine the effect of the deepwater ocean outfalls.

(5) With reference to the fact that two years ago, Coastal Zone research was identified by CSIRO as a priority area of scientific research and that the Coastal Zone Project now involves six CSIRO Divisions, including Fisheries and Oceanography, what guarantees will be given that the splitting of Fisheries and Oceanography from CSIRO will have no adverse effect on the Coastal Zone Project.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government has decided to implement a consultation and review process to examine the need for changes to the way national marine science and fisheries research is structured in order to better serve client needs, particularly marine-based industries. The consultation and review process is being led by Professor Ken McKinnon, Vice-Chancellor of the University of Wollongong who prepared the major Oceans of Wealth? report for the Government in 1989. Professor McKinnon will report to the Government late in October this year and any decision on restructuring marine science and fisheries research, including the two CSIRO marine divisions, will not be made until after his report is received and considered by the Government.

Among the issues that will be examined when the Government considers Professor McKinnon's report will be ways to maximise cross-disciplinary research, not just within the CSIRO, but across the broader spectrum of the Commonwealth's marine science and fisheries research.

The Government, on my recommendation, has implemented the consultation and review process to examine ways of better strengthening and focussing the national marine science effort. This is especially important given the impending declaration of Australia's Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). The EEZ will represent an area about 1.5 times our land mass. Its declaration will result in heightened demands being placed on our marine science effort, and will present both major challenges to the Government to ensure sustainable development and management as well as providing new opportunities for growth of marine-based industries.
(2) The honourable Senator is referred to the answer to part 1.

(3) The project to which the honourable Senator refers is called the CSIRO Climate Change Research Program. The aim of the project is to combine data collection on ocean, sea ice and terrestrial environments with the development of numerical climate change models. The project makes an important international contribution to climate modelling because of its data collection on the Southern Hemisphere and Oceans. As the main developed country in this part of the world, Australia is in a unique position to contribute and I am very pleased that the CSIRO is doing this.

(4) Any changes that the Government might consider to the CSIRO marine divisions, including the Division of Oceanography, will ensure that necessary arrangements are in place to ensure that existing contracts and other such obligations are fully met. Indeed, the Government's consideration of current arrangements for marine science are driven by a desire to ensure that its broad client needs are properly met now and in the future.
(5) The honourable Senator is referred to the answer to part 1.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What action, if any, has been taken by the Treasurer or his predecessors to implement the recommendations of the House of Representatives Select Committee on the Print Media, March 1992, concerning the collection and publication of information by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on the characteristics and performance of the Australian print media industry.
(2) If no action has been taken: (a) why not; and (b) will any action be taken on this matter; if so, when and what action will be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) has available a range of statistical information relevant to the characteristics and performance of the Australian printing and publishing industry. The statistics available include commodity, structural and performance information, imports and exports statistics, and information related to persons employed in the Australian print media.
The classification of industry statistics in Australia has followed the Australian Standard Industry Classification (ASIC), which had as specific industry classes:
ASIC 2641 Publishing, and
ASIC 2642 Printing and Publishing.

This year, a new industry classification, Australian and New Zealand Standard Industry Classification (ANZSIC) has been published, and will be introduced into ABS statistical collections progressively over the next few years. The ANZSIC classes most relevant to the print media are:
ANZSIC 2421 Newspaper Printing or Publishing, and
ANZSIC 2422 Other Periodical Publishing.
Some other classes, such as ANZSIC 2413 Services to Printing and ANZSIC 2423 Book and Other Publishing may also be relevant, depending on the nature of any intended use of statistics.
Once this classification is fully integrated into all ABS collections, the full range of statistical information outlined above will be available for the newspaper printing and publishing industry.

Because of the volume of statistics available from ABS sources, only a limited amount can be included in regular publications. Special tabulations are available upon request. The extent of detail in such tabulations may be constrained by the confidentiality provisions of the Census and Statistics Act 1905, and, in some cases, by the sample design of the survey from which the data comes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport a Territories, upon notice, on 27 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has a recovery plan been implemented or prepared for Acacia axillaris, which is listed as a vulnerable species.
(2) If no plan has been prepared, what is the timetable for preparing a plan.
(3) Does the Acacia axillaris exist only on the banks of the Elizabeth River at Campbell Town, Tasmania; if not, where else does it exist.

(4) Has the recent clearing of the banks of the river by bulldozers reduced the number of plants; if so, does this mean that the plant now has become endangered; if so, will the Acacia axillaris be added to the list of species that are endangered.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A recovery plan has not been prepared for Acacia axillaris. Research has been carried out by the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Land Management, with funding from the Commonwealth's Endangered Species Program, on a group of species including Acacia axillaris. The report on this research will include management recommendations and will be published shortly.

(2) That research will identify species requiring recovery plans. If Acacia axillaris is so identified the preparation of a recovery plan would probably be undertaken in 1994 by the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Land Management.

(3) No. Acacia axillaris also occurs on the Dukes and St Pauls Rivers, at Ginger Marsh, Mount Barrow (where it is reserved), at Keach Hill and at other sites on the Elizabeth River, including the headwaters of the Elizabeth River (where some of the best populations occur).

(4) In the opinion of officers of the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Land Management, the bulldozing operation has not reduced the numbers of Acacia axillaris, as it is believed that none of the individual plants was lost as a result of the recent work.

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the date of export of koalas to Milwaukee Zoo, the age and sexes of koalas received by that zoo and details of the source of that export.
(2) Has Milwaukee Zoo entered into a paying arrangement with the Australian Government or the source zoo for the loan of these koalas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (l) No koalas have been exported from Australia to the Milwaukee Zoo. According to information received from the Zoological Society of San Diego, Milwaukee Zoo currently has two female koalas, aged 29 and 27 months. These animals were transferred from the San Diego Zoo and are progeny from animals exported prior to proclamation of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 on 1 May 1984.

(2) Milwaukee Zoo has not entered into any paying arrangement with the Australian Government for the two koalas they currently hold and the Australian Government does not know if any paying arrangement exists between the Milwaukee Zoo and the San Diego Zoo.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 29 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has a Northern Territory-based Department of Employment, Education and Training staff member received funding under the Training for Aboriginals Program (TAP) training program of around $50,000 to undertake training for a helicopter pilot's licence; if so, is the staff member a full-time officer of the department and is the position substantive; if so, what funding was provided and over what period.
(2) Was the course successfully completed and does the staff member now, as a result, hold a helicopter pilot's licence; if not, why not.
(3) What are the eligibility criteria for grants or assistance provided under the TAP program.
(4) Under what circumstances are persons employed as full-time permanent members of the Commonwealth public service eligible for assistance under the TAP program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A full-time Department of Employment, Education and Training staff member who was occupying a substantive position in the Tennant Creek Office was placed under the Training for Aboriginals Program (TAP) on 21 April 1992 to undertake helicopter pilot training. The amount was for $34,300 over a period of four months.
(2) The trainee developed health problems. He has not completed all aspects of the course.
(3) Under the guidelines applicable to TAP at that time, individuals were eligible to receive assistance under the program if they met the following criteria:
they were an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person;
they were registered with the CES as unemployed or seeking other employment or an improved position;
they were assessed by the CES as likely to benefit from the employment/training opportunity and were able and willing to undertake it.

(4) Under the guidelines then applicable, TAP assistance was available to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people who were already employed, provided they met the criteria set out above. That included Commonwealth public servants.

One of the objectives of the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy is to widen the spread of occupations and industries in which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are employed, in recognition of the fact that much Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander employment is in relatively low paid jobs that require low levels of skill. One means of achieving this is through assisting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to acquire employment of high status and wages and thus provide role models for other members of their communities.

Nevertheless, I consider it important that there can be no reasonable grounds for concluding that an officer of the Department has been treated more favourably under the program than people who are not officers of the Department but whose circumstances otherwise are similar. The TAP guidelines are currently under review. It is intended that TAP will continue to be available to employed persons who need assistance to progress to more highly skilled employment or to another occupation or industry and who cannot be assisted through other programs or services, including assistance that would normally be provided by the employer. The Australian Public Service Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Recruitment and Career Development Strategy should provide adequate training opportunities for people to advance through the public service. However, TAP may be available for public servants who require it to move to other employment. Henceforth, it is proposed that only Senior Executives may approve the provision of this assistance in cases where officers of the Department apply for TAP assistance other than through the APS Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Recruitment and Career Development Strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 6 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to page 40 of the Department of Administrative Services 1991-92 annual report where it is claimed that staff morale in the Australian Valuation Office (AVO) has increased by 15 percent: (a) how is this measured; (b) is it an ongoing evaluation; and (c) who has the task of assessing staff morale.

(2) With reference to the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) report into the operations of the Queensland Branch of AVO in which it stated that AVO needed a `detailed marketing strategy and action plan that identifies potential clients, sets sales targets and schedules and outline the means of achieving them': (a) who is responsible for designing this marketing strategy and action plan; (b) has this plan been finalised; (c) how many and which officers drafted this plan; and (d) does this apply to each State and territory or to Queensland alone.
(3) How many valuers and trainee valuers are employed in each State and territory by AVO.
(4) How many administrative staff are employed in each State and territory by AVO.

(5) With reference to the report by ANAO into the operations of the Queensland Branch of AVO: (a) have performance indicators been reviewed; and (b) what changes in measuring performance have been made and/or implemented.
(6) For each State and territory, what is the average response time for requests received by AVO.
(7) Was the Western Australian Branch of AVO involved in evaluating the rental value of the Northbridge Branch of the Australian Taxation Office; if so, when was the evaluation conducted.
(8) Did AVO prepare a report on the rental and/or sale value of 1 St George's Terrace; if so, when and what were the valuations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a)-(c) Staff morale in the Australian Valuation Office has been measured by staff surveys undertaken and interpreted by the DAS Staff Development Section. A further survey is to be undertaken during 1993-94.

(2) (a) The executive of the Brisbane region of AVO has been responsible for the development of that region's marketing plans; (b) The marketing plan is developed in conjunction with the region's annual budget and operational planning cycle; (c) All staff within the region had input to this planning process; and (d) Similar processes apply within other AVO regions.
(3)&(4) The following table gives the numbers of valuers and administrative staff in the central and regional offices (trainee valuers are not employed):

(5) (a) & (b) Performance indicators are reviewed each year in conjunction with the annual business planning cycle and a monthly reporting process on timeliness has been implemented in addition to the weekly review mechanisms noted in the auditor's report.

(6) The AVO does not measure the average response time per request, as customer requirements can vary from same day turn around through to five months, in the case of the Department of Social Security's Asset Test Review Program, or to twelve months for the ACT Government's annual rating program.
(7) In January 1990, the AVO's Perth Office undertook a rental valuation on the premises now occupied by the Australian Taxation Office at Northbridge.

(8) The AVO has prepared both rental and sale valuations of 1 St George's Terrace, Perth—the latest being on 4 August 1993. As this property is in the throes of being marketed, the AVO's client has requested that details of actual valuations be regarded as "Commercial-in-Confidence" and not be divulged.
